Examples are drawn from a variety of content areas: history; geography; anthropology; sociology; political science and/or economics. Emphasises participatory citizenship, culture and traditions in a pluralistic society.
EDCI404.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 404, EDCI 414, ED-E 746, EDUC 404, IED 404.

EDCI405.title: Mathematical Processes B
EDCI405.subject: EDCI
EDCI405.description: The application of effective teaching practices (establishing goals, reasoning, problem solving, representation, connections, discourse, questioning, building fluency, supporting struggle, assessing understanding) to the teaching and learning of Elementary and Middle School patterning, geometry, measurement, data, probability and financial literacy topics.
EDCI405.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 405, EDCI 415, ED-E 743, EDUC 405, IED 405.

EDCI410.title: Literacy in the Digital Age
EDCI410.subject: EDCI
EDCI410.description: An exploration of how new digital technologies have changed reading and writing for adolescents, and how these changing practices influence language and literacy teaching and learning.

EDCI412.title: Language and Literacies Pedagogy Reading Diverse Texts
EDCI412.subject: EDCI
EDCI412.description: A focus on reading development and instruction in the context of engaging learners in reading, viewing and using multiple forms of text in elementary and middle school classrooms. Theoretical perspectives on reading as well as societal and cultural factors which influence literacy development are examined. Strategies for addressing diverse needs of all learners and assessment of learning are explored.
EDCI412.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 412, EDCI 402.
  • May be offered in English or French.

EDCI413.title: Pedagogy for Science Education
EDCI413.subject: EDCI
EDCI413.description: Curriculum organization, instructional strategies and assessment practices in elementary or middle school science. Includes consideration of the nature of science, the interactions of science, technology, society and environment, and the content, processes and attitudes prescribed in the provincial curriculum.
EDCI413.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 413, EDCI 403.
  • May be offered in English or French.

EDCI414.title: Pedagogy for Social Studies Education
EDCI414.subject: EDCI
EDCI414.description: Curriculum organization, instructional approaches and assessment practices in elementary or middle school social studies. Interdisciplinary examples are drawn from; anthropology, economics, gender studies, geography, history, political science and/or sociology, with emphasis on inquiry learning, community engagement, First Nations' Principles of Learning, participatory citizenship and social justice imperatives in a pluralistic society.
EDCI414.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 414, EDCI 404.
  • May be offered in English or French.

EDCI415.title: Pedagogy for Mathematics Education
EDCI415.subject: EDCI
EDCI415.description: Application of effective teaching practices (establishing goals, reasoning, problem solving, representation, connections, discourse, questioning, building fluency, supporting struggle, assessing understanding) to the teaching and learning of Elementary and Middle School mathematics.
EDCI415.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 415, EDCI 405.
  • May be offered in English or French.

EDCI422.title: Curriculum and Program Design in Early Childhood Education
EDCI422.subject: EDCI
EDCI422.description: Practical strategies for the development of early childhood curricula and the planning and administration of programs for preschool, daycare and kindergarten. Examines current topics such as integration, multiculturalism, family involvement, and program evaluation.
EDCI422.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 422, ED-B 441.

EDCI428.title: Adapting Mathematics Curriculum and Instruction
EDCI428.subject: EDCI
EDCI428.description: Development and use of instructional methods and materials appropriate for children with learning difficulties in mathematics. Ways of adapting curricula and instruction in other content areas and technological support for children with special education needs are also considered.
EDCI428.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 428, EDCI 424B, EDUC 422, EDUC 422B.

EDCI431.title: Philosophical Foundations of Education
EDCI431.subject: EDCI
EDCI431.description: The origins and meaning of social and philosophical ideas and how these ideas influence the lives of children and teachers in schools. The major philosophical systems and ideologies that have shaped and continue to shape educational thought and practice are the focus of this course.
EDCI431.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 431, ED-B 420.

EDCI432.title: Historical Foundations of Education
EDCI432.subject: EDCI
EDCI432.description: The historical foundations of contemporary Canadian schooling and the forces that regulate educational change, reform and the nature of the teacher's work.
EDCI432.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 432, ED-B 423.

EDCI433.title: Anthropology and Education
EDCI433.subject: EDCI
EDCI433.description: Theory and perspectives from cultural anthropology relevant to the processes of education and operations of schools.
EDCI433.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 433, ED-B 425.

EDCI434.title: Sociological Foundations of Education
EDCI434.subject: EDCI
EDCI434.description: The impact of sociological variables such as poverty, ethnicity, culture, gender and social diversity on classroom teaching and life in contemporary Canadian schools.
EDCI434.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 434, ED-B 427.

EDCI441.title: Supporting Learners Experiencing Difficulties with Literacy I
EDCI441.subject: EDCI
EDCI441.description: Focus on assessment and instructional issues, practices and strategies for students who experience difficulties with reading and writing. A practical component involves administering and interpreting an informal reading assessment to a student who struggles with literacy, and planning an appropriate instructional intervention.
EDCI441.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 441, EDCI 446, ED-B 442.

EDCI443.title: Personalizing and Differentiating Instruction in Literacy
EDCI443.subject: EDCI
EDCI443.description: Examines the theoretical framework, foundational concepts and exemplary practices of differentiating instruction in literacies in the context of personalized learning environment. Emphasizes teacher responsiveness to the needs, strengths and aspirations of all students.
EDCI443.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 443, EDCI 487 (if taken in the same topic).

EDCI447.title: Principles of Teaching English Language Learning
EDCI447.subject: EDCI
EDCI447.description: A survey of principles and theories for, and the teaching of English to second language learners. The examination of curriculum and methodology for use with English language learners in the elementary and secondary schools.
EDCI447.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 447, EDCI 457, ED-B 490, ED-B 491.

EDCI448.title: Organization and Procedures for Instruction of English to Second Language Learners
EDCI448.subject: EDCI
EDCI448.description: The examination of current models for the organization and instruction of ESL students at the elementary and secondary levels. The integration of language and content instruction within the regular classroom is emphasized.
EDCI448.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 448, ED-B 490, ED-B 492.

EDCI451.title: Community and Culture
EDCI451.subject: EDCI
EDCI451.description: Designed to provide students with an appreciation of the utility of culture as a framework for understanding teaching and learning. Students explore the roles and impacts they have as teachers and community members in the transmission and transformation of culture. Investigates the implications and challenges of teaching in a multicultural society.
EDCI451.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 451, EDUC 431.

EDCI452.title: Cultural Studies in Education
EDCI452.subject: EDCI
EDCI452.description: Focuses on the school both as a community of learners and as a part of a larger community in a changing world. Topics of study include different conceptions of community as they relate to education and learning, relations of power in school and community settings, gender roles, ethnicity, spirituality, traditions of conflict resolution, human rights and the effects of global systems on local communities.
EDCI452.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 452, EDUC 432.

EDCI454.title: Environmental Education
EDCI454.subject: EDCI
EDCI454.description: This multidisciplinary course is designed to familiarize the educator with a range of issues and teaching methods related to environmental education. Topics include goals for environmental and outdoor education; environmental ethics; current issues and trends; multicultural perspectives towards the land; local, national and global issues, teaching strategies for understanding and resolving environmental issues; program and unit planning. Selected field trips to locations emphasizing current environmental issues.
EDCI454.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 454, EDUC 434.

EDCI455.title: The Evolution of Educational Ideas: Philosophy, History and the Classroom
EDCI455.subject: EDCI
EDCI455.description: The impact of educational philosophy and the history of education on the culture of the schools. Topics include the evolution and implications of educational ideas and the changing role of the school in society.
EDCI455.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 455, EDUC 436.

EDCI456.title: Community Development Project
EDCI456.subject: EDCI
EDCI456.description: Designed to provide students an opportunity to develop and implement a school-based community development project. Working in groups, with a faculty mentor, students design projects that reflect the principles and themes of community action and positive social change. Sample projects could include environmental protection and restoration initiatives, community based violence prevention programs, home- and school-based media literacy campaigns or multicultural and cultural sensitivity programs.
EDCI456.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 456, EDUC 437.

EDCI457.title: English Language Learning
EDCI457.subject: EDCI
EDCI457.description: A survey of curriculum and instruction designed to develop beginning competence for teaching English as a second language. There are three main themes: language instruction techniques, evaluation of the language and educational needs of English language learners, and developing sensitivity for the prior educational and cultural experiences of English language learners.
EDCI457.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 457, EDCI 447, EDUC 438, ED-B 491.

EDCI463.title: Visual Thinking
EDCI463.subject: EDCI
EDCI463.description: Visual artists use a variety of strategies to develop original imagery, find creative solutions to problems and express ideas that cannot be conveyed in any other medium. Students explore the methods artists use to create and communicate. Though they arise from art, the methods can be applied to many other areas of learning. Developmentally appropriate classroom activities and teaching methods are recommended as ways of engaging elementary students in visual thinking.
EDCI463.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 463, EDUC 443.

EDCI469.title: Teaching Oral French
EDCI469.subject: EDCI
EDCI469.description: Theoretical and practical elements of teaching French as a second language for the general classroom teacher. Introduces teaching strategies to promote communication with purpose and confidence, effectively teach language acquisition, select authentic learning resources, use technology and immerse students in Francophone culture. Language of instruction includes both French and English. Provides opportunities to increase proficiency in French, incorporate First People's Principles of Learning and expand appreciation of Francophone cultures.
EDCI469.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 469, ED-B 391, EDUC 448.

EDCI474.title: Rural Education
EDCI474.subject: EDCI
EDCI474.description: Introduces teaching in rural settings, focusing on the theoretical, curricular and pedagogical foundations to create a rewarding teaching experience and a meaningful learning environment for students in small, rural schools. Includes: defining rurality; urbanormativity; theories of justice; place-consciousness; the unique features of teaching and learning in rural spaces; the importance of relationships; living in small communities.​
EDCI474.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 474, EDCI 487 (if taken in the same topic).

EDCI475.title: Principles in Teaching French Immersion
EDCI475.subject: EDCI
EDCI475.description: The basic curricula and evaluation as required of the French Immersion program, and an understanding of the similarities and differences between teaching in Immersion and the English program. Emphasizes how students develop literacy and numeracy in French Immersion while mastering the skills and concepts laid out in all subject areas as required by the BC curriculum. This course is taught in French.

EDCI476.title: Organization and Instruction in French Immersion
EDCI476.subject: EDCI
EDCI476.description: An examination of current models for the organization and instruction of French Immersion students at the elementary and secondary level. Participants define and articulate those critical factors that ensure lessons and units of study enable students to learn language as well as concepts/skills. This course is taught in French.

EDCI477.title: Designs for Learning in French Immersion
EDCI477.subject: EDCI
EDCI477.description: Assessment and evaluation within the context of French Immersion's language and content methodology. Emphasis is on planning, analysis and evaluation. Canadian and International models of language learning and assessment are examined. This course is taught in French.

EDCI487.title: Special Topics in Education
EDCI487.subject: EDCI
EDCI487.notes: • May be offered in English or French.

EDCI488.title: Special Topics in Education
EDCI488.subject: EDCI
EDCI488.notes:
• May be offered in English or French.
  • Students in an education degree program require permission of the Teacher Education Advising Office to apply the additional 1.5 units credit towards their degree program.

EDCI490.title: Transformative Inquiry
EDCI490.subject: EDCI
EDCI490.description: Focus on dialogic learning, teacher as researcher and other ways of knowing to identify and explore personally meaningful topics within teaching practice. Individual reflection, collaborative processes and mentoring sessions with instructor culminate in student facilitated inquiry conversations where the intricacies and overlapping issues of transformative pedagogy are considered and assimilated.
EDCI490.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 490, ED-P 490, IED 490.
  • May be offered in English or French.

EDCI496.title: Professional Communication for Personal Success
EDCI496.subject: EDCI
EDCI496.description: Focuses on the effective design and delivery of print, multimodal, and oral communications for successful engagement of professional and student audiences. Examines the relevancy and persuasiveness of diverse print and digital-based communication formats in varied contemporary educational contexts through theory and practice.

EDCI499.title: Professional Development - Curriculum and Instruction
EDCI499.subject: EDCI
EDCI499.description: A variable content course directed at improving specific teacher and/or administrator competencies. Normally offered off campus.
EDCI499.notes: • Not more than 3 units of credit for any EDCI 499 courses may be approved as electives in an education degree program.

EDCI706.title: Curriculum and Instruction in Secondary School Art
EDCI706.subject: EDCI
EDCI706.description: As the last formal stage in becoming an art teacher, this course prepares students for their practicum experience. It examines relationships between the practical and theoretical aspects of art education. Students are introduced to various teaching methodologies appropriate for implementing the curriculum, teaching styles are discussed and explored, and students design lessons and develop learning activities around specific concepts.
EDCI706.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 706, ED-A 750.

EDCI716.title: Curriculum and Instruction in Secondary School Theatre
EDCI716.subject: EDCI
EDCI716.description: Designed to prepare theatre/drama education students for the teaching profession. Provides students with one of the many bridges connecting their university theatre and drama experiences to the world of the secondary school. The focus is on the how, what, and why of classroom drama.
EDCI716.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 716, ED-A 767.

EDCI746.title: Curriculum and Instruction in Secondary School French
EDCI746.subject: EDCI
EDCI746.description: An opportunity to develop abilities in teaching and testing the language features (pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar and cultural component) and the language skills (listening, speaking, reading and writing) and to familiarize students with current French language teaching approaches through the study of representative materials and techniques. Emphasis is placed on practical classroom techniques and the challenges particular to teaching French in the secondary school.
EDCI746.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 746, ED-B 754.

EDCI747.title: Curriculum and Instruction in Secondary School English
EDCI747.subject: EDCI
EDCI747.description: Prepares students to instruct and assess secondary English language arts. Explores a variety of teaching and assessment strategies, resources and current research into the challenges and possibilities of teaching English language arts.
EDCI747.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 747, ED-B 753.

EDCI749.title: General Methods of Second Language Teaching
EDCI749.subject: EDCI
EDCI749.description: An opportunity to develop abilities in teaching and testing the language features (pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar and cultural component) and the language skills (listening, speaking, reading and writing) and to familiarize students with current second language teaching approaches through the study of representative materials and techniques. Emphasis is placed on practical classroom techniques and the challenges particular to teaching second languages.
EDCI749.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 749, ED-B 756.

EDCI757.title: Curriculum and Instruction in Secondary School Mathematics
EDCI757.subject: EDCI
EDCI757.description: Helps students develop the pedagogical content knowledge needed to teach secondary school mathematics. This includes knowledge about: the goals, content and sequence of the 8-12 mathematics curriculum, how students learn mathematics, how to plan instructional activities, lessons and units that are meaningful and mathematically correct, teaching strategies that instill in all students enthusiasm and satisfaction in learning and using mathematics, and how to develop and apply appropriate assessment and evaluation techniques. Explores how to establish classroom environments that facilitate problem solving; conceptual understanding, autonomy and issues related to equity and multi-culturalism in teaching mathematics.
EDCI757.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 757, ED-E 761.

EDCI761.title: Curriculum and Instruction in Secondary School Music
EDCI761.subject: EDCI
EDCI761.description: Designed to provide students with practical strategies that will inform and enhance professional practice in the secondary music classroom. Through teaching opportunities, presentations, readings and discussion, this course develops personal knowledge related to pedagogical issues in music, curriculum design and implementation, program management, assessment strategies and professional portfolio building.
EDCI761.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 761, ED-A 762.

EDCI767.title: Curriculum and Instruction in Secondary School Science
EDCI767.subject: EDCI
EDCI767.description: A study of the curriculum organization, instructional strategies, and assessment practices in secondary sciences. Includes consideration of the nature of science, the interactions of science, technology, society and environment, the development of science literacy through constructivist approaches to teaching, and selected current trends and issues in science education such as meeting the needs of diverse students and the use of technology in the science classroom.
EDCI767.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 767, ED-E 769.
  • Students with teaching areas in biology, chemistry, physics, or general will enrol in this course.

EDCI773.title: Curriculum and Instruction in Secondary School Social Sciences
EDCI773.subject: EDCI
EDCI773.description: Explores the area of Social Studies as a multidisciplinary subject that draws from the social sciences and humanities to study human interaction with natural and social environments. While there is a theoretical component to the course, the learning of best practices in social studies education dominates.
EDCI773.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 773, ED-E 757.

EDCI780.title: Secondary Field Experience Seminar
EDCI780.subject: EDCI
EDCI780.description: A series of seminars providing assistance in planning for practicum, discussion of topics of common concern for student teachers, and current issues related to instruction.
EDCI780.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EDCI 780, ED-P 780.

EDCI787.title: Cross-curricular Inquiry Strategies
EDCI787.subject: EDCI
EDCI787.description: Inquiry-focused, project-based learning strategies applicable across a range of subject areas, and adaptable to learners' needs, interests and competencies, will be presented, experienced and critically examined. Grouping structures that facilitate collaborative investigations and interactions, and multi-format presentations, are featured.

EDUC100.title: Introduction to Education
EDUC100.subject: EDUC
EDUC100.description: A broad understanding of education, formal and informal, through an exploration of what education is and how it is articulated. Participants inquire about: the nature of knowledge/ knowing; the nature of learning/ learners; the varied roles of educators (e.g. teacher, leader, researcher, mentor, community steward); and the educational challenges of work-life balance.

ENGR001.title: Work Term 1
ENGR001.subject: ENGR
ENGR001.description: Students are employed for a work term, normally of four months' duration. Competencies typically addressed include personal management and work place behaviour. Provides an introduction to a productive work experience that is related to the student's program of studies and individual interests.

ENGR002.title: Work Term 2
ENGR002.subject: ENGR
ENGR002.description: Students are employed for a work term, normally of four months' duration. Competencies typically addressed include communication and teamwork. Should generally provide an increased level of responsibility in an area that is related to the student's program of studies and individual interests.

ENGR003.title: Work Term 3
ENGR003.subject: ENGR
ENGR003.description: Students are employed for a work term, normally of four months' duration. Competencies typically addressed include managing information, research and problem solving, and commitment to quality. Should generally provide an increased level of responsibility in an area that is related to the area of specialization in the student's program of studies.

ENGR004.title: Work Term 4
ENGR004.subject: ENGR
ENGR004.description: Students are employed for a work term, normally of four months' duration. Competencies typically addressed include project and task management, social responsibility and continuous learning. Should generally provide a path to a career choice in the student's anticipated degree.

ENGR110.title: Design and Communication I
ENGR110.subject: ENGR
ENGR110.description: Introductory principles of engineering design processes through practical projects to be undertaken by teams of students; integrated development and demonstration of writing, research, design and presentation skills through research and design projects. Writing, research and organizational skills appropriate for University level writing.
ENGR110.notes: • Not open for credit to students registered in or with credit in any of ENGR 111, ENGR 112, ATWP 135, ELEC 199, ENGL 115, ENGL 135.

ENGR112.title: Design I
ENGR112.subject: ENGR
ENGR112.description: Introductory principles of engineering design processes through practical projects to be undertaken by teams of students.
ENGR112.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 112, ENGR 110, ENGR 111, ELEC 199.

ENGR120.title: Design and Communication II
ENGR120.subject: ENGR
ENGR120.description: Principles of engineering science and design applied to practical projects undertaken by student teams. Integrated development and demonstration of writing, research, design and presentation skills. Referencing methods for scientific and technical literature. Characteristics of effective technical and scientific style. Emphasis on clarity, precision, and consistency. Practical experience in writing short technical documents such as memoranda, letters, abstracts, reports, papers, manuals, brochures, and specifications.
ENGR120.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 120, ENGR 121, ENGR 240, ENGL 225, ENSH 202.

ENGR121.title: Design II
ENGR121.subject: ENGR
ENGR121.description: Principles of engineering design with application to biomedical, civil, computer, electrical, mechanical and software engineering through practical projects to be undertaken by teams of students.
ENGR121.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 121, ENGR 120.

ENGR130.title: Introduction to Professional Practice
ENGR130.subject: ENGR
ENGR130.description: Awareness of the role and responsibilities of Professional Engineers in society with respect to the environment, ethics, equity, public and worker safety and health considerations. Introduction to technical and other forms of work term and/or work experience report preparation, understanding national and international placement standards, WorkSafeBC standards, engineering logbooks. Development of effective interview techniques, skill assessment and analysis, career management and development. Preparation of resumés and cover letters.
ENGR130.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 130, ENGR 020.

ENGR141.title: Engineering Mechanics
ENGR141.subject: ENGR
ENGR141.description: Forces, moments of forces, couples, resultants of force systems; distributed loads; hydrostatics; conditions of equilibrium and applications to particles and rigid bodies in two dimensions; analysis of statically determinate structures including beams, trusses and arches; bending moment and shear force diagrams; dry friction.
ENGR141.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 141, MECH 141, MECH 241, MECH 245.

ENGR240.title: Technical Writing
ENGR240.subject: ENGR
ENGR240.description: Searching and referencing methods used in dealing with scientific and technical literature and on the characteristics of effective technical and scientific style. The emphasis throughout is on clarity, precision and consistency. Students acquire practical experience in the writing of short technical documents such as memoranda, letters and abstracts, longer forms such as reports, papers, and theses, and instructional forms such as manuals, brochures and specifications.
ENGR240.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENGR 240, ENGR 120, ENGL 225, ENGL 226, ENGL 240.

ENGR297.title: Technology and Society
ENGR297.subject: ENGR
ENGR297.description: Introduction to the effects of technology on society including the ethical, environmental, cultural, social, economic and political issues raised by technological change. The concepts of sustainability, civil society, engineering law (negligence and product liability torts, contract law and consumer protection statutes) and environmental stewardship are addressed in the context of systems engineering design.

ENGR446.title: Technical Report
ENGR446.subject: ENGR
ENGR446.description: A major technical report demonstrating written communication and analytical skills. Includes development and approval of topic, adherence to reporting guidelines and management of time constraints.

ENGR498.title: Engineering Law
ENGR498.subject: ENGR
ENGR498.description: Sources and classification of law; professional engineering legislation, registration and discipline; introduction to tort law including negligence; introduction to contract law including employment law. Ethics in professional practice.

ENSH101.title: Themes in Literature (AWR)
ENSH101.subject: ENSH
ENSH101.description: Introduces literary criticism through particular themes and a wide study of literary forms (may include short story, novel, drama, and poetry). Develops skills for writing about literature and making research-based academic arguments in any discipline.
ENSH101.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 101, ENGL 116, ENGL 121, ENGL 122, ENGL 125, ENGL 146.
  • This course satisfies the Academic Writing Requirement.

ENSH102.title: Literature in Action (AWR)
ENSH102.subject: ENSH
ENSH102.description: Introduces literary and cultural criticism through a focused study of a small set of texts. Combines an examination of the influences at work on literary texts with a study of how those texts are then circulated and interpreted. Develops skills for writing about literature and making research-based academic arguments in any discipline.
ENSH102.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 102, ENGL 116, ENGL 121, ENGL 122, ENGL 145, ENGL 147.
  • This course satisfies the Academic Writing Requirement.

ENSH200.title: Foundations of Writing Literary Criticism
ENSH200.subject: ENSH
ENSH200.description: Introduces basic categories and problems of literary criticism. Skills include close reading, using critical vocabulary, using textual evidence and contextual information, and writing confidently about literature.
ENSH200.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 200 and ENGL 209.

ENSH201.title: Writing with Style
ENSH201.subject: ENSH
ENSH201.description: An intermediate writing course designed to improve student command of the styles and methods of nonfiction prose. Combines the style of popular writing techniques with a practical focus on student writing.
ENSH201.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 201 and ENGL 215.

ENSH202.title: Technical Communications, Written and Verbal
ENSH202.subject: ENSH
ENSH202.description: Assists students who plan careers in business, government, public service and research institutions. Improve written and oral communication skills in a work environment. Its practical basis, which requires the preparation of business letters, internal memoranda and reports, is supplemented by a theoretical outline of basic communication within an organizational structure. Offers experience of both individual and group problem-solving.
ENSH202.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 202, ENGL 225, ENGR 120, ENGR 240.

ENSH203.title: Professional Communication Foundations
ENSH203.subject: ENSH
ENSH203.description: Introduction to communication theories as applied to professional workplaces, teaching relevant skills in written, oral and visual communication that meet the needs of internal and external audiences. Considers diverse communication scenarios to prompt students to craft clear informative and persuasive documents, conduct research to support reports and proposals and deliver professional presentations across multimodal channels.

ENSH210.title: How Poetry Works
ENSH210.subject: ENSH
ENSH210.description: Surveys poems in English from different periods and places, in various genres and styles, with a focus on the pleasurable uses of poetic language and meaning and the core concepts and common vocabulary used to discuss poetry.

ENSH211.title: How Fiction Works
ENSH211.subject: ENSH
ENSH211.description: Surveys a selection of stories and novels in English with a focus on the ways in which fiction explores human experience. Includes core concepts and a common vocabulary for discussing fiction.

ENSH212.title: How Drama Works
ENSH212.subject: ENSH
ENSH212.description: Surveys plays in English from different periods and places, in various genres and styles, with a focus on the core concepts and common vocabulary used to discuss drama.

ENSH213.title: How Popular Genres Work
ENSH213.subject: ENSH
ENSH213.description: Surveys literature in English in relation to popular genres (such as science fiction, fantasy, romance, mystery, horror and historical fiction) across books, film, television and more. Includes core concepts and a common vocabulary for discussing popular genres.

ENSH220.title: Cultural Studies
ENSH220.subject: ENSH
ENSH220.description: Introduces students to different ways of studying popular culture, including forms and content, definitions and genres, audiences, power, production and transmission.
ENSH220.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 220, ENGL 207.

ENSH221.title: Women's Writing
ENSH221.subject: ENSH
ENSH221.description: A study of literature by women in English; texts from one or more traditions, genres, or periods considered from a variety of approaches, or a special focus on one woman writer.
ENSH221.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 221, ENGL 208.

ENSH222.title: Erotic Literature
ENSH222.subject: ENSH
ENSH222.description: Studies erotic writing in English or within Anglophone traditions of Britain and Ireland; may include comparative analysis of ancient and non-Anglophone texts and traditions in translation. Focuses on what counted as erotic in different historical contexts and how different sexualities are represented.
ENSH222.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 222, ENGL 230 (if taken 202009, 202101, 202201, 202301).

ENSH223.title: Narrative Worldmaking
ENSH223.subject: ENSH
ENSH223.description: Surveys how stories make and remake imaginative worlds, focusing on speculative genres that include fantasy, dystopian and sci-fi in various media.

ENSH224.title: Literary Modernism
ENSH224.subject: ENSH
ENSH224.description: Surveys major works of fiction, poetry and drama from the modernist period (roughly 1900-45), with emphasis on the dynamic relation between revolutions in aesthetic form and social, psychological and intellectual developments that marked the early 20th century.
ENSH224.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 224, ENGL 201.

ENSH230.title: Literature, Self and Society
ENSH230.subject: ENSH
ENSH230.description: A theme-based analysis of literature from various places and times focusing on broad but limited questions of the relations between self and society. Specific iterations may include discussions of power and authority, love, history, race, gender, sexuality and more.
ENSH230.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 230, ENGL 262.

ENSH231.title: Literature and Psychology
ENSH231.subject: ENSH
ENSH231.description: Literature in relation to a selection of influential psychological theories, concepts and issues. May include study of literature’s influence on psychological theory as well as how and why psychological theories help inform a number of literary works.

ENSH232.title: Literature and Myth
ENSH232.subject: ENSH
ENSH232.description: A study of selected narratives in English in relation to their mythological sources and contexts.
ENSH232.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 232, ENGL 393 (if taken in the same topic).

ENSH233.title: The Bible as Literature
ENSH233.subject: ENSH
ENSH233.description: Surveys basic stories and books in the Old and New Testaments with a focus on their literary features. Familiarizes students with important biblical stories, genres and references in literature and religious discourse.
ENSH233.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 233, ENGL 260, ENGL 365 (if taken prior to December 1983), ENGL 409, RCS 260, RS 260.

ENSH240.title: Introduction to a Major Author
ENSH240.subject: ENSH
ENSH240.description: Focuses on several works by a single major author.
ENSH240.notes: • May be taken more than once for credit in different topics to a maximum of 3 units.

ENSH250.title: British Literature to 1660
ENSH250.subject: ENSH
ENSH250.description: A survey of selected literary works in Britain up to the Restoration, in some combination of poetry, prose and drama. May be organized around some prominent themes.
ENSH250.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 250, ENGL 150, ENGL 200, ENGL 200A.

ENSH251.title: British Literature 1660-1945
ENSH251.subject: ENSH
ENSH251.description: A survey of selected literary works in Britain from the Restoration to the end of World War II, in some combination of poetry, prose and drama. May be organized around some prominent themes.
ENSH251.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 251, ENGL 151, ENGL 200, ENGL 200B, ENGL 200C (if taken prior to September 2009).

ENSH252.title: World Literatures
ENSH252.subject: ENSH
ENSH252.description: A survey of literatures in English from Southeast Asia, the Caribbean, Africa and Australasia, among other places, in some combination of poetry, prose and drama; may include comparative analysis of non-Anglophone texts in translation.
ENSH252.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 252, ENGL 263.

ENSH253.title: Canadian Literature
ENSH253.subject: ENSH
ENSH253.description: A survey of Canadian literature in some combination of poetry, prose and drama.
ENSH253.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 253, ENGL 202.

ENSH254.title: American Literature
ENSH254.subject: ENSH
ENSH254.description: A survey of American literature in some combination of poetry, prose and drama.
ENSH254.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 254, ENGL 203.

ENSH300.title: Practical Criticism (Majors)
ENSH300.subject: ENSH
ENSH300.description: Advanced instruction in writing literary criticism focused on developing close reading skills, selecting textual evidence and contextual information, learning and applying a literary-critical vocabulary and enhancing research skills.

ENSH301.title: Practical Criticism (Honours)
ENSH301.subject: ENSH
ENSH301.description: Two-semester seminar designed to extend awareness of how style and form contribute to meaning in literary works; poetic, narrative and dramatic technique; representative theoretical approaches and their application; the interdependency of literary technique and critical interpretation. Required for prospective Honours students, who register for ENSH 301 in their second or third year with the approval of the Honours Adviser.
ENSH301.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 301, ENGL 310, ENGL 345.

ENSH302.title: Copy Editing
ENSH302.subject: ENSH
ENSH302.description: Introduction to the principal tasks of copy editing non-fiction print and electronic manuscripts to ensure they are correct, consistent, coherent and concise. Topics include the copyeditor's role, spelling, punctuation, editorial style features, usage and writing style. Practice in the skills of the professional copy editor, including using manual editing marks, copy editing manuscripts drawn from a variety of non-fiction sources and preparing an editorial style sheet.
ENSH302.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 302, ENGL 303, ENGL 216 (if taken in Sep 2000 - Apr 2001).
  • May not be counted toward upper-level requirements in Honours, Major, General or Minor Literature Programs in English.

ENSH303.title: Writing for Business and the Private Sector
ENSH303.subject: ENSH
ENSH303.description: Essential skills of modern technical and business writing, particularly usability, style and structure. Technology as part of the research, writing, revision and presentation processes. Proposals, reports, descriptions, writing for general audiences.
ENSH303.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 303, ENGL 301.
  • May not be counted toward upper-level requirements in Honours, Major, General or Minor Literature Programs in English.

ENSH304.title: Writing for Government and the Public Sector
ENSH304.subject: ENSH
ENSH304.description: Introduction to the essential skills of writing effectively for government and public sector organizations. Develops skills in focusing on a purpose, writing for different audiences, structuring information effectively and writing clear, concise and correct English. Taught in a computer lab and features extensive practice in writing briefing notes, memos, correspondence and reports.
ENSH304.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 304, ADMN 316, ENGL 302.
  • May not be counted toward upper-level requirements in Honours, Major, General or Minor Literature Programs in English.

ENSH305.title: Visual Rhetoric for Professional Writers
ENSH305.subject: ENSH
ENSH305.description: Introduction to visual rhetoric as applied to the design of documents. Covers the fundamental concepts and practices of visual design in professional communications for both digital and print media. Using MS-Word and Adobe Creative Suite, students experiment with text styles and document structure, HTML and CSS, typography, composition, colour and digital image editing in support of effective communication.
ENSH305.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 305, ENGL 305.
  • May not be counted toward upper-level requirements in Honours, Major, General or Minor Literature Programs in English.

ENSH306.title: Communicating for the Environment
ENSH306.subject: ENSH
ENSH306.description: Focuses on the use of professional communication tools and tactics to impart scientific information on environmental issues, provide effective crisis communication and advocate for sustainable and environmental initiatives to diverse stakeholders and communities. Considers the ethics of communicating for the environment, in terms of incorporating multicultural frameworks, formulating corporate social responsibility plans and promoting sustainable practices or ethical products.

ENSH308.title: Speech Communication for Public and Private Sectors
ENSH308.subject: ENSH
ENSH308.description: Prepares future communication professionals for effective speech communication in the public and private sectors. Applies speech communication theories and best practices to professional scenarios.How to structure speeches to inform or persuade audiences and deliver confident, polished and effective presentations with the use of slide decks and other audiovisual aids, in both in-person and remote professional communications contexts.

ENSH309.title: Fashion Communication
ENSH309.subject: ENSH
ENSH309.description: Communication practices in the fashion industry, including media and public relations, marketing and promotions, and retail and e-commerce. Traces fashion communication across print and digital environments, drawing from theories of communication, media representation and cultural studies.. Prepares students to address issues in local and global fashion industries and cultures such as sustainable production, ethical consumption, decolonization, and the inclusion of diverse identities, abilities and sizes.

ENSH310.title: Speculative Fiction
ENSH310.subject: ENSH
ENSH310.description: Study of fiction that imagines alternate histories, futures or worlds (such as science fiction, fantasy, utopian, dystopian, and post-apocalyptic).
ENSH310.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 310, ENGL 395 (if taken in the same topic).

ENSH311.title: Crime and Detective Fiction
ENSH311.subject: ENSH
ENSH311.description: Study of crime fiction and detective fiction. May include short stories, novels, film or other genres.

ENSH312.title: Horror
ENSH312.subject: ENSH
ENSH312.description: Study of horror, textual and visual; the evolution of horror tropes and their adaptation to anxieties about social change, shifting ideas of race and gender, technological advancement and political impotence; horror as cultural commentary. May include short stories, novels, film or other genres.
ENSH312.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 312, ENGL 330 (if taken in the same topic).

ENSH313.title: Children's Literature
ENSH313.subject: ENSH
ENSH313.description: Study of literature written for child readers (and adults who read literature to children).
ENSH313.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 313, ENGL 385 (if taken in Sep 2011 - Apr 2014), ENGL 402, ENGL 479.

ENSH314.title: Young Adult Fiction
ENSH314.subject: ENSH
ENSH314.description: Study of fiction created for young adult readers.
ENSH314.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of ENSH 314, ENGL 230 (if taken 202001).

ENSH315.title: Coming of Age Novels
ENSH315.subject: ENSH
ENSH315.description: Study of novels depicting the shift from childhood to adulthood.

ENSH316.title: Creative Non-Fiction
ENSH316.subject: ENSH
ENSH316.description: Study of literary non-fiction (such as essays, biography, life writing, investigative journalism and memoirs).

ENSH320.title: Special Topics in Narrative and Film
ENSH320.subject: ENSH
ENSH320.description: Study of how a select number of films tell stories. Topic is announced each year.
ENSH320.notes: • May be taken more than once for credit in different topics.

ENSH321.title: Special Topics in Authors on Screen
ENSH321.subject: ENSH
ENSH321.description: Study of screen adaptations of a particular author’s or set of authors’ works. Topic is announced each year.
ENSH321.notes: • May be taken more than once for credit in different topics.

ENSH322.title: Shakespeare on Screen
ENSH322.subject: ENSH
ENSH322.description: Study of Shakespeare’s texts adapted for film and television.
ENSH322.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of ENSH 322, ENGL 360 (if taken 201909, 202101, 202201).

ENSH323.title: Special Topics in Media and Popular Culture
ENSH323.subject: ENSH
ENSH323.description: Study of popular media and culture. May include novels, television, film, radio, music, magazines, games, comics, criticism, adaptations and more; may focus on one or more historical moments. Topic is announced each year.
ENSH323.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 323, ENGL 381 (if taken in the same topic).

ENSH324.title: Comics and Graphic Novels
ENSH324.subject: ENSH
ENSH324.description: Study of literature that combines text and image, from comics to graphic novels.
ENSH324.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 324, ENGL 330 (if taken Sept-Dec 2020).

ENSH325.title: Games and Interactive Fiction
ENSH325.subject: ENSH
ENSH325.description: Study of games and interaction in the context of fiction. Topics may include play and affect, branching narratives, worldbuilding, fandom, predictability and uncertainty and values in design.
ENSH325.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of ENSH 325 and ENGL 230 (if taken Jan-Apr 2023).

ENSH330.title: Literature and the Bible
ENSH330.subject: ENSH
ENSH330.description: Examines the relationship between the Bible and literature in English, and especially intertextual relationships between biblical and literary texts. Topics include the history of biblical translation, the Bible and popular culture, the combination of biblical and classical mythologies in the creation of Western cultural ideals, the impact of biblical interpretation on literary theory.
ENSH330.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 330, ENGL 365 (if taken prior to September 1983), ENGL 409, ENGL 464, RCS 464, RS 464.

ENSH331.title: Epic Imagination
ENSH331.subject: ENSH
ENSH331.description: Study of epic in English or within Anglophone traditions of Britain and Ireland across multiple genres and literary periods.

ENSH332.title: Special Topics in Literature, Home and Away
ENSH332.subject: ENSH
ENSH332.description: Study of literary representations of home and away, including such issues as migration, belonging and place. Topic is announced each year.
ENSH332.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 332, ENGL 395 (if taken in the same topic), ENGL 433A (if taken in the same topic).

ENSH333.title: Trans-Atlantic Literature
ENSH333.subject: ENSH
ENSH333.description: A comparative study of literatures from both sides of the Atlantic, for example British, Canadian, American, Caribbean. May be organized around a specific theme, topic or cluster of authors.

ENSH334.title: Special Topics in Literature and Love
ENSH334.subject: ENSH
ENSH334.description: Study of literary representations of love—idealized, erotic and sexual, or socially transgressive—in poetry, fiction, drama or nonfiction prose. Topic is announced each year.
ENSH334.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of ENSH 334, ENGL 391 (if taken 202101, 202201).

ENSH335.title: Special Topics in Literature and Social Justice
ENSH335.subject: ENSH
ENSH335.description: Study of literature’s representation of and/or engagement with social justice issues (such as legal and political oppression, environmental destruction, activism, race relations and gender relations). Topic is announced each year.
ENSH335.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 335, ENGL 425 (if taken in the same topic), ENGL 475 (if taken in the same topic).

ENSH340.title: Special Topics in a Major Author
ENSH340.subject: ENSH
ENSH340.description: In-depth study of the works of a single major author.
ENSH340.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 340, ENGL 344A (if taken in the same topic), ENGL 392 (if taken in the same topic), GMST 480 (if taken in the same topic), SLST 480 (if taken in the same topic), SLST 481(if taken in the same topic).
  • Topic is announced each year.

ENSH341.title: Special Topics in Theories and Methods
ENSH341.subject: ENSH
ENSH341.description: Study of specific critical theories, methods and methodologies for literary studies. Topic is announced each year.
ENSH341.notes:
• Topic is announced each year.
  • Credit granted for only one of ENSH 341, ENGL 462 (if taken in the same topic).

ENSH342.title: Special Topics in a Genre, Movement or Theme
ENSH342.subject: ENSH
ENSH342.description: Study of a specific genre (such as the novel, drama, poetry) or subgenre (such as illustrated fiction, periodical poetry, erotic literature), movement or theme. Topic is announced each year.
ENSH342.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 342, ENGL 362 (if taken in the same topic), ENGL 391 (if taken in the same topic), GMST 462 (if taken in the same topic).

ENSH346.title: Old English Language and Literature
ENSH346.subject: ENSH
ENSH346.description: Introduction to the English language, its literature (including Beowulf) and its cultural contexts to about 1100. May be organized around a specific theme, topic or cluster of authors.
ENSH346.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 346, ENGL 340, ENGL 341, ENGL 441, ENGL 442.

ENSH347.title: Major Figures or Movements in Medieval Literature
ENSH347.subject: ENSH
ENSH347.description: Study of the literatures, languages, and cultures of medieval Britain, normally with a focus on Middle English, from the 11th through 15th centuries, covering some combination of poetry, prose and/or drama, organized around one or more major figures or movements (e.g, Chaucer; dream visions).
ENSH347.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 347, ENGL 342 (if taken if the same topic) ENGL 344A (if taken if the same topic), ENGL 344B(if taken if the same topic).

ENSH348.title: Themes in Medieval Literature
ENSH348.subject: ENSH
ENSH348.description: Study of the literatures, languages, and cultures of medieval Britain, through to 15th century, covering some combination of poetry, prose and/or drama, organized around a specific theme or topic; materials may be taught in translation.

ENSH351.title: Renaissance Literature
ENSH351.subject: ENSH
ENSH351.description: A study of 16th- and early 17th-century British literature with an emphasis on poetry and prose. May be organized around a specific theme, topic, or cluster of authors.
ENSH351.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 351, ENGL 361, ENGL 365, RCS 365, RS 365.

ENSH352.title: Renaissance Drama
ENSH352.subject: ENSH
ENSH352.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 352, ENGL 364.

ENSH353.title: Shakespeare's Histories and Tragedies
ENSH353.subject: ENSH
ENSH353.description: A study of selected history plays and tragedies.
ENSH353.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 353, ENGL 366, ENGL 366A, ENGL 366B, ENGL 366D.

ENSH354.title: Shakespeare's Comedies and Romances
ENSH354.subject: ENSH
ENSH354.description: A study of selected comedies and late romances.
ENSH354.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 354, ENGL 366, ENGL 366A, ENGL 366C, ENGL 366E.

ENSH355.title: Milton
ENSH355.subject: ENSH
ENSH355.description: A study of Paradise Lost, as well as other major poems and selected prose.
ENSH355.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 355, ENGL 369, RCS 369, RS 369.

crossListed.title: Milton’s Major Poetry and Selected Prose

ENSH359.title: British Literature 1660-1750
ENSH359.subject: ENSH
ENSH359.description: A study of Restoration and early 18th-century literature, including poetry, prose and drama. May be organized around a specific theme, topic or cluster of authors.
ENSH359.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 359, ENGL 373, ENGL 374.

ENSH360.title: British Literature 1750-1800
ENSH360.subject: ENSH
ENSH360.description: A study of the literature of the later 18th century, including poetry, prose and drama. May be organized around a specific theme, topic or cluster of authors.
ENSH360.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 360, ENGL 375.

ENSH364.title: 19th-Century British Fiction
ENSH364.subject: ENSH
ENSH364.description: A study of Romantic and/or Victorian period fiction. May include the novel, the novella and short stories.
ENSH364.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 364, ENGL 379, ENGL 380, ENGL 384.

ENSH365.title: Romantic Period Poetry
ENSH365.subject: ENSH
ENSH365.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 365, ENGL 382, ENGL 383, ENGL 430.

ENSH366.title: Victorian Period Poetry
ENSH366.subject: ENSH
ENSH366.description: Victorian poetry examined in relation to 19th-century theories of aesthetics and poetics, with emphasis on topics such as historiography, medievalism, imperialism, orientalism, decadence, construction of gender, the relations between the sexes, the rise of science and the decline of faith.
ENSH366.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 366, ENGL 386.

ENSH369.title: 20th-Century Poetry in Britain and or Ireland
ENSH369.subject: ENSH
ENSH369.description: A study of modern British or Irish poetry (or some combination). May be organized around a specific theme, topic, or cluster of authors.
ENSH369.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 369, ENGL 433, ENGL 433A, ENGL 434, ENGL 434A.

ENSH370.title: 20th-Century Drama in Britain and or Ireland
ENSH370.subject: ENSH
ENSH370.description: A study of modern British or Irish drama (or some combination). May be organized around a specific theme, topic, or cluster of authors.

ENSH371.title: 20th-Century Fiction in Britain and or Ireland
ENSH371.subject: ENSH
ENSH371.description: A study of modern British or Irish fiction (or some combination). May be organized around a specific theme, topic or cluster of authors.
ENSH371.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 371, ENGL 433, ENGL 433A, ENGL 436, ENGL 436A.

ENSH372.title: Contemporary Literature in Britain and or Ireland
ENSH372.subject: ENSH
ENSH372.description: A study of British or Irish literature (or some combination) from the late 20th century up to the present focused on either poetry, fiction, or drama or some combination of genres. May be organized around a specific theme, topic or cluster of authors.
ENSH372.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 372, ENGL 433, ENGL 433B, ENGL 436, ENGL 436B.

ENSH376.title: Literature in Canada to 1900
ENSH376.subject: ENSH
ENSH376.description: A study of pre-20th century Canadian literature in some combination of poetry, prose and drama. May be organized around a specific theme, topic or cluster of authors.
ENSH376.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 376, ENGL 459.

ENSH377.title: 20th-Century Literature in Canada
ENSH377.subject: ENSH
ENSH377.description: A study of modern Canadian literature focused on either poetry, fiction, or drama or some combination of genres. May be organized around a specific theme, topic or cluster of authors.
ENSH377.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 377, ENGL 397, ENGL 450, ENGL 452.

ENSH378.title: Contemporary Literature in Canada
ENSH378.subject: ENSH
ENSH378.description: A study of Canadian literature from the late 20th century up to the present focused on either poetry, fiction, or drama or some combination of genres. May be organized around a specific theme, topic, or cluster of authors.
ENSH378.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 378, ENGL 397, ENGL 451, ENGL 453.

ENSH379.title: Critiquing Settler-Colonialism in Canadian Literature
ENSH379.subject: ENSH
ENSH379.description: A critical study of literature by settler writers.

ENSH380.title: Margaret Atwood
ENSH380.subject: ENSH
ENSH380.description: A study of major novels and other selected writings.
ENSH380.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 380, ENGL 448 (if taken 201809).

ENSH383.title: Poetry in the United States
ENSH383.subject: ENSH
ENSH383.description: A study of American poetry, primarily focused on the 20th century. May be organized around a specific theme, topic, or cluster of authors.
ENSH383.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 383, ENGL 431, ENGL 431A, ENGL 431B, ENGL 432, ENGL 432A, ENGL 432B.

ENSH384.title: Literature in the United States to 1900
ENSH384.subject: ENSH
ENSH384.description: A study of pre-20th century American literature in some combination of poetry, prose, and drama. May be organized around a specific theme, topic, or cluster of authors.
ENSH384.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 384, ENGL 427, ENGL 428, ENGL 428A, ENGL 428B.

ENSH385.title: Fiction in the United States 1900-1970
ENSH385.subject: ENSH
ENSH385.description: A study of modern American fiction. May be organized around a specific theme, topic or cluster of authors.
ENSH385.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 385, ENGL 429, ENGL 429A, ENGL 429B.

ENSH386.title: Fiction in the United States 1970-present
ENSH386.subject: ENSH
ENSH386.description: A study of contemporary American fiction from the late 20th century up to the present. May be organized around a specific theme, topic or cluster of authors.
ENSH386.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 386, ENGL 429, ENGL 429B, ENGL 429C.

ENSH390.title: Comparative World Literatures after 1900
ENSH390.subject: ENSH
ENSH390.description: Study of literatures in English after 1900 from Southeast Asia, the Caribbean, Africa, and Australasia, among other places. May address a theme, topic, or cluster of authors; may include comparative analysis of non-Anglophone texts in translation.
ENSH390.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 390, ENGL 439, ENGL 439B (if taken in the same topic).
  • Topic is announced each year.

ENSH395.title: Topics in Indigenous Literatures after 1900
ENSH395.subject: ENSH
ENSH395.description: A study of Indigenous literatures after 1900; may be organized around particular themes, genres or authors.
ENSH395.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 395, ENGL 477 (if taken in the same topic).
  • Topic is announced each year.

ENSH400.title: Technical Communication
ENSH400.subject: ENSH
ENSH400.description: Communicating scientific and technical information to subject matter experts, managers, technicians and non-specialists using print and digital media. Technical reports, manuals, user guides.
ENSH400.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 400, ENGL 306, ENGL 406 (if taken in the same topic).
  • May not be counted toward upper-level requirements in Honours, Major, General or Minor Literature Programs in English.

ENSH401.title: Web Design
ENSH401.subject: ENSH
ENSH401.description: Introduction to technologies and writing skills required to produce websites in HTML5, CSS3 and WordPress. Cross-platform tools, terms, processes and standards. Emphasis on open-source tools and best practices for design and implementation.
ENSH401.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 401, ENGL 401.
  • May not be counted toward upper-level requirements in Honours, Major, General or Minor Literature Programs in English.

ENSH402.title: Topics in Professional Communication
ENSH402.subject: ENSH
ENSH402.description: A study of special topics in Professional Communication.
ENSH402.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 402, ENGL 406.
  • May not be counted toward upper-level requirements in Honours, Major, General or Minor Literature Programs in English.

ENSH403.title: Digital Communication and Social Media
ENSH403.subject: ENSH
ENSH403.description: Cultural, social and economic processes underlying digital media, particularly social media. Skills may be developed in, but are not limited to, collaborative and document authoring applications, podcasting, digital writing, digital video production and blogging, which may be applied via community-engaged learning.
ENSH403.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 403, ENGL 406 (if taken in the same topic), ENGL 407.
  • May not be counted toward upper-level requirements in Honours, Major, General or Minor Literature Programs in English.

ENSH404.title: Research for Professional Writers
ENSH404.subject: ENSH
ENSH404.description: An introduction to the research skills, tasks and tools of professional writers. Practice in developing research questions and identifying and evaluating information sources; using search engines, databases, indexes and other electronic sources to gather information; developing research proposals; creating electronic research notebooks and annotated bibliographies; interpreting and reporting data.
ENSH404.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 404, ENGL 412.
  • May not be counted toward upper-level requirements in Honours, Major, General or Minor Literature Programs in English.

ENSH405.title: Print Media Genres and Techniques for Professional Communication
ENSH405.subject: ENSH
ENSH405.description: Introduction to print-based genres associated with professional writing, including media kits, news releases, bios, speeches, op-ed writing and organizational newsletters.
ENSH405.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 405, ENGL 406 (if taken in the same topic), ENGL 418.
  • May not be counted toward upper-level requirements in Honours, Major, General or Minor Literature Programs in English.

ENSH406.title: Strategic Communication in Arts, Culture and Tourism Sectors
ENSH406.subject: ENSH
ENSH406.description: Principles of intentional and ethical strategic communication and their practical application to the arts, cultural and tourism sectors. Topics may include: developing organizational mandates; maintaining effective internal communications; undertaking media, public and member relations; advocating to public officials; liaising with sponsors and funding bodies; and creating impactful promotional content across platforms.

ENSH480.title: Advanced Theories and Methods
ENSH480.subject: ENSH
ENSH480.description: A capstone course offering intensive training in various methods of interpretation and theoretical approaches to literature, culture and media. May include experiential learning in Special Collections or a computer lab.
ENSH480.notes:
• Limited to Majors and Honours students except by permission of the instructor.
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

ENSH481.title: Advanced Special Topics Seminar
ENSH481.subject: ENSH
ENSH481.description: A capstone course on advanced variable topics in a focused area of literary or cultural analysis (could focus on a specific author).
ENSH481.notes:
• May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class limited to Majors and Honours students except by permission of the instructor.
  • Credit granted for only one of ENSH 481, ENGL 480 (if taken in the same topic).

ENSH482.title: Community-Engaged Learning and Public Humanities
ENSH482.subject: ENSH
ENSH482.description: A capstone course organized around opportunities for community engagement and experiential learning in an applied situation with an emphasis on public-facing literary or cultural writing in various digital and/or print media; students apply their research and writing skills in a community setting. Possible engagements include working with local literacy initiatives, independent theatre or social justice organizations.
ENSH482.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 482, ENGL 448 (if taken Jan-Apr 2020).
  • Limited to Majors and Honours students except by permission of the instructor.
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

ENSH483.title: In the Archives
ENSH483.subject: ENSH
ENSH483.description: A hands-on variable-content course conducted largely in Special Collections.
ENSH483.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 483, ENGL 353 (if taken in Jan-Apr 2015, Sep-Dec 2015, or Sep-Dec 2016), ENGL 481 (if taken in the same topic), MEDI 451 (if taken in the same topic).
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class; limited to Majors and Honours students

ENSH484.title: Field School in Literary and Cultural Studies
ENSH484.subject: ENSH
ENSH484.description: Connects the study of literature, culture or media to a particular place.
ENSH484.notes:
• Limited to Majors and Honours students except by permission of the instructor.
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

ENSH490.title: Directed Reading
ENSH490.subject: ENSH
ENSH490.description: A specified reading project for Honours students determined by the student and the instructor; written assignments are required.
ENSH490.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 490, ENGL 490.

ENSH492.title: Directed Reading in Advanced Topics in Professional Communication
ENSH492.subject: ENSH
ENSH492.description: A specific writing project in some area of Professional Communication to be determined by the student and the instructor. Students must have the approval of the instructor, the Director of the Professional Communication Program and the department Chair.
ENSH492.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 492, ENGL 492.
  • May not be counted toward upper-level requirements in Honours, Major, General or Minor Literature Programs in English.

ENSH493.title: Directed Reading in Advanced Topics in Literary Study
ENSH493.subject: ENSH
ENSH493.description: Supervised study in some area of English literature; written assignments required.
ENSH493.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 493, ENGL 493.

ENSH499.title: Honours Graduating Essay
ENSH499.subject: ENSH
ENSH499.description: Graduating essay written under the guidance of an individual instructor, usually in the Honours student’s final year.
ENSH499.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of ENSH 499, ENGL 499.

ENT100.title: Introduction to Entrepreneurship
ENT100.subject: ENT
ENT100.description: Introduces and applies fundamental knowledge of the phenomenon of innovation in for-profit, social, government, and other contexts; provides tools to aid in the recognition of innovation opportunities; introduces use of creativity techniques, design thinking, and other tools and perspectives to generate effective solutions to complex problems; provides change management tools and perspectives aimed at the successful adoption/acceptance of innovation.

ENT400.title: Strategic Management for the Entrepreneurship Specialist
ENT400.subject: ENT
ENT400.description: Examines entrepreneurial strategies related to new ventures and focuses on the strategic decisions and processes around bringing new products and services to the market. Using cases and key readings students learn how to apply to their own venture idea organizational strategy and strategic management including the process of choosing and defining goals, formulating and implementing strategies and monitoring strategic performance.
ENT400.notes: • Students specializing only in Entrepreneurship use ENT 400 in lieu of COM 400 toward graduation.

ENT402.title: Entrepreneurship and Small Business for the Non-Specialist
ENT402.subject: ENT
ENT402.description: Using lean start-up methods as the foundation, aspects of new venture development are explored and practiced – opportunity recognition and quantification, customer development research, minimum viable product (MVP) design and testing, business model design, new venture marketing strategies, financing and funding, and intellectual property protection. Students select a business idea and work independently and with their team to examine and test the idea’s feasibility, culminating in development and presentation of a sound business model and launch plan.
ENT402.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of ENT 402, ENT 302, MECH 462.
  • Enrolment limited to students outside the Entrepreneurship area of specialization.

ENT410.title: Venture Marketing Expertise (Promise Skills)
ENT410.subject: ENT
ENT410.description: As part of the integrated Entrepreneurship Core, this course material is designed to help students develop the conceptual tools and techniques needed for market scanning, opportunity recognition, product development, market acceptance and the establishment and maintenance of venture stakeholder relationships. This element of the Entrepreneurship area of specialization helps students develop skills in identifying and building the market relationships upon which successful entrepreneurship is based.

ENT411.title: Venture Planning/Finance Expertise (Planning Skills)
ENT411.subject: ENT
ENT411.description: As part of the integrated Entrepreneurship Core, this course material is designed to help students develop the conceptual tools and techniques necessary to identify critical venture attributes and processes, and the consequent financial outcomes of venture creation decisions. This element of the Entrepreneurship area of specialization helps students develop skills in recognizing the decision points and enacting the choice patterns that lead to relevant venture outcomes.

ENT412.title: Acquiring Expert Venture Cognitions
ENT412.subject: ENT
ENT412.description: As part of the integrated Entrepreneurship Core, this course is designed to provide an overarching conceptual framework within which to integrate the other course materials that students encounter within the Entrepreneurship specialization. Students examine the process and content (sequence and norms) of New Venture Expert Scripts, creating their own master and sub-scripts that enable them to become independent economic actors. Students create individual verbal and written searching, screening, planning, financing, start-up and harvesting scripts.

ENT413.title: Portfolio Practicum
ENT413.subject: ENT
ENT413.description: As part of the integrated Entrepreneurship Core, this course helps students to further integrate into practice the concepts experienced within the Entrepreneurship specialization. Students participate in industry tours, networking sessions, start-up experiences, visits from guest speakers, case studies and industry immersions. From these experiences, students create a portfolio that demonstrates to instructors, investors and other stakeholders their mastery of new venture skills and abilities, and the practical integration of knowledge sets acquired in the Entrepreneurship Specialization.

EOS110.title: Oceans and Atmosphere
EOS110.subject: EOS
EOS110.description: Origin and structure of the oceans and atmosphere. Dynamic processes that drive ocean and atmosphere circulation, weather patterns and global climate change. The coastal ocean, marine ecosystems, nutrient and carbon cycles, human influences on ocean environments, marine resources and sustainability.
EOS110.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of EOS 110, GEOG 110, GEOG 203B, GEOG 213, GEOG 216, EOS 350 (if taken prior to May 2011).
  • Credit will be granted for only two of the following courses with no more than one course from a particular group. Group 1: EOS 100, EOS 101; Group 2: EOS 110, GEOG 110, GEOG 216; Group 3: EOS 120, GEOG 120, GEOG 217.

EOS120.title: The Dynamic Earth
EOS120.subject: EOS
EOS120.description: Internal and external processes that shape the Earth and its landscapes. Nature of tectonic forces, earthquakes, volcanoes, rocks and minerals, and mountain building. Processes of erosion, sediment transport and deposition and glaciation. Global water cycle and hydrological processes. Geologic record of past environmental change and its impact on life. Natural resources, natural hazards and sustainability.
EOS120.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of EOS 120, GEOG 120, GEOG 203A, GEOG 213, GEOG 217.
  • Credit will be granted for only two of the following courses with no more than one course from a particular group. Group 1: EOS 100, EOS 101; Group 2: EOS 110, GEOG 110, GEOG 216; Group 3: EOS 120, GEOG 120, GEOG 217.

EOS130.title: Climate Change
EOS130.subject: EOS
EOS130.description: An introduction to the fundamental physical principles governing the climate of the Earth system, and its response to anthropogenic factors. Topics include: components of the climate system, radiative energy balance, forcings and feedbacks, the carbon cycle, climate of the past, impacts of climate change, global climate model projections, and approaches to mitigation and adaptation.
EOS130.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EOS 130, GEOG 130.

EOS170.title: Natural Hazards
EOS170.subject: EOS
EOS170.description: An overview of natural hazards including earthquakes, volcanoes, tsunami, landslides, flooding, extreme weather, wildfires and space hazards. Particular attention is given to hazards affecting southwestern British Columbia, hazards related to climate change, and important historic natural disasters. This is an introductory-level course that does not require a science/math background.
EOS170.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EOS 170, EOS 370.

EOS201.title: Sedimentary Geology
EOS201.subject: EOS
EOS201.description: The physical, chemical and biological nature of sediments at sea and on land. The process of sediment transport, deposition and diagenesis. The origin and internal stratigraphy of sedimentary basins in the context of plate tectonics. The sedimentary record as used to reconstruct past climates, geographies, and earth and ocean dynamics. The geological evolution of western Canada as deduced from its stratigraphic record.

EOS202.title: Structural Geology
EOS202.subject: EOS
EOS202.description: Geometric, kinematic and dynamic analysis of deformation structures in rock bodies at different scales, in both brittle and ductile regimes. Stress and strain in rocks and their relationship to geologic structures. Interpretation of the physical mechanisms of folding and faulting in rocks with structural data and geological maps. The origin of crustal deformation in the context of plate tectonics.

EOS205.title: Mineralogy
EOS205.subject: EOS
EOS205.description: Introduction to the fundamental principles and concepts of mineralogy and optical mineralogy. A practical and systematic treatment of the common rock-forming minerals and mineral groups. Emphasis is placed on understanding the behaviour of minerals in relation to changing physical and chemical conditions in igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary environments.

EOS210.title: Introductory Geophysics
EOS210.subject: EOS
EOS210.description: An introduction to seismology, gravity, geomagnetism, paleomagnetism and heat flow, and how they contribute to our understanding of whole Earth structure and plate tectonics.
EOS210.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EOS 210, PHYS 210.

EOS220.title: Weather and Climate
EOS220.subject: EOS
EOS220.description: An introduction to the physical processes that determine Earth’s weather and climate. Topics include: atmospheric composition, flows of energy through the atmosphere, small-scale and large-scale winds, cloud and precipitation processes, climate change.
EOS220.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EOS 220, GEOG 220.

EOS230.title: Introduction to Environmental Data Analysis
EOS230.subject: EOS
EOS230.description: An introduction to using computer programming to analyze climate data. Topics include; fundamentals of programming, data visualization, analysis of spatial data, descriptive statistics, linear regression.
EOS230.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EOS 230, GEOG 230.

EOS240.title: Geochemistry
EOS240.subject: EOS
EOS240.description: Thermodynamic and kinetic approaches to understanding the Earth system. Application of theory to practical questions such as mineral formation, weathering, water quality, and petroleum formation. Thermodynamic and kinetic approaches are applied to the general geochemistry of the oceans, atmosphere and solid earth.
EOS240.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EOS 240, EOS 360 (if taken prior to September 1992).

EOS261.title: The Climate System
EOS261.subject: EOS
EOS261.description: Introduces the processes and mechanisms through which the atmosphere, ocean, earth, and biosphere interact to control Earth’s climate. Examines interactions via the carbon cycle and climate feedbacks, giving rise to stability, gradual evolution, and rapid change in the climate system. Develops understanding of the dynamics of the climate system by examining records of past climates and climate models. Applies this understanding to anthropogenic climate change.
EOS261.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of EOS 261, EOS 260.

EOS300.title: Earth Science Field School
EOS300.subject: EOS
EOS300.description: An up to two-week field course in and around southern Vancouver Island during which students are introduced to geological fieldwork (mapping, traversing, drawing sedimentary logs, sampling, recording field notes) and the regional geology and tectonics of Vancouver Island. Normally held in late April - early May after examinations for Year 2.
