A student field research project is required.
MRNE412.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MRNE 412, BIOL 431, BIOL 431A (if taken prior to May 2011).
  • This is a field course offered at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre for upper level Biology credit. Please visit the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre website for more information.

MRNE414.title: Coastal Biodiversity and Conservation
MRNE414.subject: MRNE
MRNE414.description: Current topics, concepts and practice in coastal conservation biology, with a focus on biodiversity within marine, intertidal and terrestrial ecosystems. In addition to course lectures and paper discussions, the course places an emphasis on student-led studies of the natural world. Independent student research projects include biodiversity surveys, assessments of anthropogenic impacts, and studies of coastal species, including a diversity of mammal, bird, invertebrate, and plant taxa.
MRNE414.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MRNE 414, MRNE 401 (if taken in the same topic).
  • This is a field course offered at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre for upper level Biology credit. Please visit the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre website for more information.

MRNE415.title: Structure and Function in Animals
MRNE415.subject: MRNE
MRNE415.description: Structure of marine animals, and their adaptations to the marine environment. Neurobiology, developmental biology, functional morphology and other topics.
MRNE415.notes: • This is a field course offered at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre for upper level Biology credit. Please visit the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre website for more information.

MRNE416.title: Coastal Community Ecology
MRNE416.subject: MRNE
MRNE416.description: Key ideas and concepts on how ecological and evolutionary forces shape natural communities. Using a hands-on approach, students explore key topics in community ecology including island biogeography, community succession, dispersal, marine terrestrial interactions, niche theory, climate change, and techniques to measure species diversity.
MRNE416.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MRNE 416, MRNE 401 (if taken in the same topic), MRNE 402 (if taken in the same topic).

MRNE417.title: Crustacean Biology
MRNE417.subject: MRNE
MRNE417.description: The taxonomic diversity, ecology and morphological, behavioural and life-history adaptations of Crustaceans. Laboratory and field activities include Crustacean collection, identification and the terminology used in identification keys. A student field research project is required.
MRNE417.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MRNE 417, MRNE 401 (if taken in the same topic).
  • This is a field course offered at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre for upper level Biology credit. Please visit the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre website for more information.

MRNE418.title: Marine Behavioural Ecology
MRNE418.subject: MRNE
MRNE418.description: The diversity of behaviours exhibited by intertidal animals. Key concepts and principles of behavioural ecology based on observations in the field. Students carry out an extensive, multi-component, group-oriented research project with a focus on marine invertebrates.
MRNE418.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MRNE 418, MRNE 401 (if taken in the same topic), MRNE 402 (if taken in the same topic).

MRNE419.title: Subtidal Science
MRNE419.subject: MRNE
MRNE419.description: An introduction to the techniques and practical aspects of performing research underwater using SCUBA. The intensive practical component introduces a diversity of sub-tidal research techniques. Students learn to manage the logistical challenges associated with a subtidal research project. Lectures provide theoretical background for the field techniques, including designing effective surveys, dealing with logistics and safety and analyzing data.
MRNE419.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MRNE 419, MRNE 401 (if taken in the same topic).
  • This is a field course offered at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre for upper level Biology credit. Please visit the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre website for more information. Permission from the department will be granted only if scuba diving qualifications are met prior to course registration.

MRNE420.title: Marine Phycology
MRNE420.subject: MRNE
MRNE420.description: A survey of the marine algae, with emphasis on the benthic forms, in the vicinity of the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. Includes lectures, laboratory periods, field collection, identification and observation. Emphasis is placed on the study of living specimens in the laboratory and in the field.
MRNE420.notes: • This is a field course offered at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre for upper level Biology credit. Please visit the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre website for more information.

MRNE421.title: Terrestrial and Freshwater Conservation
MRNE421.subject: MRNE
MRNE421.description: Modern theory and practice in conservation ecology as applied to terrestrial and freshwater habitats. Emphasis on field experience, supplemented by lectures including global biodiversity, ecosystem services, links between conservation and livelihoods, legislation protecting habitats and species, and local and global solutions. Independent research projects include biodiversity surveys, environmental impact assessments, and restoration techniques.
MRNE421.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MRNE 421, MRNE 401 (if taken in the same topic), MRNE 402 (if taken in the same topic).

MRNE425.title: Ecological Adaptations of Seaweeds
MRNE425.subject: MRNE
MRNE425.description: Morphological, physiological, genetic and reproductive adaptations of seaweeds to their natural and human-altered environments.
MRNE425.notes: • This is a field course offered at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre for upper level Biology credit. Please visit the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre website for more information.

MRNE430.title: Marine Ecology
MRNE430.subject: MRNE
MRNE430.description: An analytical approach to biotic associations in the marine environment. Opportunities are provided for study of the intertidal realm in exposed and protected areas and of beaches and estuaries in the vicinity of the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre; plankton studies and investigations of the subtidal and benthic environments by diving and dredging are envisaged.
MRNE430.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MRNE 430, BIOL 406.
  • This is a field course offered at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre for upper level Biology credit. Please visit the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre website for more information.

MRNE435.title: Introduction to Biological Oceanography
MRNE435.subject: MRNE
MRNE435.description: An introduction to the biology of the oceans, with supporting coverage of relevant physics and chemistry. Emphasis is placed on plankton biology, community structure and life histories and influencing environmental factors. Collections are made from sheltered inlets, through Barkley Sound to offshore waters. Involves both field and laboratory studies of plankton organisms.
MRNE435.notes: • This is a field course offered at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre for upper level Biology credit. Please visit the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre website for more information.

MRNE437.title: Marine Population Ecology and Dynamics
MRNE437.subject: MRNE
MRNE437.description: An analytical approach to the study of marine ecology and marine populations. Intertidal and subtidal communities are examined, with emphasis on the biota of the Barkley Sound region.
MRNE437.notes: • This is a field course offered at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre for upper level Biology credit. Please visit the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre website for more information.

MRNE475.title: Applied Data Analysis in Marine Science
MRNE475.subject: MRNE
MRNE475.description: Principles of study design and data analysis illustrated by lecture material, current research and research seminars. Students acquire experience using the statistical computing language R.
MRNE475.notes: • This is a field course offered at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre for upper level Biology credit. Please visit the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre website for more information.

MUS101A.title: Language of Music
MUS101A.subject: MUS
MUS101A.description: An introduction to tonal music, including two-part species counterpoint and the basics of four-part harmony and voice leading.

MUS101B.title: Language of Music
MUS101B.subject: MUS
MUS101B.description: A continuation of 101A, focusing on four-part harmony and voice leading, and on the analysis of simple tonal compositions.

MUS105.title: Introduction to Composition
MUS105.subject: MUS
MUS105.description: Designed to enhance one's understanding of and development in compositional systems, processes and techniques through written exercises and assignments related to 20th century musical idioms.

MUS108.title: African Hand Drumming
MUS108.subject: MUS
MUS108.description: Hands-on introduction to African drumming and percussion. Instruments include drums, bells, shakers and xylophones. No prior playing experience necessary; all instruments are provided.
MUS108.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 108, MUS 208 (if taken in the same topic).

MUS109.title: Great Film Music
MUS109.subject: MUS
MUS109.description: From Jaws to Jedi; Batman to Bond, Great Film Music examines the role of music in American movies from the 1930s to present day. The course helps students develop an awareness of the impact and intent of music in relation to film. Open to all students.
MUS109.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 109, MUS 391 (if taken in the same topic).

MUS111.title: Rudiments of Music
MUS111.subject: MUS
MUS111.description: An introduction to the rudiments of music, including pitch and rhythmic notation, basic harmonic language, and a study of the elementary principles of melodic writing and harmony.
MUS111.notes:
• Not open to students registered in or with credit in any of MUS 100, MUS 100A, MUS 101A, MUS 101B.
  • No background in music required.

MUS116.title: Music Appreciation
MUS116.subject: MUS
MUS116.description: A historical music survey focused on terminology, composers and styles, and critical listening skills.
MUS116.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 116, MUS 110, MUS 110A, MUS 110B, MUS 115, MUS 120A, MUS 120B.

MUS121.title: Western Music from Antiquity to 1750
MUS121.subject: MUS
MUS121.description: The development of Western music from notated beginnings.
MUS121.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 121, MUS 120A, MUS 120B.

MUS131.title: Introduction to Music Education
MUS131.subject: MUS
MUS131.description: Explores teaching music in a variety of settings. An orientation to the public school profession, community music making and the significance of music education in society.
MUS131.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 131, ME 101.

MUS143.title: Individual Tuition: Secondary area
MUS143.subject: MUS
MUS143.description: Lessons in a secondary instrument, voice, or conducting, in exceptional cases.
MUS143.notes: • Credit will be granted for only four of MUS 143, MUS 141, MUS 141A, MUS 141B, MUS 141C, MUS 141D, MUS 141E, MUS 141F.

MUS170A.title: Basic Musicianship IA
MUS170A.subject: MUS
MUS170A.description: Beginning sightsinging, dictation and corresponding keyboard skills.
MUS170A.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 170A, MUS 170.
  • Normally taken concurrently with MUS 101A.

MUS170B.title: Basic Musicianship IB
MUS170B.subject: MUS
MUS170B.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 170B, MUS 170.
  • Normally taken concurrently with MUS 101B.

MUS180A.title: University Orchestra
MUS180A.subject: MUS
MUS180A.description: Rehearses and performs orchestral repertoire from the Baroque to the present.
MUS180A.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 180A, MUS 180.
  • Open to all students by audition.

MUS180B.title: University Wind Symphony
MUS180B.subject: MUS
MUS180B.description: Rehearses and performs advanced repertoire for winds, brass and percussion.
MUS180B.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 180B, MUS 180.
  • Open to all students by audition.

MUS180C.title: University Concert Band
MUS180C.subject: MUS
MUS180C.description: A non-auditioned campus and community concert band performing a range of music from pop, film, and jazz to classical and contemporary repertoire.
MUS180C.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 180C, MUS 180.
  • Open to all students.

MUS180D.title: Jazz and Creative Music Ensemble
MUS180D.subject: MUS
MUS180D.description: Rehearses and performs music with emphasis on community and collaboration, including jazz, improvisation and soundtracks for silent film.
MUS180D.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 180D, MUS 180.
  • Open to all students by audition.

MUS180E.title: University Chorus
MUS180E.subject: MUS
MUS180E.description: A large mixed choral ensemble that rehearses and performs a varied repertoire and choral/orchestral works.
MUS180E.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 180E, MUS 180.
  • Open to all students.

MUS180F.title: Chamber Singers
MUS180F.subject: MUS
MUS180F.description: An auditioned choral ensemble performing advanced repertoire from a diverse spectrum of composers and styles.
MUS180F.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 180F, MUS 180.
  • Open to all students by audition. Previous choral experience and strong music skills are required.

MUS181.title: Chamber Music
MUS181.subject: MUS
MUS181.description: Ensembles include the standard chamber groups as well as New Music Ensemble (Sonic Lab), Opera Ensemble, Brass Choir, Vocal Jazz and Collaborative Piano.

MUS189.title: Vikes Band
MUS189.subject: MUS
MUS189.description: An ensemble that rehearses and performs at Vikes Varsity events at the Centre for Athletics, Recreation and Special Abilities (CARSA), and select special events on campus.
MUS189.notes:
• Open to all students.
  • Students should have a basic ability to play a band instrument, and must supply their own instrument or rent one.

MUS201A.title: Language of Music
MUS201A.subject: MUS
MUS201A.description: The structural principles, harmonic and contrapuntal practices of tonal music of the late 18th century explored through analysis and composition.

MUS201B.title: Language of Music
MUS201B.subject: MUS
MUS201B.description: A continuation of 201A. The structural principles, harmonic and contrapuntal practices of tonal music of the 19th century explored through analysis and composition.

MUS205.title: Music Composition I
MUS205.subject: MUS
MUS205.description: Individual and class lessons with members of the Music Composition faculty. Compositions for solo and small ensembles. Attendance required at Composition Master Class Seminar.

MUS207.title: Music, Science and Computers
MUS207.subject: MUS
MUS207.description: An investigation into the historical relationships among music, science and technology, leading to current possibilities in computers and music. Focuses on the use of computers in music composition, analysis and synthesis of sound. Open to all students.

MUS208.title: Popular Music and Society I
MUS208.subject: MUS
MUS208.description: Topic varies and may include music for the cinema, folk music, rock music, the blues, or a specific performer or group.
MUS208.notes: • Not open to BMus students and cannot be used as a music elective.

MUS220A.title: Western Music from 1750 to 1885
MUS220A.subject: MUS
MUS220A.description: The development of Western Music and related contexts in history.
MUS220A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 220A, MUS 110, MUS 110B, MUS 313A, MUS 313B.

MUS220B.title: Western Music from 1885 to 1952
MUS220B.subject: MUS
MUS220B.description: The development of Western Music and related contexts in history.
MUS220B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 220B, MUS 110, MUS 110B, MUS 313A, MUS 313B.

MUS231.title: Foundations of Music Education
MUS231.subject: MUS
MUS231.description: A study of the historical, philosophical, sociological, psychological, and curricular foundations of music education.
MUS231.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 231, ME 201.

MUS237.title: Music in the Elementary School Curriculum
MUS237.subject: MUS
MUS237.description: Elementary K-7 school music education methods and materials.
MUS237.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 237, ME 207, ME 403.
  • Includes a field experience in K-7 schools.

MUS239.title: Instrumental/Vocal Jazz Pedagogy
MUS239.subject: MUS
MUS239.description: Instrumental and vocal jazz pedagogy in music education. Emphasis is on practical experience.
MUS239.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 239, ME 120, ME 121, ME 209A, ME 220, ME 221.

MUS240.title: Individual Tuition
MUS240.subject: MUS
MUS240.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 240, MUS 245.

MUS245.title: Seminar in Performance
MUS245.subject: MUS
MUS245.description: Individual tuition and weekly class including discussion of repertoire, pedagogy, and techniques of ensemble performance.
MUS245.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 245, MUS 240.

MUS256A.title: Introduction to Instrumental and Choral Conducting I
MUS256A.subject: MUS

MUS256B.title: Introduction to Instrumental and Choral Conducting II
MUS256B.subject: MUS

MUS270A.title: Basic Musicianship IIA
MUS270A.subject: MUS
MUS270A.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 270A, MUS 270.
  • Normally taken concurrently with MUS 201A.

MUS270B.title: Basic Musicianship IIB
MUS270B.subject: MUS
MUS270B.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 270B, MUS 270.
  • Normally taken concurrently with MUS 201B.

MUS280A.title: University Orchestra
MUS280A.subject: MUS
MUS280A.description: Rehearses and performs orchestral repertoire from the Baroque to the present.
MUS280A.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 280A, MUS 280.
  • Open to all students by audition.

MUS280B.title: University Wind Symphony
MUS280B.subject: MUS
MUS280B.description: Rehearses and performs advanced repertoire for winds, brass and percussion.
MUS280B.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 280B, MUS 280.
  • Open to all students by audition.

MUS280C.title: University Concert Band
MUS280C.subject: MUS
MUS280C.description: A non-auditioned campus and community concert band performing a range of music from pop, film, and jazz to classics and contemporary repertoire.
MUS280C.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 280C, MUS 280.
  • Open to all students.

MUS280D.title: Jazz and Creative Music Ensemble
MUS280D.subject: MUS
MUS280D.description: Rehearses and performs music with an emphasis on community and collaboration, including jazz, improvisation and soundtracks for silent film.
MUS280D.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 280D, MUS 280.
  • Open to all students by audition.

MUS280E.title: University Chorus
MUS280E.subject: MUS
MUS280E.description: A large mixed choral ensemble that rehearses and performs a varied repertoire and choral/orchestral works.
MUS280E.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 280E, MUS 280.
  • Open to all students.

MUS280F.title: Chamber Singers
MUS280F.subject: MUS
MUS280F.description: An auditioned choral ensemble performing advanced repertoire from a diverse spectrum of composers and genres.
MUS280F.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 280F, MUS 280.
  • Open to all students by audition. Previous choral experience and strong music skills are required.

MUS281.title: Chamber Music
MUS281.subject: MUS
MUS281.description: Ensembles include the standard chamber groups as well as New Music Ensemble (Sonic Lab), Opera Ensemble, Brass Choir, Vocal Jazz and Collaborative Piano.

MUS289.title: Vikes Band
MUS289.subject: MUS
MUS289.description: An ensemble that rehearses and performs at Vikes Varsity events at the Centre for Athletics, Recreation and Special Abilities (CARSA), and select special events on campus.
MUS289.notes:
• Open to all students.
  • Students should have a basic ability to play a band instrument, and must supply their own instrument or rent one.

MUS301B.title: Language of Music
MUS301B.subject: MUS
MUS301B.description: A continuation of 301A. History, theory and practice of 20th century music: 1945-present.

MUS305.title: Music Composition II
MUS305.subject: MUS
MUS305.description: Individual and class lessons with members of the Music Composition faculty. Compositions for solo, small and large ensembles.

MUS306.title: Sound Recording Techniques
MUS306.subject: MUS
MUS306.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of sound recording and audio technology, including microphones, mixers and other studio components. Also introduces the use of computers in modern studio recording and processing. Practical work includes recording sessions and work in a studio.

MUS307.title: Introduction to Computer Music
MUS307.subject: MUS
MUS307.description: Introduction to electroacoustic and computer music. Practical experience in a computer music studio, with synthesizers, samplers, MIDI, digital audio, musique concrète, Max/MSP and other computer music techniques.

MUS308.title: Popular Music and Society II
MUS308.subject: MUS
MUS308.description: The topic of the course varies in different years, and may include intensive studies of music for the cinema, folk music, rock music, the blues, or a specific performer or group.
MUS308.notes: • Not for credit in the BMus program.

MUS310.title: The Business of Music
MUS310.subject: MUS
MUS310.description: An in-depth, practical investigation of the music industry with emphasis on current trends in the creation and consumption of music as it relates to commerce. Students cultivate familiarity with common music business practices necessary for a career as a music professional and manager. Includes music marketing principles and practices related to publicity, touring, distribution, publishing, licensing and synchronization rights, radio, auditions and grant writing.
MUS310.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 310, MUS 391 (if taken in the same topic), MUS 411.
  • Open to all students.

MUS316A.title: History of Rock and Roll
MUS316A.subject: MUS
MUS316A.description: Explores the origins and cultural contexts of rock and roll from Delta blues to the punk scene. No background in music is required.
MUS316A.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 316A, MUS 308 (if taken in the same topic).
  • Not open to BMus students and cannot be used as a music elective.

MUS316B.title: The Beatles
MUS316B.subject: MUS
MUS316B.description: Examines the rise to fame of The Beatles in the cultural and political contexts of the 1960s. No background in music is required.
MUS316B.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 316B, MUS 308 (if taken in the same topic).
  • Not open to BMus students and cannot be used as a music elective.

MUS317.title: Indigenous Peoples and Music
MUS317.subject: MUS
MUS317.description: An introduction to sounds and music of Indigenous Peoples with particular emphasis upon cultural identities, colonization and revitalization. Includes examples from around the world.
MUS317.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 317, MUS 391 (if taken in the same topic).
  • Open to all students.

MUS320.title: Topics in World Music
MUS320.subject: MUS
MUS320.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only two of MUS 320, MUS 320A, MUS 320B, MUS 320C.
  • Open to all students.

MUS322.title: A Composer's Style and Music
MUS322.subject: MUS
MUS322.description: A study of works of a major composer in the period from the 15th to 20th centuries. Emphasis is placed on analysis, style and performance practice.

MUS323.title: Forms and Genres in Music
MUS323.subject: MUS
MUS323.description: The study of a single musical form or genre; for example, opera, symphony, sonata.

MUS325.title: The History of Jazz
MUS325.subject: MUS
MUS325.description: A survey of the development and growth of jazz with emphasis on the major stylistic periods, the principal soloists and composers, and the great recorded performances.
MUS325.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 325, MUS 325A.
  • Open to all students.

MUS331.title: Brasses
MUS331.subject: MUS
MUS331.description: Group instruction in playing orchestral brass instruments.

MUS332.title: Woodwinds
MUS332.subject: MUS
MUS332.description: An introduction to the pedagogy of teaching woodwind instruments.

MUS333.title: Percussion
MUS333.subject: MUS
MUS333.description: Group instruction in playing orchestral percussion instruments.

MUS335.title: Singing for the Stage
MUS335.subject: MUS
MUS335.description: Technical vocal instruction with application to theatre solos and ensembles. Includes preparation for auditions using fully-staged material. Although this is an introductory course, it is not a beginner's course. A background in theatre is recommended.

MUS336.title: Strings Techniques and Mentoring
MUS336.subject: MUS
MUS336.description: The fundamentals of early strings pedagogy focusing primarily on violin and cello. Includes field experience.

MUS337.title: Music in the Middle School Curriculum
MUS337.subject: MUS
MUS337.description: Middle school choral, instrumental and general music programs and materials.
MUS337.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 337, ME 301, ME 307.
  • A field work course taking place in a middle school.

MUS338.title: Keyboard Literature 1500-Present
MUS338.subject: MUS
MUS338.description: A survey of the basic literature of the keyboard from 1500 to present, with special attention to its place in Western music and culture.​
MUS338.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 338, MUS 328A, MUS 328B.
  • Open to all students.

MUS339A.title: Instrumental Techniques for Middle and Secondary Schools
MUS339A.subject: MUS
MUS339A.description: Practical introductory level instrumental ensemble experience (band/strings). Emphasis is on beginning instrumental methods and techniques.
MUS339A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 339A, ME 216, ME 309A.

MUS339B.title: Choral Techniques for Middle and Secondary Schools
MUS339B.subject: MUS
MUS339B.description: Practical introductory level choral ensemble experience. Emphasis is on beginning choral methods and techniques.
MUS339B.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 339B, ME 216, ME 309B.
  • Includes a Grade 8-12 school choral field experience normally during Reading Break.

MUS340.title: Individual Tuition
MUS340.subject: MUS
MUS340.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 340, MUS 345.

MUS342.title: Lyric Diction
MUS342.subject: MUS
MUS342.description: A study of the basic phonetics and accepted principles of lyric diction of the most commonly used languages in concert and operatic repertoire: Italian; French; German; English. Emphasis on performance.
MUS342.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 342, MUS 142, MUS 542.

MUS345.title: Seminar in Performance
MUS345.subject: MUS
MUS345.description: Individual tuition, integrated performance seminar, and weekly master class including discussion of repertoire, pedagogy, and techniques of performance.
MUS345.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 345, MUS 340.

MUS348.title: Improvisation
MUS348.subject: MUS
MUS348.description: Performance-based course. Investigates the association between improvisation and composition.
MUS348.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of MUS 348, MUS 347A, MUS 347B.

MUS351.title: Jazz Composition and Arranging
MUS351.subject: MUS
MUS351.description: The study of basic techniques applicable to composing, arranging, and orchestrating for the jazz ensemble.

MUS365.title: History of the Guitar
MUS365.subject: MUS
MUS365.description: A survey of the basic literature of the classical guitar from 1790 to the present, with special attention to the guitar's role in Western music and culture as an accompanying, ensemble and solo vehicle.

MUS380A.title: University Orchestra
MUS380A.subject: MUS
MUS380A.description: Rehearses and performs orchestral repertoire from the Baroque to the present.
MUS380A.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 380A, MUS 380.
  • Open to all students by audition.

MUS380B.title: University Wind Symphony
MUS380B.subject: MUS
MUS380B.description: Rehearses and performs advanced repertoire for winds, brass and percussion.
MUS380B.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 380B, MUS 380.
  • Open to all students by audition.

MUS380C.title: University Concert Band
MUS380C.subject: MUS
MUS380C.description: A non-auditioned campus and community concert band performing a range of music from pop, film, and jazz to classic and contemporary repertoire.
MUS380C.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 380C, MUS 380.
  • Open to all students.

MUS380D.title: Jazz and Creative Music Ensemble
MUS380D.subject: MUS
MUS380D.description: Rehearses and performs music with an emphasis on community and collaboration, including jazz, improvisation and soundtracks for silent film.
MUS380D.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 380D, MUS 380.
  • Open to all students by audition.

MUS380E.title: University Chorus
MUS380E.subject: MUS
MUS380E.description: A large mixed choral ensemble that rehearses and performs a varied repertoire and choral/orchestral works.
MUS380E.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 380E, MUS 380.
  • Open to all students.

MUS380F.title: Chamber Singers
MUS380F.subject: MUS
MUS380F.description: An auditioned choral ensemble performing advanced repertoire from a diverse spectrum of composers and styles.
MUS380F.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 380F, MUS 380.
  • Open to all students by audition. Previous choral experience and strong music skills are required.

MUS381.title: Chamber Music
MUS381.subject: MUS
MUS381.description: Ensembles include the standard chamber groups as well as New Music Ensemble (Sonic Lab), Opera Ensemble, Brass Choir, Vocal Jazz and Collaborative Piano.

MUS389.title: Vikes Band
MUS389.subject: MUS
MUS389.description: An ensemble that rehearses and performs at Vikes Varsity events at the Centre for Athletics, Recreation and Special Abilities (CARSA), and select special events on campus.
MUS389.notes:
• Open to all students.
  • Students should have a basic ability to play a band instrument, and must supply their own instrument or rent one.

MUS390.title: Special Studies
MUS390.subject: MUS
MUS390.description: With the consent of the School, a student who has demonstrated a capacity for independent work may undertake an individual project.

MUS391.title: Cross-Cultural and Historical Topics in Music
MUS391.subject: MUS
MUS391.description: Topics may include: issues in music history, world music, music and society or cross-disciplinary perspectives. No prerequisites. Open to music and non-music students.

MUS401A.title: Topics in Music Theory and Analysis
MUS401A.subject: MUS
MUS401A.description: The study of a topic in music theory or analysis such as rhythm and meter, timbre, sonata theory. Content may vary from year to year.

MUS401B.title: Counterpoint
MUS401B.subject: MUS
MUS401B.description: The study of counterpoint through analysis and writing, as it applies to diverse musical languages.

MUS401C.title: Acoustics of Music
MUS401C.subject: MUS
MUS401C.description: The physics of musical sound and the acoustics of musical instruments. Timbre, scales, tuning and temperament. An introduction to psychoacoustical issues.

MUS401D.title: Jazz Theory
MUS401D.subject: MUS
MUS401D.description: Theoretical aspects of jazz, including its harmonic and formal characteristics.

MUS405.title: Music Composition III
MUS405.subject: MUS
MUS405.description: Individual lessons with members of the Music Composition faculty. Majors complete and have performed a graduating work of advanced and significant scope.

MUS406A.title: Advanced Sound Recording Techniques
MUS406A.subject: MUS
MUS406A.description: Advanced study of the theory and practice of sound recording and audio technology, studio techniques and procedures. Includes concert hall acoustics, perceptual coding, high-resolution formats, electro-acoustic measurements, studio design and acoustics, and surround sound microphone techniques. Practical work includes the recording of School of Music concerts, post-production editing and working with the School of Music concert archive.

MUS406B.title: Sound Recording Seminar
MUS406B.subject: MUS
MUS406B.description: Advanced work in sound recording and music production techniques including classical music recording and editing, classical music production, popular music production, multi-track recording and editing, contemporary post-production techniques, multi-track mixing and audio mastering. Practical work includes the recording of School of Music concerts, post-production editing and working with the School of Music concert archive. This course requires the completion of a major recording project.

MUS407.title: Computer Music Seminar
MUS407.subject: MUS
MUS407.description: Advanced work in computer music, including study of software synthesis and analysis of digitized signals, interactive control of synthesizers, embedded systems and robotics. Extensive work in Max/MSP/jitter.

MUS431.title: Current Issues in Music Education
MUS431.subject: MUS
MUS431.description: Issues covered in this course may include music for the special learner, global music pedagogy, technology applications in music education, musical theatre, creativity in the music classroom, improvisation in the music classroom, guitar in the secondary music classroom.
MUS431.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 431, ME 209B.
  • Offered in alternate years.

MUS437.title: Music in the Secondary School Curriculum
MUS437.subject: MUS
MUS437.description: A study of programs and materials for secondary schools. Some school experience is required.
MUS437.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 437, ME 401, ME 407.

MUS439.title: Instrumental and Choral Clinic
MUS439.subject: MUS
MUS439.description: Practical ensemble experience in secondary instrumental and choral classes. Teaching techniques, conducting, repertoire and evaluation procedures are addressed.
MUS439.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 439, ME 316, ME 409.
  • Offered in alternate years.

MUS445.title: Seminar in Performance
MUS445.subject: MUS
MUS445.description: Individual tuition, integrated performance seminar and weekly class including discussion of repertoire, pedagogy, and techniques of ensemble performance.

MUS462A.title: Seminar in Performance of New Music
MUS462A.subject: MUS
MUS462A.description: This seminar/workshop provides intensive professional training for performers who work together with composers in the creation, performance and production of new music. Performers prepare new works composed specifically for them by the composers registered simultaneously in MUS 462B. Training in contemporary notation and performance practices, extended techniques, instrumentation, analysis, conducting techniques, communication skills and concert production. The final project is a festival. Open to third- and fourth-year music students.
MUS462A.notes: • A combined undergraduate and graduate course (MUS 562A - Graduate Seminar in Performance of New Music).

MUS462B.title: Seminar in Contemporary Composition and Performance
MUS462B.subject: MUS
MUS462B.description: This seminar/workshop provides intensive professional training for performers who work together with composers in the creation, performance and production of new music. Composers create new works composed specifically for the performers registered simultaneously in MUS 462A. Training in contemporary notation and performance practices, extended techniques, instrumentation, analysis, conducting techniques, communication skills and concert production. The final project is a festival. Open to third- and fourth-year music students.
MUS462B.notes: • A combined undergraduate and graduate course (MUS 562B Graduate Seminar in Contemporary Composition and Performance).

MUS480A.title: University Orchestra
MUS480A.subject: MUS
MUS480A.description: Rehearses and performs orchestral repertoire from the Baroque to the present.
MUS480A.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 480A, MUS 480.
  • Open to all students by audition.
  • A combined undergraduate and graduate course.

MUS480B.title: University Wind Symphony
MUS480B.subject: MUS
MUS480B.description: Rehearses and performs advanced repertoire for winds, brass and percussion.
MUS480B.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 480B, MUS 480.
  • Open to all students by audition.
  • A combined undergraduate and graduate course.

MUS480C.title: University Concert Band
MUS480C.subject: MUS
MUS480C.description: A non-auditioned campus and community concert band performing a range of music from pop, film, and jazz to classic and contemporary repertoire.
MUS480C.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 480C, MUS 480.
  • Open to all students.
  • A combined undergraduate and graduate course.

MUS480D.title: Jazz and Creative Music Ensemble
MUS480D.subject: MUS
MUS480D.description: Rehearses and performs music with an emphasis on community and collaboration, including jazz, improvisation and soundtracks for silent film.
MUS480D.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 480D, MUS 480.
  • Open to all students by audition.
  • A combined undergraduate and graduate course.

MUS480E.title: University Chorus
MUS480E.subject: MUS
MUS480E.description: A large mixed choral ensemble that rehearses and performs a varied repertoire and choral/orchestral works.
MUS480E.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 480E, MUS 480.
  • Open to all students.
  • A combined undergraduate and graduate course.

MUS480F.title: Chamber Singers
MUS480F.subject: MUS
MUS480F.description: An auditioned choral ensemble performing advanced repertoire from a diverse spectrum of composers and styles.
MUS480F.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 480F, MUS 480.
  • Open to all students by audition. Previous choral experience and strong music skills are required.
  • A combined undergraduate and graduate course.

MUS481.title: Chamber Music
MUS481.subject: MUS
MUS481.description: Ensembles include the standard chamber groups as well as New Music Ensemble (Sonic Lab), Opera Ensemble, Brass Choir, Vocal Jazz and Collaborative Piano.
MUS481.notes:
• Students in a fifth year of study may request permission to register in the course.
  • A combined undergraduate and graduate course.

MUS489.title: Vikes Band
MUS489.subject: MUS
MUS489.description: An ensemble that rehearses and performs at Vikes Varsity events at the Centre for Athletics, Recreation and Special Abilities (CARSA), and select special events on campus.
MUS489.notes:
• Open to all students.
  • Students should have a basic ability to play a band instrument, and must supply their own instrument or rent one.

MUS490.title: Special Studies
MUS490.subject: MUS
MUS490.description: With the consent of the School, a student who has demonstrated a capacity for independent work may undertake an individual project.

MUS498A.title: Music Research I
MUS498A.subject: MUS
MUS498A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 498A, MUS 398.

MUS498B.title: Music Research II
MUS498B.subject: MUS
MUS498B.description: Supervised completion of a capstone musicology project.
MUS498B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of MUS 498B, MUS 498.

MUS499.title: Graduating Projects in Music History
MUS499.subject: MUS
MUS499.description: A graduating project consisting of a major essay, study of selected readings, and an oral defence.

NURS341.title: Professional Practice IV: Nursing Inquiry
NURS341.subject: NURS
NURS341.description: Builds on Professional Practice I, II and III. Knowledge for the discipline of nursing is explored as well as various modes of nursing inquiry. Relationships between practice, theory, and research are explored.

NURS342.title: Health and Healing VI: Global Health Issues
NURS342.subject: NURS
NURS342.description: Study of complex chronic and episodic global health challenges and issues. Emphasis is placed on the role of the nurse as care provider, community organizer/facilitator, educator and advocate within the context of the global society and the changing health care environment. Participants examine emerging health issues and trends further to develop their understanding of nursing practice.

NURS345.title: Family Nursing
NURS345.subject: NURS
NURS345.description: Building on existing knowledge of registered nurses, students have the opportunity to develop an understanding of health-promoting family nursing. Four major domains are explored theoretically and experientially: health, family, relational nursing practice and ethics.
NURS345.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of NURS 345, NURS 330, NURS 331.

NURS350.title: Health and Healing VII: Promoting Community and Societal Health
NURS350.subject: NURS
NURS350.description: Explores knowledge for nursing as a practice of relationship and inquiry, in promoting community and societal health. Emphasis is placed on working with community and society, from perspectives of social justice, health equity and political action, community development and capacity building for community health promotion, and transformative and emancipatory approaches to teaching and learning. Students engage in community-based learning activities to integrate theory and practice.
NURS350.notes: • Normally, a student must pass both theory and practice co-requisites in the same term to advance in the program. If a student fails one co-requisite but achieves a minimum grade of B (73-76%) or higher in the second the student may not be required to complete both co-requisites again the next time they are offered.

NURS351.title: Nursing Practice VI: Promoting Health of Communities and Society
NURS351.subject: NURS
NURS351.description: Provides opportunities to develop caring relationships with families, groups and communities and/or populations with an emphasis on health promotion and community empowerment. Participants have opportunities to work with a community on an identified health issue.
NURS351.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of NURS 351, NURS 456.
  • Normally, a student must pass both theory and practice co-requisites in the same term to advance in the program. If a student fails one co-requisite but achieves a minimum grade of B (73-76%) or higher in the second the student may not be required to complete both co-requisites again the next time they are offered.

NURS360.title: Professional Practice VI: Nursing Research
NURS360.subject: NURS
NURS360.description: Building on Professional Practice II, III, and IV, participants enhance their understanding of nursing scholarship and their abilities to comprehend, critique and utilize nursing research. Participants critically reflect on various scholarly works and research methodologies. Participants experience ways to critically examine their practice in relation to nursing research and to pose research questions for evidence-informed practice.

NURS370.title: Consolidated Practice Experience III
NURS370.subject: NURS
NURS370.description: Provides opportunities for participants to integrate learning from previous terms, and to advance their professional nursing practice. Participants have opportunities to consolidate learning and advance their clinical decision making in a variety of settings. Nursing practice experiences consist of a six week practice placement.
NURS370.notes: • CPE Workshops are required for all BSN Partnership students.

NURS390.title: Directed Studies
NURS390.subject: NURS
NURS390.description: Directed readings, research projects or special studies in a specified area of interest. A proposal is developed in consultation with a faculty member and includes a plan for the evaluation of the student's work. The proposal must receive the approval of the Director or designate before students are permitted to register.

NURS400.title: Academic Writing for Nurses
NURS400.subject: NURS
NURS400.description: Elective online credit course, gives students practice writing academic genres: summaries, analyses, arguments, abstracts and literature reviews. Students refresh grammar and APA skills and share and improve their writing through peer review and revision. Scaffolded assignments, drafting, revision, and self-reflective exercises assist students to develop writing voice and build confidence. This course is directed to undergraduate nursing students to improve academic writing.
NURS400.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of NURS 400, NURS 300, NURS 390 (if taken in the same topic), NURS 480 (if taken in the same topic).

NURS405.title: Statistics for Evidence-Based Practice
NURS405.subject: NURS
NURS405.description: Introduction to basic statistics used by healthcare professionals in critically appraising research literature. The current demand for accountability, professionalism, knowledge translation activities, and evidence-based practice are of paramount importance when making clinical decisions. Offers a solid foundation in preparing for future advanced research courses.
NURS405.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of NURS 405, NURS 480 (if taken in the same topic).

NURS425.title: Quantitative and Qualitative Analysis
NURS425.subject: NURS
NURS425.description: Address the techniques commonly used in the analysis of both quantitative and qualitative data. Understand a range of statistics commonly used in nursing research and learn how they are used in a computer-based application. Understand how qualitative data is used in nursing research and engage in the process of coding qualitative data through coding and thematic construction.
NURS425.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of NURS 425, HSD 425.
  • All students must have basic computing and word processing skills prior to enrolling in the course.
  • This course is offered in an online delivery mode.

NURS430.title: Professional Practice V: Leadership in Nursing
NURS430.subject: NURS
NURS430.description: Investigates knowledge of leadership for nursing practice in the promotion of health for individuals, families, groups and communities. Topics include nurses' roles in the Canadian health care system, nurses' influence in change, impacts of global trends and issues, collaborative and ethical approaches for working within institutional philosophies and frameworks and issues facing nurses in current work environments. Students engage in leadership experiences to integrate theory and practice of leadership competencies.
NURS430.notes: • Normally, a student must pass both theory and practice co-requisites in the same term to advance in the program. If a student fails one co-requisite but achieves a minimum grade of B (73-76%) or higher in the second the student may not be required to complete both co-requisites again the next time they are offered.

NURS431.title: Nursing Practice VII: Engaging in Leadership
NURS431.subject: NURS
NURS431.description: Provides opportunities to further develop competencies in the areas of leadership, influencing and managing change, and using research to promote the health of individuals, families, communities and society within the context of the Canadian health care system. Focus on participants' growth as nursing professionals; opportunities to explore inter-professional practices and nursing leadership in the context of emerging Canadian and global health issues and trends.
NURS431.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of NURS 431, NURS 456.
  • Normally, a student must pass both theory and practice co-requisites in the same term to advance in the program. If a student fails one co-requisite but achieves a minimum grade of B (73-76%) or higher in the second the student may not be required to complete both co-requisites again the next time they are offered.

NURS450.title: Nursing Leadership and Management
NURS450.subject: NURS
NURS450.description: Enhances participants' understanding of the meaning of leadership and the tasks of management. Worldviews that influence perceptions of health care and health organizations and current approaches to managing health care are studied. Nursing leadership in establishing a climate in which quality of care and quality work environments can become a reality are emphasized.

NURS456.title: Nursing within Communities and Health Systems
NURS456.subject: NURS
NURS456.description: Apply nursing knowledge, skills, judgements, and attributes where people intersect with communities, organizations and health systems. Students analyze and utilize evidence-informed data to: influence change, promote inter-professional collaboration to enhance continuity, address challenges and deliver safe, ethical, quality care, foster social justice, empowerment, and culturally competent practice, and provide leadership.
NURS456.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of NURS 456, NURS 351, NURS 431.

NURS470.title: Consolidated Practice Experience IV
NURS470.subject: NURS
NURS470.description: Provides opportunities for participants to integrate learning from previous terms, and to advance their professional nursing practice. Participants have opportunities to consolidate learning and advance their clinical decision-making in a variety of settings. Nursing practice experiences consist of a six-week practice placement.
NURS470.notes: • CPE Workshops are required for all BSN Partnership students.

NURS475.title: Consolidated Practice Experience V
NURS475.subject: NURS
NURS475.description: Provides opportunities for participants to integrate learning from previous terms, and to advance their professional nursing practice. In a variety of settings, participants have opportunities to consolidate learning, and advance their clinical decision-making. Nursing practice experiences consist of a six-week practice placement.
NURS475.notes: • CPE Workshops are required for all BSN Partnership students.

NURS480.title: Special Topics
NURS480.subject: NURS
NURS480.description: Topics of current interest or concern to groups of students.

NURS481C.title: Nursing Practice in Hospice Palliative Care
NURS481C.subject: NURS
NURS481C.description: Explore nursing practice in hospice palliative care. Examine and analyze historical, theoretical, personal and professional perspectives in relation to their impact on nursing practice. Gain understanding of the human experience of persons living their dying and how nurses choose to engage with and serve hospice palliative care patients. Examine these dimensions to guide practise with persons living their dying in ways that uphold human dignity and honour human uniqueness.
NURS481C.notes: • This course is offered in an online delivery mode.

NURS482.title: Pharmacological Knowledge for Nursing Practice
NURS482.subject: NURS
NURS482.description: A systematic approach to develop knowledge of pharmacological, herbal and homeopathic interventions. Students have opportunities to explore populations of interest and local, national, and/or global issues related to pharmacological interventions and marketing. Students work collaboratively to develop and disseminate nursing knowledge.
NURS482.notes:
• In the on-campus course, online work complements in-classroom instruction.
  • In the online course, conferencing tools will be used to augment required learning activities, readings and assignments.

NURS484.title: Understanding Indigenous Health and Wellbeing
NURS484.subject: NURS
NURS484.description: Develops student understanding of the socio-cultural history and current context that shapes the lives of Indigenous people and their communities' health in Canada. We enter into a 'relational space' through the use of storytelling, self-reflection, and experiential learning methods, and engage a critical social lens that explores power, white privilege, racism and culture. Embedded in this course are the strengths and gifts of Indigenous knowledge and teachings.

NURS487.title: Health Care Law
NURS487.subject: NURS
NURS487.description: Designed to allow students to develop an understanding of the origin and sources of the law as it applies to the Canadian health care system. Stimulates an appreciation for legal terminology, reasoning, and processes as well as the basic principles of law which apply to and govern the delivery of health care services in Canada. Designed to develop an ability to identify the legal aspects of health care practice, information systems and management as well as an ability to determine when and how to use legal counsel effectively.
NURS487.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of NURS 487, HINF 330, HINF 491 (if taken in the same topic).

NURS490.title: Directed Studies
NURS490.subject: NURS
NURS490.description: Directed readings, research projects or special studies in a specified area of interest. A proposal is developed in consultation with a faculty member and includes a plan for the evaluation of the student's work. The proposal must receive the approval of the Director or designate before students are permitted to register.

NURS491.title: Nursing Practice VIII: Transitions
NURS491.subject: NURS
NURS491.description: Provides opportunities for participants to consolidate their learning and explore the transition to professional nursing as a BSN graduate. Participants also explore transitions in the health care system and the workplace that affect nurses. Participants may develop their practice within a specific area, e.g., particular setting of practice, a certain client population, or a specific health challenge.
NURS491.notes: • CPE Workshops are required for all BSN Partnership students.

NURS493A.title: Community Health Nursing
NURS493A.subject: NURS
NURS493A.description: Examines the theoretical and conceptual foundations of community health nursing practice. Students explore and critique nurses' roles in community health nursing, particularly in public health and in primary health care settings. Provides opportunities to advance and/or to add to your nursing knowledge and experience. Community health assessment, individual health assessment, population-focused practice, epidemiology, communicable disease control, and health-promoting practice with specific populations and in relation to specific health issues are explored and critiqued.

NURS493C.title: Lived Experience of Health in Aging
NURS493C.subject: NURS
NURS493C.description: Examines the complex nature of aging and health. Explores determinants of health, as well as the common chronic and episodic challenges of health and healing in later life. Changing demographics and societal forces influencing present and future health care of older persons are analyzed and critiqued. Examines nursing theory and issues related to the delivery of care with older persons. Health promotion and nursing practice, and environments that support healthy aging are integral to this course.

NURS495.title: Nursing Practice Synthesis
NURS495.subject: NURS
NURS495.description: This final course of the Post Diploma BSN program is designed as a practice course. The course informs transition to baccalaureate-prepared nursing practice. Course activities foster integration and synthesis of prior learning, and further strengthen theory and evidence-informed knowledge addressing key program concepts.
NURS495.notes:
• Post-diploma students may take NURS 495 more than once for credit to a maximum of 4.5 units.
  • Students who wish to condense their practice hours will not be able to do so until after week six of the course.

NURS496.title: Nursing with Childbearing Families
NURS496.subject: NURS
NURS496.description: Employ a woman and family-centered approach that attends to health inequities, material, social, and discursive conditions and the experiences of all family members to explore nursing care for childbearing families from preconception through the childbearing year. Develop the knowledge and clinical judgement needed for working with common perinatal, neonatal, rural and public health nursing situations.
NURS496.notes: • This course is offered in an online delivery mode.

NURS497.title: Nursing at the Intersections in Mental Health and Substance Use
NURS497.subject: NURS
NURS497.description: Focuses on mental health, mental illness, substance use and addictions in the Canadian context. The core concepts of relational practice, epigenetics and social dimensions of substance use and mental health are applied. Harm reduction, cultural safety and trauma and violence informed practice are integrated through case study, context-based learning, and arts-based approaches to enhance student application of nursing practice related to mental health and substance use.
NURS497.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of NURS 497 or NURS 480 (if taken in the same special topic).

PAAS100.title: Introduction to Pacific and Asian Studies
PAAS100.subject: PAAS
PAAS100.description: Introduces central themes in Pacific and Asian Studies and develops foundational skills required for more advanced study. Areas covered may include film, literature, new media, religion, gender, art, music, pop culture, politics and economics.

PAAS101.title: Text, Manipulation, Propaganda
PAAS101.subject: PAAS
PAAS101.description: The process of textual analysis, covering the written word, film and theatre from different genres, eras and countries. Analysis of the relationship between narrative features, emotional or ideological manipulation of the reader, and various types of propaganda in Asia.

PAAS103.title: Global Wars in Asia and the Pacific
PAAS103.subject: PAAS
PAAS103.description: Traces the transnational history of the wars in the region in relation to the political, economic, socio-cultural and ideological dynamics of Asian Pacific countries including Japan, North and South Koreas, China, Taiwan, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, the Philippines, Pacific Islands, and the United States.
PAAS103.notes: • Credit will be granted to only one of these courses: PAAS 103, HSTR 103

crossListed.title: Global Wars in Asia and the Pacific

PAAS116.title: Beginner Chinese I: Part 1
PAAS116.subject: PAAS
PAAS116.description: First half of Beginner Chinese I for students with no prior or very limited knowledge of Chinese. Basic skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese.
PAAS116.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 116, PAAS 110, PAAS 118.
  • Not open to fluent speakers of Chinese.

PAAS117.title: Beginner Chinese I: Part 2
PAAS117.subject: PAAS
PAAS117.description: Second half of Beginner Chinese I and a continuation of PAAS 116. Further development of basic communication skills in listening, speaking, reading and writing.
PAAS117.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 117, PAAS 110, PAAS 118.
  • Not open to fluent speakers of Chinese.

PAAS118.title: Intensive Beginner Chinese I
PAAS118.subject: PAAS
PAAS118.description: Intensive Chinese language instruction for beginning language students.
PAAS118.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 118, PAAS 110, CHIN 100, CHIN 100A, CHIN 100B, CHIN 149.
  • Not open to fluent speakers of Chinese.

PAAS120.title: Introduction to Indonesian I
PAAS120.subject: PAAS
PAAS120.description: Indonesian for students with no previous knowledge of the language with emphasis on developing listening comprehension and speaking ability; common conversational patterns, as well as some of the cultural reasoning behind them. Reading and writing are also introduced.
PAAS120.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 120, SEA 100A.
  • Limited to 25 students per section.

PAAS121.title: Introduction to Indonesian II
PAAS121.subject: PAAS
PAAS121.description: Basic conversations and grammar in Indonesian and readings of a variety of elementary textual materials.
PAAS121.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 121, SEA 100B.
  • Limited to 25 students per section.

PAAS128.title: Introduction to Korean I
PAAS128.subject: PAAS
PAAS128.notes: • Not open to fluent speakers of Korean.

PAAS129.title: Introduction to Korean II
PAAS129.subject: PAAS
PAAS129.description: Basic conversations and grammar in Korean and readings of a variety of elementary textual materials.
PAAS129.notes: • Not open to fluent speakers of Korean.

PAAS138.title: Intensive Beginner Japanese I
PAAS138.subject: PAAS
PAAS138.description: Japanese language instruction for beginning language students. Development of basic language skills, including listening, speaking, reading and writing.
PAAS138.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 138, PAAS 130, JAPA 100, JAPA 100A, JAPA 100B, JAPA 149.

PAAS150.title: Premodern Chinese Culture
PAAS150.subject: PAAS
PAAS150.description: An introduction to the history and culture of China from earliest times to the mid-19th century. Philosophy, religion, art and literature are the most important areas of discussion. Relevant political, economic, social and educational traditions are introduced as well.
PAAS150.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 150, CHIN 201, CHIN 201A.
  • No knowledge of Chinese language is required.

PAAS151.title: Modern Chinese Culture
PAAS151.subject: PAAS
PAAS151.description: A survey of Chinese culture from the mid-19th century to the present. Contemporary culture patterns are placed in traditional perspective, while relevant political, economic and social contexts are also considered. Emphasizing the effects of modern events on cultural life, particularly literature, the arts, religion and education system.
PAAS151.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 151, CHIN 201, CHIN 201B.

PAAS152.title: Essentials of Chinese Civilisation (in Chinese)
PAAS152.subject: PAAS
PAAS152.description: Introduces the essential features, beliefs, institutions and arts of Chinese civilisation, from the earliest times through the nineteenth century.

PAAS153.title: Chinese Food Culture
PAAS153.subject: PAAS
PAAS153.description: An introduction to the history, customs, language, art/aesthetics and science of Chinese food in and beyond the Sinophone world. Additional attention given to exploring the history of Chinese diaspora—particularly in North America—through the lens of the globalization of Chinese food.

PAAS170.title: Premodern Southeast Asian Cultures
PAAS170.subject: PAAS
PAAS170.description: A survey of cultural developments in Southeast Asia from earliest times to the 19th century.
PAAS170.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 170, SEA 201, SEA 201A.

PAAS171.title: Modern Southeast Asian Cultures
PAAS171.subject: PAAS
PAAS171.description: Examines the development of modern Southeast Asian cultures, paying particular attention to media such as the press, popular music, theatre, film and television.
PAAS171.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 171, SEA 201, SEA 201B.

PAAS180.title: Premodern Japanese Culture
PAAS180.subject: PAAS
PAAS180.description: Surveys Japan's cultural past from earliest times to the mid-19th century. Emphasizes the outstanding developments of each epoch, especially in the areas of literature, drama, philosophy and religion, and the visual arts. No knowledge of Japanese language is required.
PAAS180.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 180, JAPA 201, JAPA 201A.

PAAS181.title: Modern Japanese Culture
PAAS181.subject: PAAS
PAAS181.description: Survey of Japanese culture from the mid-19th century to the present. Developments in literature, film, technology, ethnicity, religion, consumerism, manga and anime are considered in their historical and social contexts. No knowledge of Japanese language is required.
PAAS181.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 181, JAPA 201, JAPA 201B.

PAAS202.title: Topics in Asian Cinema
PAAS202.subject: PAAS
PAAS202.description: The analysis of thematic issues, variations, stylistic considerations and mechanics of meaning production in Asian cinema. Looks at both contemporary and classic films from Japan, China, Taiwan and Indonesia.

PAAS204.title: Introduction to Asian Religions
PAAS204.subject: PAAS
PAAS204.description: A survey of the sources, beliefs and practices of Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism and the Chinese religions. The traditions are studied in their cultural and political contexts from both historical and contemporary perspectives.
PAAS204.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 204, RCS 200B, RS 200B.

PAAS206.title: Comics and Graphic Novels in Asia and the Pacific
PAAS206.subject: PAAS
PAAS206.description: Introduces theories of graphic narratives and visual storytelling. Focus on works from Asia and North America representing experiences of life in Asia or in the global Asian Diaspora. Special emphasis on the development of the form, and of particular styles and themes within their local and global contexts.

PAAS207.title: Ghosts and Spirits
PAAS207.subject: PAAS
PAAS207.description: Ghosts and spirits in literature, drama and cinema from the Asia-Pacific. Explores how these texts interact with philosophical and religious belief systems.

PAAS208.title: Family, Gender and Sexuality in the Asia-Pacific
PAAS208.subject: PAAS
PAAS208.description: Introduces domestic relationships, constructs of gender and their intersections with broader political and economic processes in the Asia-Pacific and diasporic communities.
PAAS208.notes: Credit will be granted to only one of PAAS 208, GNDR 211.

crossListed.title: Family, Gender and Sexuality in the Asia-Pacific

PAAS209.title: Introductory Special Topics in Pacific and Asian Studies
PAAS209.subject: PAAS
PAAS209.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 209, PACI 281 (if taken in the same topic).

PAAS215.title: Language, Media and Translation in PAAS
PAAS215.subject: PAAS
PAAS215.description: Introduces approaches to language, media and translation in Pacific and Asian Studies, with an emphasis on reading critically for meaning, style, genre and context. Fosters an appreciation for the role of language in shaping our experience as human beings, both individually and collectively.

PAAS218.title: Intensive Beginner Chinese II
PAAS218.subject: PAAS
PAAS218.description: Bringing beginner students to the lower-intermediate level in modern standard Chinese. Primary emphasis on reading and translation of texts in modern Chinese in both standard and simplified characters. Introduction of elements of the classical language as used in modern writing. Attention to listening, speaking and writing skills.
PAAS218.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 218, PAAS 111, CHIN 150, CHIN 200, CHIN 200A, CHIN 200B.
  • Not open to fluent speakers of Chinese.

PAAS220.title: Intermediate Indonesian I
PAAS220.subject: PAAS
PAAS220.description: A continuation of 121 for students who wish to improve their skills in Indonesian. Includes advanced grammar and use of simple newspaper materials to stimulate students' ability to read and discuss a variety of topics.
PAAS220.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 220, SEA 200, SEA 200A.
  • Limited to 25 students per section.

PAAS221.title: Intermediate Indonesian II
PAAS221.subject: PAAS
PAAS221.description: Continues the focus of 220 with increasingly-advanced readings, schema exercises to facilitate vocabulary building and longer written assignments. Emphasis on speaking, reading, writing and listening prepares students for immersion experiences and advanced language work.
PAAS221.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 221, SEA 200, SEA 200B.
  • Limited to 25 students per section.

PAAS228.title: Pre-Intermediate Korean I
PAAS228.subject: PAAS
PAAS228.description: Continuation of PAAS 129 for students who wish to improve their skills in Korean. Includes advanced sentence patterns (grammar) and use of written and audio-visual materials to stimulate students’ ability to communicate on a variety of topics.
PAAS228.notes: • Not open to fluent speakers of Korean.

PAAS229.title: Pre-Intermediate Korean II
PAAS229.subject: PAAS
PAAS229.description: Continues the focus of PAAS 228 with increasingly advanced readings, schema exercises to facilitate vocabulary building and longer written assignments. Emphasis on listening, speaking, reading and writing prepares students for immersion experiences and more advanced language work.
PAAS229.notes: • Not open to fluent speakers of Korean.

PAAS238.title: Intensive Beginner Japanese II
PAAS238.subject: PAAS
PAAS238.description: Continuation of 138 for those students who intend to practise their listening comprehension, speaking and reading abilities, and writing skills on a more advanced level.
PAAS238.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 238, PAAS 131, JAPA 150, JAPA 200.

PAAS240.title: Traditions of Death and Dying in Asia
PAAS240.subject: PAAS
PAAS240.description: Surveys traditions of death and dying in Asia through the critical analysis of various media, sites and events—such as scripture, statuary, contemplative art, funerary processions, afterlife theme parks, music and film. Draws on Hindu, Buddhist, Islamic and other traditions from across East, South and Southeast Asia.
PAAS240.notes: Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 240, RCS 240.

crossListed.title: Traditions of Death and Dying in Asia

PAAS252.title: Pop Cultural Asia
PAAS252.subject: PAAS
PAAS252.description: Surveys popular cultures of Asia and their social, political and economic uses. Pop cultural materials from Korea, Japan, China and Southeast Asia will be examined in their local, regional and global contexts.

PAAS253.title: Activism in Asia
PAAS253.subject: PAAS
PAAS253.description: A critical survey of activism and activist movements in Asia, exploring their local, regional and global contexts, including historical contexts such as anti-colonial struggles. Issues addressed include, but are not limited to, climate change, anti-racism, lgbtq rights, indigenous rights, digital rights, labour rights, press freedom, participatory governance, corruption and social justice.

PAAS265A.title: China and the Premodern World
PAAS265A.subject: PAAS
PAAS265A.description: Introduction to the political, intellectual and socioeconomic history of China and its relations with other premodern civilizations to 1840. Topics include Chinese philosophies and religions, imperial institutions and traditions, elite and popular classes, science and technology, the contacts of China with other premodern nations and comparison of these countries in a global context.
PAAS265A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 265A, HIST 252, HIST 253, HSTR 265A, PACI 253.

PAAS265B.title: China and the Modern West
PAAS265B.subject: PAAS
PAAS265B.description: Survey of modern Chinese history with an emphasis on China's relations to the West from 1840 to 2010. Topics include China's responses to Western challenges and early modernization, its Republican, Nationalist and Communist revolutions and its recent reforms and rise as a global power.
PAAS265B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 265B, HIST 254, HSTR 265B, PACI 254.

PAAS274.title: How to Learn a Language
PAAS274.subject: PAAS
PAAS274.description: Current issues in learning a new language, including techniques and strategies for learning language skills such as grammar, vocabulary and pronunciation. The role of activities such as comprehension, production, instruction, practice and error correction in learning such skills.
PAAS274.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 274, LING 274.

PAAS275.title: Modern South Asia from Early Empires to Gandhi
PAAS275.subject: PAAS
PAAS275.description: Examines the political and cultural history of South Asia. Focus on ancient and early modern India, the emergence of religious diversity, the rise of Buddhism, Islam, Sikhism and trans-regional connections with the outside world. Explores modern institutions from the early 18th century through 1947, featuring the rise of the East India Companies, the 1857-58 rebellions, the British Empire in India, the rise of nationalism and the partition of colonial India.
PAAS275.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 275, HSTR 275

crossListed.title: Modern South Asia from Early Empires to Gandhi

PAAS279.title: Introduction to Chinese Language and Linguistics
PAAS279.subject: PAAS
PAAS279.description: Introduces the synchronic and diachronic descriptions of Chinese. Subjects covered may include phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, historical changes, poetics, dialectology, orthography, the sociolinguistic and psycholinguistic aspects of Chinese, the history of Chinese linguistics and the relationship between the Chinese language, thought and culture.
PAAS279.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 279, CHIN 261, LING 261.

crossListed.title: Introduction to Chinese Language and Linguistics

PAAS280.title: A Taste of Japan
PAAS280.subject: PAAS
PAAS280.description: A survey through film, TV dramas, literature and other readings of Japanese food and gastronomy: its nutritional value, its history, its relationship to art and aesthetics, entertainment, economy and the environment, and its role in the globalization of food culture.

PAAS285.title: Environmental Justice in Asia
PAAS285.subject: PAAS
PAAS285.description: Surveys the framework of environmental justice in Asia and the Pacific to understand how different groups mobilize to engage with environments and advocate for infrastructure to support development.

PAAS299.title: Experiential Learning
PAAS299.subject: PAAS
PAAS299.description: Students present a project, approved in advance, based on the experience of living, working, or studying in an Asian language-speaking environment.

PAAS305.title: Religions of East Asia
PAAS305.subject: PAAS
PAAS305.description: A survey of the religious literature and systematic thought of the traditions of China and Japan, including Confucianism, Daoism, Buddhism and Shinto.
PAAS305.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 305, RCS 361, RS 361.

PAAS307.title: Globalization and Religion
PAAS307.subject: PAAS
PAAS307.description: Examines how scholars account for simultaneous worldwide religious resurgence and economic globalization.
PAAS307.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 307, RCS 381, RS 381.

PAAS309.title: Human Rights and Cultural Expression in the Asia-Pacific Region
PAAS309.subject: PAAS
PAAS309.description: Examines connections between concepts of and debates about Human Rights in relation to a variety of forms of cultural expression. Forms of expression may include film, literature, music, graphic arts and mass media. Investigates material from and about China, Japan, South Asia, Southeast Asia, the Pacific Islands and the Asian Diaspora.

PAAS315.title: Critical Approaches to History, Culture and Society in PAAS
PAAS315.subject: PAAS
PAAS315.description: Develops students’ understanding of critical approaches to history, culture and society in Pacific and Asian Studies. Analyzes the rhetorical strategies employed in academic prose, and to contextualize scholarly arguments with reference to broader social, cultural and historical contexts.

PAAS318.title: Intermediate Chinese
PAAS318.subject: PAAS
PAAS318.description: Emphasis placed on acquiring new vocabulary and developing reading skills. Students have the opportunity to make more advanced classroom presentations and present longer written assignments in Chinese.
PAAS318.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 318, PAAS 210, PAAS 211, CHIN 249, CHIN 249A, CHIN 249B, CHIN 300.
  • Not open to fluent speakers of Chinese.

PAAS320.title: Indigenous Modernities in Asia
PAAS320.subject: PAAS
PAAS320.description: Surveys Indigenous efforts toward decolonization and self-determination in the Asia-Pacific since the 1970s and their relationship to global Indigenous movements. Considers how Asian Indigeneities, movements for autonomy and Land/Water relations are shaped by storytelling, art, gender, politics, sociality and environmental health. Focusing on histories of mobility and diaspora, a special emphasis is placed on contrasts with Indigeneity in the Americas.

PAAS338.title: Intermediate Japanese
PAAS338.subject: PAAS
PAAS338.description: A continuation of PAAS 238, aimed at a balanced development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills.
PAAS338.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 338, PAAS 230, JAPA 249, JAPA 250, JAPA 300, JAPA 311.

PAAS340.title: Integrative Intermediate Japanese
PAAS340.subject: PAAS
PAAS340.description: A continuation of PAAS 338, offering further development of language skills. Focusses primarily on reading and writing, for students who want to gain fundamental competence in the Japanese language in preparation for advanced academic or career goals. Classes conducted in Japanese.
PAAS340.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 340, PAAS 330, JAPA 250, JAPA 311.

PAAS341.title: Advanced Readings in Japanese I
PAAS341.subject: PAAS
PAAS341.description: Readings in modern Japanese, designed to broaden students' acquaintance with the Japanese writing system, expand their working vocabulary and provide a firmer grounding to their general knowledge of the language. Course content may vary from year to year.
PAAS341.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 341, PAAS 331, JAPA 312, JAPA 400.

PAAS342.title: Advanced Readings in Japanese II
PAAS342.subject: PAAS
PAAS342.description: For students who wish to expand their working vocabulary and develop their skills in reading modern Japanese. Course content may vary from year to year.
PAAS342.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 342, PAAS 332, JAPA 313, JAPA 400.

PAAS343.title: Advanced Comprehension and Conversation in Japanese
PAAS343.subject: PAAS
PAAS343.description: An advanced course designed to develop knowledge of practical Japanese through listening and speaking practice.
PAAS343.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 343, PAAS 333, JAPA 314, JAPA 411.

PAAS344.title: Advanced Composition in Japanese
PAAS344.subject: PAAS
PAAS344.description: An advanced course designed to develop knowledge of written Japanese through practical writing practice.
PAAS344.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 344, PAAS 334, JAPA 315, JAPA 411.

PAAS345.title: Japanese through Popular Culture
PAAS345.subject: PAAS
PAAS345.description: A cultural approach to the Japanese language for daily life in Japan, using manga, anime, films, popular media and television to improve speaking, listening and reading, but focussing primarily on daily, communicative Japanese. Classes conducted in Japanese.
PAAS345.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 345, PAAS 336.

PAAS346.title: Digital Asia
PAAS346.subject: PAAS
PAAS346.description: Examines emerging digital technologies and cultures of Asia, exploring the ways in which new media have transformed the possibilities for agency, community and tradition. Developments in Korea, Japan, China and Southeast Asia will be examined with reference to local, regional and global contexts.
