PAAS351.title: Contemporary Chinese Society
PAAS351.subject: PAAS
PAAS351.description: Traces China's economic development and socialist transformation since 1949.
PAAS351.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 351, PACI 319B, PACI 419.

PAAS352.title: Global Taiwan
PAAS352.subject: PAAS
PAAS352.description: Surveys key aspects of Taiwanese history, culture and society, with special attention to the dynamic relations and interactions between this multi-ethnic, multilingual, and multicultural island and countries in Asia, North America and beyond.
PAAS352.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 352, HSTR 354

PAAS353.title: Survey of Classical Chinese Literature
PAAS353.subject: PAAS
PAAS353.description: Introduces major topics and masterpieces in classical Chinese literature from earliest times to the Qing Dynasty (1644-1911). Readings are in both Chinese and English. Basic knowledge of Chinese language is required.

PAAS355.title: Modern Chinese Literature and Society 1900-1949 (in English)
PAAS355.subject: PAAS
PAAS355.description: A historical overview, followed by a study of selected works of fiction, poetry, drama, memoir, film, and popular song from late Qing and Republican (1911-1949) China, a time of political turmoil and intellectual and cultural innovation. Supplementary readings in social and political history and literary criticism. Assigned readings are in English translation and original versions in Chinese may also be available.
PAAS355.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 355, CHIN 305, HSTR 359.

crossListed.title: Modern Chinese Literature and Society 1900-1949 (in English)

PAAS356.title: The Literature of the People's Republic of China 1949 to the Present in English
PAAS356.subject: PAAS
PAAS356.description: A study of Chinese literary texts created in a range of forms and styles during the period of communist rule, with an emphasis on the years since the death of Mao and the end of the Cultural Revolution (1976 to the present). Chinese versions of all primary texts and secondary texts may be available.
PAAS356.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 356, CHIN 306.

PAAS357.title: Chinese Cinema from Text to Screen
PAAS357.subject: PAAS
PAAS357.description: Explores Chinese filmmakers' adaptations of pre-modern, modern and contemporary works of literature for the screen. Examples are taken from republican, Mao-era and reform-era film, and may include selections from Taiwan and Hong Kong directors.
PAAS357.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 357, CHIN 324.

PAAS358.title: Screening the Nation: Nationalism, Ideology, and Politics in Chinese Cinema
PAAS358.subject: PAAS
PAAS358.description: Provides a theoretical and thematic framework for the analysis of films from Mainland China from the 1930s to the present.
PAAS358.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 358, CHIN 325.

PAAS361.title: War and Revolution in China
PAAS361.subject: PAAS
PAAS361.description: Studies the dynamic interactions between wars and revolutions as well as military and political changes in modern China up to the mid-20th century. Focuses on the escalation of China's civil wars and its military engagements with foreign powers during its successive Republican, Nationalist and Communist revolutions. Special attention given to the militant radicalization of revolutionary politics and the simultaneous politicization of military forces and strategies, such as the militia/guerrilla-style "people's wars".
PAAS361.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of HSTR 366, HIST 438 (if taken as section A01 in Sep-Dec 2013), PAAS 361

PAAS363.title: Buddhism
PAAS363.subject: PAAS
PAAS363.description: Surveys the practices, doctrines, and literatures of Buddhism with particular focus on themes such as meditation, ethics, and narrative traditions from the time of the historical Buddha (c. 500 BCE) through to the contemporary scene.
PAAS363.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 363, RS 303 (if taken in the same topic), RS 363.

PAAS366.title: Gendering India from Empire to Bollywood
PAAS366.subject: PAAS
PAAS366.description: Uses a gendered lens to analyze the manner in which both the British colonial gaze and Indian nationalists imagined India. Theoretical readings, biographies and Bollywood films unpack ways in which gender, race and class constructed dominant ideas of the Indian nation and how this nationalism in turn shaped women's lives.
PAAS366.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 366, GNDR 304, WS 314.

PAAS367.title: Gandhi and the Ethics of Nonviolence
PAAS367.subject: PAAS
PAAS367.description: Centres upon the life and teachings of Mohandas K. Gandhi. Examines Gandhi's religious thought with regard to ideals of nonviolence (ahimsā) and truth (satya), as well as his attempts to realize these principles in the personal, social and political spheres. Also covers a number of religious and political figures with comparable view, including B. R. Ambedkar, Martin Luther King Jr., Malcolm X, Krishnamurti, Thich Nhat Hanh, Aung San Suu Kyi and the Dalai Lama.
PAAS367.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 367, RCS 311, RS 301 (if taken in the same topic), RS 311.

crossListed.title: Gandhi and the Ethics of Nonviolence

PAAS372.title: Southeast Asian Cinema
PAAS372.subject: PAAS
PAAS372.description: A survey of trends in the cinemas of Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines and Malaysia/Singapore.
PAAS372.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 372, SEA 324.

PAAS374.title: Short Films and Filmmaking in Asia
PAAS374.subject: PAAS
PAAS374.description: Examines short films from Asia, exploring their social, political and cultural contexts. Includes the analysis of film festivals, online streaming and the use of short film for social commentary and political engagement.

PAAS375.title: History of Decolonization in Asia and Africa
PAAS375.subject: PAAS
PAAS375.description: Emphasis on South and Southeast Asian history, and African diasporic political networks of anti-colonialism and nationalism from the late 19th century to the late 20th century. Focus on global historical changes such as the rise of trans-Atlantic slavery, abolition, the world system, as well as nationalisms in the Afro-Asian world, with an emphasis on Mohandas Gandhi, Subhas Chandra Bose, Frantz Fanon and Nelson Mandela.
PAAS375.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 375, HSTR 375

crossListed.title: History of Decolonization in Asia and Africa

PAAS376.title: Street Art and Graffiti in Asia
PAAS376.subject: PAAS
PAAS376.description: Examines street art and graffiti in Asia, exploring its social, political and cultural contexts, as well as the role of social media and new technologies.

PAAS380.title: Japanese Economy, Politics and Culture
PAAS380.subject: PAAS
PAAS380.description: Examines various aspects of the history of Japan, with emphasis on the complex, changing relationship of the economy, politics, culture and ideas.
PAAS380.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 380, PACI 321, PACI 321A.

PAAS385.title: Sex, Gender and the Body in Japanese Culture
PAAS385.subject: PAAS
PAAS385.description: Examines representations of sex, gender, sexuality and bodies in modern and contemporary Japanese literature, media and popular cultures.
PAAS385.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 385, GNDR 385, JAPA 358 (if taken in the same topic), JAPA 359 (if taken in the same topic).

crossListed.title: Sex, Gender and the Body in Japanese Culture

PAAS386.title: Premodern Japanese Literature in Translation
PAAS386.subject: PAAS
PAAS386.description: Surveys through materials in English translation Japanese literature from the earliest times to the eve of the Meiji Restoration. Major literary trends are examined including poetry, literary diaries, zuihitsu, Noh drama, puppet theatre and popular fiction.
PAAS386.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 386, JAPA 302, JAPA 302A, JAPA 302B.

PAAS388.title: Modern Japanese Literature in Translation
PAAS388.subject: PAAS
PAAS388.description: Japanese literature from the Meiji Restoration to the present day in English translation. Focuses on thematic and stylistic developments of various genres of Japanese literature.
PAAS388.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 388, JAPA 303, JAPA 303A, JAPA 303B.

PAAS393.title: Humanism in Japanese Cinema to the 1960s
PAAS393.subject: PAAS
PAAS393.description: Humanism and Existentialism as sources of social critique in post-war Japanese film, through the late 1960s.
PAAS393.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 393, JAPA 324A.

PAAS394.title: Pre-modern Japanese Theatre
PAAS394.subject: PAAS
PAAS394.description: Surveys Japanese theatre history from earliest times until the nineteenth century. Introduction to the major forms, styles and theory of traditional Japanese theatre, including nô, kyôgen, bunraku and kabuki.
PAAS394.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 394, JAPA 320A, THEA 312.

PAAS395.title: Intermediate Topics in Pacific and Asian Studies
PAAS395.subject: PAAS

PAAS396.title: Directed Experiential Learning in Pacific and Asian Studies
PAAS396.subject: PAAS
PAAS396.description: Conducted in relation to an experiential learning opportunity, such as a Coop or internship placement, either located in the Asia-Pacific region or substantively addressing a theme pertaining to the Asia-Pacific. Students prepare for and engage in experiential learning and reflect critically on work experience in an applied setting. Topics addressed include ethical issues pertinent to the experiential learning context; methods of recording and reflecting on this experience; and forms of knowledge mobilization such as report-writing, research papers, creative projects, blogging, community-based events.
PAAS396.notes: • May be taken more than once for credit in different topics with permission of the department to a maximum of 4.5 units.

PAAS397.title: Field School in Pacific and Asian Studies
PAAS397.subject: PAAS
PAAS397.description: Opportunity for students from PAAS and the broader university community to gain direct, thematic research experience in Asia.

PAAS398.title: Asia-Pacific Experiential Learning Project
PAAS398.subject: PAAS
PAAS398.description: Academic component for students in an exchange, study abroad term, co-op placement or internship that is either in the Asia-Pacific region or substantively addresses a theme pertaining to the Asia-Pacific. Students create a knowledge mobilization project (such as a research paper, creative project, blog, community event, photography project) based on their experiential learning opportunity, aspects of which are determined in advance in consultation with a departmental instructor.
PAAS398.notes: • May be taken more than once for credit in different topics with permission of the department to a maximum of 4.5 units.

PAAS399.title: Sociolinguistic Issues in Japanese
PAAS399.subject: PAAS
PAAS399.description: Examines the Japanese language in its social context. A wide range of sociolinguistic topics are covered, including non-verbal communication and types of Japanese spoken outside of Japan. Attention is given to linguistic, dialectal and stylistic variation in speech communities, and to sociolinguistic considerations such as class, gender and social setting.
PAAS399.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 399, JAPA 396, LING 396.

PAAS400.title: Advanced Research Seminar
PAAS400.subject: PAAS
PAAS400.description: Leads to the research, writing and presentation of an original paper on a theme relevant to Pacific and Asian Studies.
PAAS400.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 400, PACI 490A.

PAAS404.title: Asian Horror Cinema
PAAS404.subject: PAAS
PAAS404.description: Examines Asian horror cinema as a reaction/response to social change and trauma through representative works from China, Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and/or Thailand.

PAAS409.title: Globalization, Cosmopolitanism and Asian-Pacific Cultures
PAAS409.subject: PAAS
PAAS409.description: Explores the ways in which cultural writers, filmmakers and popular musicians in the Asia-Pacific region attempt to make sense of their worlds and construct identities in literature, film and songs.
PAAS409.notes: • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PAAS410.title: Advanced Topics in Chinese Language and Culture
PAAS410.subject: PAAS
PAAS410.description: Intended for literate speakers of Chinese. Reading and discussion from the Chinese literary and cultural traditions.
PAAS410.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 410, CHIN 420 (if taken in the same topic).

PAAS411.title: Directed Readings in Chinese Language
PAAS411.subject: PAAS
PAAS411.description: Extensive readings chosen in consultation with the instructor.
PAAS411.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 411, CHIN 480 (if taken in the same topic).
  • Not open to fluent speakers of Chinese.

PAAS412.title: Understanding Chinese Media
PAAS412.subject: PAAS
PAAS412.description: Develops students' proficiency in the language of Chinese online media, newspapers, magazines, film and television, through exercises in reading and listening comprehension. Students also refine translation skills.
PAAS412.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 412, PAAS 310, CHIN 349, CHIN 349A, CHIN 400.
  • Not open to fluent speakers of Chinese.

PAAS413.title: Effective Communication in Chinese
PAAS413.subject: PAAS
PAAS413.description: Advances students' abilities in communication in Chinese, both oral (including everyday conversation, work-related discussions, and formal presentations) and written (including reports and correspondence).
PAAS413.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 413, PAAS 311, CHIN 349, CHIN 349B, CHIN 400.
  • Not open to fluent speakers of Chinese.

PAAS418.title: Classical Chinese Prose
PAAS418.subject: PAAS
PAAS418.description: Introduces the key features of grammar, syntax and usage of literary Chinese, employing intensive study of a set of readings in the language. Readings are of literary texts ranging from pre-Han to the Song dynasty.
PAAS418.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 418, PAAS 312, CHIN 310A.

PAAS420.title: Chinese Narrative
PAAS420.subject: PAAS
PAAS420.description: Studies traditional Chinese narrative literature through reading of early historiographic writing, narrative poetry, poetic history, ancient-style prose, drama, novella and fiction. Traditional Chinese narrative theory is introduced.

PAAS430.title: Seminar in Modern Japanese Literature
PAAS430.subject: PAAS
PAAS430.description: Intended for advanced students prepared to read literary texts in modern Japanese. Course content may include contemporary fiction, drama and/or poetry, and may vary from year to year. May be taken by fluent speakers of Japanese.
PAAS430.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 430, JAPA 403A (if taken in the same topic), JAPA 403B (if taken in the same topic).

PAAS432.title: Directed Readings in Japanese
PAAS432.subject: PAAS
PAAS432.description: Designed for advanced students prepared to read extensively in Japanese. Readings are assigned by the instructor in consultation with the participating students.
PAAS432.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 432, JAPA 480 (if taken in the same topic).

PAAS440.title: Anti-Colonial Movements in Asia
PAAS440.subject: PAAS
PAAS440.description: Examines political, intellectual, and cultural histories of anti-colonial movements in Asia along with their contemporary manifestations and theoretical implications.

PAAS451.title: Asian Mega-Cities and Urban Regions
PAAS451.subject: PAAS
PAAS451.description: A comparative multi-disciplinary survey of urban transition in Asia. Several case studies introduce patterns and processes which challenge conventional theories of urbanization, and highlight implications for the future of urban societies in Asia.
PAAS451.notes: • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PAAS452.title: Teaching and Learning Chinese as an Additional Language
PAAS452.subject: PAAS
PAAS452.description: Advanced study of how the fundamental concepts of second language acquisition (SLA) can be applied to facilitate the learning and teaching of Chinese as an additional language. Examines learner language, language learning motivations, language learning strategies and other factors pertinent to SLA and their pedagogical implications for learners of Chinese as an additional language.
PAAS452.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 452, PAAS 497 (if taken in the same topic).

PAAS455.title: Authors in Contemporary Chinese Literature
PAAS455.subject: PAAS
PAAS455.description: A study of works of fiction, drama and/or film on a single topic or by a single major figure from the 20th and 21st centuries. Chinese and English versions of all primary texts are available.
PAAS455.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 455, CHIN 307.

PAAS456.title: Thematic Study of Contemporary Chinese Literature in Translation
PAAS456.subject: PAAS
PAAS456.description: Intensive study of a small number of works of fiction, drama and/or film on a single theme from the 20th or early 21st centuries.

PAAS457.title: Authors in Classical Chinese Literature
PAAS457.subject: PAAS
PAAS457.description: Studies of a number of works of poetry, prose or both by one major literary figure of the Tang Dynasty. Readings are in Chinese.

PAAS458.title: Themes in Classical Chinese Literature
PAAS458.subject: PAAS
PAAS458.description: Studies of a number of works of poetry, prose, or historiography on a single theme from earliest times to the Qing Dynasty. Readings are in Chinese.

PAAS459.title: Directed Readings in Chinese Linguistics
PAAS459.subject: PAAS
PAAS459.description: Advanced course taught in Mandarin. Intended for students who are prepared to read and discuss extensively in Mandarin. Covers aspects of the Chinese language within the general framework of modern linguistics. Topics covered may include Mandarin sound system, pinyin romanization, writing system, word structures, sentence structures, dialect research, national minority languages and language planning in the People's Republic of China.
PAAS459.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 459, CHIN 461.

PAAS464.title: Topics in Studies of Australasia
PAAS464.subject: PAAS
PAAS464.description: Examines issues and topics on Australia and adjacent areas.
PAAS464.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 464, PACI 413.

PAAS481.title: Transcultural Japan
PAAS481.subject: PAAS
PAAS481.description: Explores the society and culture of Japan as a transcultural phenomenon through areas such as mobility and migration, foodways, gender, race and ethnicity, geography and environment.

PAAS484.title: Identity in Animated Japanese Cinema
PAAS484.subject: PAAS
PAAS484.description: Analysis of the arguments various Japanese animated films make about the theme of identity and its relationship to individual, social, national and spiritual dimensions of contemporary Japan. Also considers the identity of genre in works of art.
PAAS484.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 484, PAAS 487 (if taken in Sep-Dec 2011), JAPA 324B.

PAAS485.title: Seminar in Japanese Language, Literature and Culture
PAAS485.subject: PAAS
PAAS485.description: Examines selected topics related to Japanese language, literature or cultural studies.
PAAS485.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 485, JAPA 358 (if taken in the same topic).

PAAS487.title: Trends in Japanese Cinema, 1960 to Present
PAAS487.subject: PAAS
PAAS487.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 487, JAPA 324B.

PAAS488.title: Japanese Fantasy
PAAS488.subject: PAAS
PAAS488.description: Fantasy in Japanese literature, film, anime and science fiction.

PAAS493.title: Seminar in Buddhism in English
PAAS493.subject: PAAS
PAAS493.description: Buddhist literature from a variety of primary sources. Students engage in a close reading of selected texts, with additional secondary literature and commentaries.
PAAS493.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 493, RCS 493, RS 493.

PAAS494.title: Special Topics in Translating Asian Languages
PAAS494.subject: PAAS
PAAS494.description: Theories and processes of translation, from an Asian language into English. May be offered in Chinese, Indonesian, or Japanese.

PAAS495.title: Advanced Topics in Pacific and Asian Studies
PAAS495.subject: PAAS
PAAS495.notes: • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PAAS496.title: Directed Studies in Pacific and Asian Studies
PAAS496.subject: PAAS

PAAS497.title: Special Topics in Asian Languages
PAAS497.subject: PAAS
PAAS497.description: Offered in Chinese, Japanese or Indonesian. Consult members of the faculty for subjects and availability.

PAAS499.title: Honours Thesis
PAAS499.subject: PAAS
PAAS499.description: The writing of an Honours Thesis of at least 10,000 words.
PAAS499.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PAAS 499, PACI 490, PACI 490B.

PHIL100.title: Introduction to Philosophy
PHIL100.subject: PHIL
PHIL100.description: Central works in the history of Western philosophy, with a principal goal of fostering the capacity to think logically and critically. Questions include: Does God exist? Is knowledge possible? Do humans have free will? What is justice? Figures studied may include: Plato, Aristotle, Descartes, Leibniz, Berkeley, Hume, Kant, Mill and Nietzsche.

PHIL201.title: Critical Thinking
PHIL201.subject: PHIL
PHIL201.description: An analysis of simple argument forms in natural language with close attention to the different uses of language in an argumentative context. A treatment of elementary principles of inductive logic, decision making, syllogistic reasoning, and informal fallacies.
PHIL201.notes: • Designed as a first course in logic for students with little or no symbolic orientation; it may be taken before or after PHIL 203.

PHIL203.title: Elementary Formal Logic
PHIL203.subject: PHIL
PHIL203.description: Explores the fundamentals of good reasoning by means of symbolic techniques in both propositional and predicate logic. Students learn to translate English sentences into logical notation, as well as how to use truth tables and derivations to demonstrate the validity of arguments.
PHIL203.notes: • Designed as a first course in logic for students with little or no symbolic orientation. May be taken before or after PHIL 201.

PHIL204.title: Traditions of Asian Philosophy
PHIL204.subject: PHIL
PHIL204.description: An introductory study of selected philosophical texts from the Chinese, Japanese or Indian tradition.
PHIL204.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 204, PHIL 205, PHIL 206, PHIL 287.

PHIL207A.title: Introduction to Ancient Philosophy
PHIL207A.subject: PHIL
PHIL207A.description: Central thinkers, topics and concepts in ancient Greek and Roman philosophy. Topics and figures may include: the teachings of the pre-Socratics (Parmenides, Heraclitus, and others), Plato and Aristotle; doctrines of the Hellenistic period such as Stoicism, Epicureanism and Skepticism; Neo-Platonic schools of thought; the ways these ancient philosophers and theories have continued to influence philosophy through medieval, modern and contemporary periods.

PHIL208.title: Introduction to Islamic Philosophy
PHIL208.subject: PHIL
PHIL208.description: Islamic philosophy from the 9th - 12th century CE. Topics include a brief introduction to ancient Greek philosophy that was influential on Muslim thinkers and an introduction to the thought of al-Farabi, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), al-Ghazali (Algazel) and Ibn Rushd (Averroes). Their influence on medieval European philosophy is also discussed.

PHIL210.title: Introduction to Early Modern Philosophy
PHIL210.subject: PHIL
PHIL210.description: Central thinkers, topics and concept in the early modern period of philosophy (1500-1799). Topics and figures covered may include Descartes, Malebranche, Locke, Hume, Berkeley, Spinoza, Leibniz; universals, space and time, knowledge, abstraction, concepts and substance.

PHIL211.title: Introduction to Existentialism
PHIL211.subject: PHIL
PHIL211.description: The themes and method of existentialism. Surveys the writings of a number of existentialists. Questions to be addressed include: Can the individual realize an authentic form of existence in a technological society dedicated to the ideals of comfort, efficiency, and security? Why have existentialists been so vehemently attacked and how have they responded?

PHIL220.title: Introduction to Philosophy of Science
PHIL220.subject: PHIL
PHIL220.description: The epistemological and ethical issues concerning science as a method of gaining knowledge about the world. Epistemological issues may include the distinction between science and non-science, the logic of explanation and the logic of confirmation. Ethical issues may include the ethics of experimentation with humans, animals, or the environment, the social consequences of scientific knowledge or technology and the community control of research.
PHIL220.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 220, PHIL 222A, PHIL 222B.

PHIL223.title: Introduction to Philosophy of the Social Sciences
PHIL223.subject: PHIL
PHIL223.description: Philosophical issues in and raised by research in the social sciences. Topics may include: What is supposed to be scientific about the social sciences? How do the social sciences differ from the natural sciences and from the humanities? What makes a phenomenon "social"? Are some approaches and methodologies more suited to social investigation than others? Is objectivity possible or desirable in the study of social phenomena?

PHIL225.title: Death and Dying
PHIL225.subject: PHIL
PHIL225.description: Focuses on thinking about end of life issues from a philosophical perspective. Readings are drawn from the history of philosophy and from contemporary philosophy. Topics include the problem of defining death, whether death is an evil to be feared, the relationship between death and a meaningful life, the morality and rationality of suicide and the issue of physician assisted suicide and euthanasia.
PHIL225.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 225, PHIL 290 (if taken as section A01 in Sep-Dec 2008, section A01 in Sep-Dec 2010, section A01 in Sep-Dec 2011, or as section A02 in Jan-Apr 2014, or as section A01 in Jan-Apr 2016, or as section A01 in Sep-Dec 2016).

PHIL232.title: Moral Problems of Contemporary Society
PHIL232.subject: PHIL
PHIL232.description: Philosophical introduction to a variety of controversial issues in contemporary society, focusing on understanding and critically assessing the practical ethical dimensions of such topics as abortion, euthanasia, the treatment of animals, violence and war, environmental protection, punishment, racism and free speech.

PHIL235.title: Ethics of Violence, War and Terrorism
PHIL235.subject: PHIL
PHIL235.description: A philosophical investigation of the moral problems that arise in the context of violence, war and terrorism. Topics may include: moral justifications for war and other forms of political violence; moral limits on tactics and weaponry; humanitarian intervention and the duty to protect; the coherence and limits of moral distinctions between combatants and non-combatants; transitional justice; the ethics of torture.

PHIL236.title: Introduction to Social and Political Philosophy
PHIL236.subject: PHIL
PHIL236.description: The central concepts and issues in social and political philosophy. Topics may include: the origins and limits of political authority; the nature and limits of individual rights; the moral claims of communities and groups; the coherence of distinctions between public and private; the coherence of distinctions between natural and social.

PHIL238.title: Philosophy in Literature
PHIL238.subject: PHIL
PHIL238.description: Explores philosophical theories and themes as these find expression in literature. Readings may range over the literature of many countries and are not necessarily confined to works in the Western tradition.

PHIL239.title: Philosophy and Feminism
PHIL239.subject: PHIL
PHIL239.description: An introduction to philosophical issues raised in and by feminist thought. Topics may include: the influence of feminist perspectives on the framing and study of philosophical problems; an examination of concepts, issues, and arguments underlying feminist claims; liberal feminism; Marxist feminism; radical feminism; feminism and race; an examination of current issues such as gender essentialism, pornography, mothering, and reproductive rights from a feminist perspective.
PHIL239.notes: • Consult annual Departmental Handbook for details in any given year.

PHIL240.title: Introduction to Philosophy of Art
PHIL240.subject: PHIL
PHIL240.description: Questions to be addressed include: What is art? What makes art valuable? How is art to be evaluated? Is the value of art relative to audiences? Is art a source of knowledge? What moral issues arise in connection with the arts?
PHIL240.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 240, PHIL 242.

PHIL251.title: Knowledge, Certainty and Skepticism
PHIL251.subject: PHIL
PHIL251.description: An introduction to central concepts, issues and theories in epistemology (the theory of knowledge). Topics are drawn from the following list: knowledge; skepticism; evidence; rational belief; doubt; justification; certainty.
PHIL251.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 251, PHIL 250.

PHIL252.title: Introduction to Metaphysics
PHIL252.subject: PHIL
PHIL252.description: An investigation of the ultimate nature of reality. Historical and contemporary writings deal with such topics as: substance; monism vs. pluralism; universals vs. particulars; realism vs. nominalism; mind and matter; God; causation and change; possibility and necessity; space and time.
PHIL252.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 252, PHIL 250.

PHIL260.title: Introduction to Philosophy of Mind
PHIL260.subject: PHIL
PHIL260.description: An introduction to the study of mind and its place in nature. Typical issues: Is the mind physical or non-physical? How is the mind related to the body and the rest of nature? Are conscious mental processes just neurophysical processes? Is thought nothing but computation? Can we know the presence and nature of other minds? Are animals, plants, or machines conscious? Can the mind be explained scientifically?
PHIL260.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 260, PHIL 414.

PHIL261.title: Philosophy of Religion
PHIL261.subject: PHIL
PHIL261.description: A consideration of some of the conclusions that have emerged from a philosophical examination of such religious questions as: the existence of God, survival after death, the problem of evil, the significance of religious ignorance, etc. Class discussion is much emphasized.
PHIL261.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 261, PHIL 214, RCS 261.

PHIL290.title: Introduction to Selected Topics
PHIL290.subject: PHIL
PHIL290.description: Introductory investigations of a selected philosophical topic.

PHIL301.title: Plato
PHIL301.subject: PHIL
PHIL301.description: A philosophical examination of one or more Platonic dialogues.
PHIL301.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 301, PHIL 421.

PHIL303.title: Aristotle
PHIL303.subject: PHIL
PHIL303.description: A study of one or more of the philosophical writings of Aristotle.
PHIL303.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 303, PHIL 422.

PHIL305A.title: Early Medieval Philosophy
PHIL305A.subject: PHIL
PHIL305A.description: An examination of the philosophical basis of early medieval thought and of major thinkers in the Christian, Islamic and Jewish traditions from the 5th to the 12th century CE.
PHIL305A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 305A, PHIL 245, PHIL 305.

PHIL305B.title: Later Medieval Philosophy
PHIL305B.subject: PHIL
PHIL305B.description: An examination of medieval philosophical thought in the 13th and 14th centuries.
PHIL305B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 305B, PHIL 245, PHIL 305.

PHIL306.title: The Rationalists
PHIL306.subject: PHIL
PHIL306.description: Studies in depth the so-called "continental rationalists". Examines the positions of representative figures, and relates them to each other. Emphasis is on the rationalists' preoccupation with a priori necessary truths and the principle of sufficient reason vis-à-vis their theories of perception and knowledge.

PHIL308.title: The Empiricists
PHIL308.subject: PHIL
PHIL308.description: Studies the major writings of Locke, Berkeley and Hume, with emphasis on metaphysics and epistemology.
PHIL308.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 308, PHIL 310.

PHIL309.title: Kant
PHIL309.subject: PHIL
PHIL309.description: Studies Kant's epistemology and metaphysics, principally as presented in The Critique of Pure Reason .
PHIL309.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 309, PHIL 310.

PHIL311.title: Existentialist Thinkers
PHIL311.subject: PHIL
PHIL311.description: Focuses on one or two of the great philosophers in the tradition of existentialism and phenomenology, such as Nietzsche, Sartre, Merleau-Ponty, Camus, Kierkegaard and Heidegger.

PHIL314.title: 19th-Century Philosophy
PHIL314.subject: PHIL
PHIL314.description: An examination of one or more figures or themes in 19th-century Philosophy.

PHIL316.title: History of Analytic Philosophy
PHIL316.subject: PHIL
PHIL316.description: An examination of several figures and/or ideas central to the development of 20th-century analytic philosophy.

PHIL321.title: Philosophy of Medicine
PHIL321.subject: PHIL
PHIL321.description: An examination of how our philosophical conceptions of the nature of mind and body affect the goals and practice of medicine. Topics covered may include: Is medicine an art or a science? What is health? What counts as disease? What is mental illness? Empiricism vs. Realism in medical thinking: Hermeneutics in medicine; causality in medicine; Western vs. Eastern medicine.
PHIL321.notes: • Credit for this course cannot be counted towards 300-level and 400-level requirements in Honours or Major programs in Philosophy.

PHIL330.title: Professional and Business Ethics
PHIL330.subject: PHIL
PHIL330.description: An examination of ethical issues arising in the contemporary professional and business setting; emphasis is on the mastery of representative ethical systems and concepts and their application to actual situations.
PHIL330.notes: • Credit for this course cannot be counted towards 300-level and 400-level requirements in Honours or Major programs in Philosophy.

PHIL331.title: Biomedical Ethics
PHIL331.subject: PHIL
PHIL331.description: An investigation into various ethical issues that arise in the delivery of health care. Lectures and discussions on topics such as informed consent, abortion, human experimentation, euthanasia, reproductive technologies, the health-care professional/client relationship. Emphasis on the ability to apply theoretical concepts to actual situations.
PHIL331.notes: • Credit for this course cannot be counted towards 300-level and 400-level requirements in Honours or Major programs in Philosophy.

PHIL333.title: Philosophy and the Environment
PHIL333.subject: PHIL
PHIL333.description: A philosophical investigation of the moral and conceptual dimensions of environmental problems. Different philosophies of the relation between humans and nature will be compared.
PHIL333.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 333, ES 314.
  • Credit for this course cannot be counted towards 300-level and 400-level requirements in Honours or Major programs in Philosophy.

PHIL335.title: Contemporary Moral Philosophy
PHIL335.subject: PHIL
PHIL335.description: An inquiry into basic issues and theoretical perspectives in moral philosophy. Some classic texts in moral philosophy are studied but emphasis is on contemporary literature and debates. Topics may include consequentialism, Kantianism, contractarianism and contractualism.
PHIL335.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 335, PHIL 302.

PHIL336.title: Philosophy of Law
PHIL336.subject: PHIL
PHIL336.description: An examination of relationships among law, politics and morality. Topics may include: the nature and foundations of law; how legal reasoning relates to moral and other reasoning; civil disobedience; the nature and foundation of legal obligations; theories of punishment; the nature and justification of individual and group rights; the nature and justification of international legal institutions.
PHIL336.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 336, PHIL 328.

PHIL337.title: Ethics: Theory and Practice
PHIL337.subject: PHIL
PHIL337.description: A survey of the foundations of moral reasoning and judgment that examines the origins of contemporary normative theories and their relevance to practical ethical issues. Intended primarily for students pursuing the Minor in Applied Ethics, but is open to other students.

PHIL338.title: Meta-ethics
PHIL338.subject: PHIL
PHIL338.description: An examination of philosophical issues and theories arising from consideration of the epistemic, metaphysical and semantic features of value judgments. Topics may include moral relativism, moral skepticism, non-cognitivism, nihilism, constructivism, moral realism and moral anti-realism.

PHIL339.title: Theories of Justice
PHIL339.subject: PHIL
PHIL339.description: An examination of problems in and approaches to contemporary political philosophy. Topics may include equality, freedom, structural injustice, the interrelationship between racial, gender, class and cultural oppression, injustices across borders and the coherence and cross-cultural justification of human rights

PHIL351.title: Epistemology
PHIL351.subject: PHIL
PHIL351.description: An examination of current issues and theories in epistemology. Topics may include: theories of justification; internalism/externalism; foundationalism; coherentism; naturalism; epistemic virtue; the goal of truth; relativism; social epistemology.

PHIL352.title: Metaphysics
PHIL352.subject: PHIL
PHIL352.description: Metaphysics concerns the ultimate nature of reality. This course is an intermediate survey of some central issues in metaphysics, including: existence, matter, space, time, causation, emergence, universals, and possibility and necessity.

PHIL354.title: Philosophy of Language
PHIL354.subject: PHIL
PHIL354.description: An examination of topics in philosophy of language. Topics may include theories of reference and theories of meaning and theories of truth.

PHIL356.title: Philosophy of Science
PHIL356.subject: PHIL
PHIL356.description: An examination of problems in and approaches to science as a method of gaining knowledge about the world. Topics may include: the logic of explanation and the logic of confirmation; the ethics of experimentation; the social consequences of scientific knowledge or technology; community control of research.

PHIL358.title: Theory of Perception
PHIL358.subject: PHIL
PHIL358.description: A study of philosophical issues that pertain both to the psychology of perception and the theory of knowledge. Includes the respective merits of realist, representationalist and phenomenalist theories of perception.
PHIL358.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 358, PHIL 418, PHIL 453.

PHIL360.title: Philosophy and Film
PHIL360.subject: PHIL
PHIL360.description: Explores the portrayal of philosophical ideas in film, analyzing a selection of philosophical films with regard to their content, form and effect on the viewer. Readings from philosophy, film theory, aesthetics and cultural studies complement viewing of films.
PHIL360.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 360, PHIL 290 (if taken as section A01 in Jan-Apr 2015 or as section A01 in Jan-Apr 2016).

PHIL362.title: Philosophy of Mind
PHIL362.subject: PHIL
PHIL362.description: An intermediate survey of philosophy of mind, focusing on two broad questions: what are the natures of various mental (especially conscious) states (such as beliefs, perceptual experiences, and emotions)? and what is the relationship between mind and body (or, is the mental part of the physical world)?
PHIL362.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 362, PHIL 342A.

PHIL370.title: Theoretical Logic
PHIL370.subject: PHIL
PHIL370.description: Treatment and justification of formal logic from a theoretical point of view: Ideal formal languages developed, and their relationship to natural languages discussed. Syntactic and semantic theories formalized for the analysis of complex deductive arguments. The metatheory of formal logic, relating the syntactic theories and the semantic theories, developed. Topics may include consistency, compactness, soundness and completeness.
PHIL370.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 370, PHIL 304A.

PHIL371.title: Logic
PHIL371.subject: PHIL
PHIL371.description: Studies a particular branch of formal logic. Topics may include set theory, incompleteness and undecidability, modal or other non-classical logics.
PHIL371.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 371, PHIL 304B.

PHIL375.title: Philosophy of Mathematics
PHIL375.subject: PHIL
PHIL375.description: Introduces problems in the philosophy of mathematics. Topics may include the nature of mathematical objects, the status of the infinite in mathematics, the relationship between mathematics and natural science/physical reality.
PHIL375.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 375, MATH 375.

PHIL379.title: Early Greek Thought
PHIL379.subject: PHIL
PHIL379.description: Examination of early Greek thought as embodied in Hesiod and Presocratics such as Heraclitus, Anaxagoras, Parmenides and Democritus. These figures may be considered in the context of historical and literary writings of their society (e.g., works by Aeschylus, Herodotus, Thucydides). Topics may include: distinctions among myth, science and philosophy; notions of law, morality, and causality; the influence of early Greek thought on later thinkers.
PHIL379.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 379, PHIL 381, GRS 379, CLAS 379.
  • Does not presuppose a background in either Greek and Roman studies or Philosophy.

PHIL380.title: Wittgenstein
PHIL380.subject: PHIL
PHIL380.description: An examination of one or more of Wittgenstein's philosophical writings.
PHIL380.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 380, PHIL 390 (if taken in same topic).

PHIL383.title: The Life and Times of Socrates
PHIL383.subject: PHIL
PHIL383.description: Examination of a critical moment in Greek intellectual and political life, as seen from various points of view. Topics include: Socrates' trial and its background; the rise of the Socratic conception of philosophy and its relation to the methods of the Sophists; perceived Socratic challenges to religious and social mores; written vs. unwritten philosophy; types of Socratic literature.
PHIL383.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 383, GRS 380, CLAS 380.

crossListed.title: The Life and Times of Socrates

PHIL391.title: Directed Studies in Philosophy
PHIL391.subject: PHIL
PHIL391.description: Under the supervision of a faculty member and with the approval of the Chair of the department.
PHIL391.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 391, PHIL 348 (if taken in the same topic).

PHIL420.title: Advanced Topics in Philosophy of Science
PHIL420.subject: PHIL
PHIL420.description: Investigation of the methodology, epistemology and ontology of science. Topics may include the logic of explanation, the logic of confirmation, the rationality of theory acceptance, the rationality of scientific revolutions, the unity of science, or the reality of theoretical entities.
PHIL420.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 420, PHIL 222A, PHIL 320.
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL424.title: Advanced Studies in Ancient Philosophy
PHIL424.subject: PHIL
PHIL424.description: Investigation of central figures and/or topics in ancient philosophy. Philosophical figures in the ancient world from the time of the pre-Socratics through to the Hellenistic and Neo-Platonic schools may be considered. Topics may include the nature of reality, theories of truth, ethical theories, psychological issues, political theory, or issues in logic and theories of meaning.
PHIL424.notes: • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL426.title: Major Figures in Ancient Philosophy
PHIL426.subject: PHIL
PHIL426.description: Investigation of one or more major figures in ancient philosophy.
PHIL426.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 426, PHIL 490 (if taken in the same topic).
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL427.title: Advanced Studies in Early Modern Philosophy
PHIL427.subject: PHIL
PHIL427.description: Investigation of a central topic or major figure in the early modern period of philosophy (1500-1799).
PHIL427.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 427, PHIL 490 (if taken in the same topic).
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL430.title: Advanced Ethics
PHIL430.subject: PHIL
PHIL430.description: An advanced investigation of contemporary debates in ethical theory, including issues in normative ethics and metaethics.
PHIL430.notes: • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL431.title: Advanced Biomedical Ethics
PHIL431.subject: PHIL
PHIL431.description: An in-depth study of selected topics in biomedical ethics. Usually includes such topics as informed consent, experimentation, allocation of resources, administrative procedures, and professional relationships (with clients and other professionals). Methodology includes the use of video role plays, student presentations and analysis.
PHIL431.notes: • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL433.title: Advanced Social and Political Philosophy
PHIL433.subject: PHIL
PHIL433.description: Investigation of problems in contemporary social and political philosophy. Topics may include: theories of distributive justice, the relationship between law and morality, theories of democracy, the nature of rights, liberty, political legitimacy, community and culture, interrelationships among forms of economic, class, racial and gender oppression.
PHIL433.notes: • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL436.title: Advanced Philosophy of Law
PHIL436.subject: PHIL
PHIL436.description: Investigation of contemporary issues in the philosophy of law. Topics may include: the relationship between law and morality; the nature and foundations of legal obligation; theories of international law; theories of human rights; the relationship between international law and global justice.
PHIL436.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 436, PHIL 490 (if taken in the same topic).
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL440.title: Advanced Aesthetics
PHIL440.subject: PHIL
PHIL440.description: Investigation of issues in the philosophy of art. Topics may include art and ethics, philosophy of music, philosophy of literature, interpretation of artworks and ontology of artworks.
PHIL440.notes: • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL450.title: Advanced Metaphysics
PHIL450.subject: PHIL
PHIL450.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 450, PHIL 432.
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL451.title: Advanced Epistemology
PHIL451.subject: PHIL
PHIL451.description: An advanced philosophical investigation of human knowledge and its relation to reality.
PHIL451.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 451, PHIL 416.
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL453.title: Advanced Theory of Perception
PHIL453.subject: PHIL
PHIL453.description: A study of philosophical issues that pertain both to the psychology of perception and the theory of knowledge. The respective merits of realist, representationalist and phenomenalist theories of perception come under examination.
PHIL453.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 453, PHIL 418.
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL460.title: Advanced Philosophy of Mind
PHIL460.subject: PHIL
PHIL460.description: Study of contemporary metaphysics, epistemology and methodology in the philosophy of mind.
PHIL460.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 460, PHIL 414.
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL462.title: Advanced Philosophy of Language
PHIL462.subject: PHIL
PHIL462.description: Investigation of contemporary issues in philosophy of language. Topics may include truth, meaning and reference. Authors may include Frege, Wittgenstein, Quine, Davidson, Dummett, Kripke, Putnam and Tarski.
PHIL462.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 462, PHIL 334, PHIL 461.

PHIL490.title: Advanced Topics in Philosophy
PHIL490.subject: PHIL
PHIL490.description: Advanced investigations of a selected philosophical topic.
PHIL490.notes: • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

PHIL491.title: Directed Studies in Philosophical Topics
PHIL491.subject: PHIL
PHIL491.description: Under the supervision of a faculty member and with the approval of the Chair of the department.
PHIL491.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 491, PHIL 448 (if taken in the same topic).

PHYS102A.title: General Physics I
PHYS102A.subject: PHYS
PHYS102A.notes:
• Not open for credit to students registered in or with credit in any of PHYS 102, PHYS 110, PHYS 112, PHYS 120, PHYS 122.
  • Students intending to take further courses in Physics should consider PHYS 110 or PHYS 120 rather than PHYS 102A.

PHYS102B.title: General Physics II
PHYS102B.subject: PHYS
PHYS102B.description: Introductory algebra-based survey of physics including heat, sound, wave motion, light, electricity, magnetism, and modern physics. Life Science applications.
PHYS102B.notes: • Not open for credit to students registered in or with credit in any of PHYS 102, PHYS 111, PHYS 112, PHYS 125, PHYS 130.

PHYS110.title: Introductory Physics I
PHYS110.subject: PHYS
PHYS110.description: Newton's laws; particle dynamics and curvilinear motion; force and momentum; kinetic and potential energy; circular and rotational motion; thermal physics; gravitational and electric forces. Engineering and Physical Science applications.
PHYS110.notes:
• Students with credit for PHYS 112, PHYS 120, or PHYS 122 may not take PHYS 110 for credit.
  • A basic course in physics for students planning a program of study in fields such as Physics, Astronomy, Chemistry, Earth and Ocean Sciences and Engineering.
  • Students with a strong interest in Physics or Astronomy are encouraged to consider registering in PHYS 120.

PHYS111.title: Introductory Physics II
PHYS111.subject: PHYS
PHYS111.description: Heat engines; harmonic motion; wave motion; geometric and wave optics; modern physics. Engineering and Physical Science applications.
PHYS111.notes:
• Students with credit in PHYS 112, PHYS 125, or PHYS 130 may not take PHYS 111 for credit.
  • A basic course in physics for students planning a program of study in fields such as Physics, Astronomy, Chemistry, Earth and Ocean Sciences and Engineering.
  • Students with a strong interest in Physics or Astronomy are encouraged to consider registering in PHYS 130.

PHYS120.title: Physics I
PHYS120.subject: PHYS
PHYS120.description: Particle dynamics and curvilinear motion; force and momentum; rotational dynamics and angular momentum; kinetic and potential energy; special relativity.
PHYS120.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 120, PHYS 110, PHYS 122.
  • Credit will be granted for only PHYS 112 (3.0 units) or two of PHYS 120, PHYS 130, PHYS 122, PHYS 125 (1.5 units each).
  • An enriched course in physics primarily intended for students who are planning a career in Physics or Astronomy.
  • This course may include tours of local physics research institutions.

PHYS130.title: Physics II
PHYS130.subject: PHYS
PHYS130.description: Rotational and simple harmonic motion; wave motion and sinusoidal waves; reflection, refraction, and interference; optics; sound and the Doppler effect; de Broglie waves and the hydrogen atom; radioactivity and principles of quantum mechanics.
PHYS130.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 130, PHYS 111, PHYS 125.
  • Credit will be granted for only PHYS 112 (3.0 units) or two of PHYS 120, PHYS 130, PHYS 122, PHYS 125 (1.5 units each).
  • An enriched course in physics primarily intended for students who are planning a career in Physics or Astronomy.
  • This course may include tours of local physics research institutions.

PHYS210.title: Introductory Geophysics
PHYS210.subject: PHYS
PHYS210.description: An introduction to seismology, gravity, geomagnetism, paleomagnetism and heat flow, and how they contribute to our understanding of whole Earth structure and plate tectonics.
PHYS210.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 210, EOS 210.

PHYS215.title: Introductory Quantum Physics
PHYS215.subject: PHYS
PHYS215.description: Experimental basis of quantum mechanics. Atomic structure and wave properties of matter. Time-independent Schroedinger equation - wavefunctions and probability. Introduction to the Hydrogen atom.

PHYS216.title: Introductory Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS216.subject: PHYS
PHYS216.description: Electric and magnetic fields, Gauss' law, electric potential, capacitance, dieletrics, current and resistance, resistivity, magnetic inductance. Faraday's law of induction, Ampere's law, energy stored in electric and magnetic fields.
PHYS216.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 216, ECE 216, ELEC 216.
  • Registration priority may be given to students declared in an Honours, Major, or Combined program offered by the Department.

PHYS223.title: Introductory Quantum Computing
PHYS223.subject: PHYS
PHYS223.description: Elementary introduction to quantum mechanics with special attention to two-level systems and entanglement. Manipulation of quantum systems. Quantum computing algorithms. This course includes an experiential learning component using IBM-Q and D-Wave Leap quantum clouds.

PHYS229.title: Introduction to Experimental Physics
PHYS229.subject: PHYS
PHYS229.description: Principals and techniques of experiment design and measurement, systematic and statistical uncertainties, data acquisition, analysis and the dissemination of knowledge. Laboratory experiments focus on the use of electronics, instrumentation, and optical systems fundamental to experimental physics.
PHYS229.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 229, PHYS 214.

PHYS232.title: Introductory Biomedical Physics
PHYS232.subject: PHYS
PHYS232.description: An introduction to biomedical physics. Interactions of photons with matter. Physics of biologically-relevant molecules and solids. Radioactivity and therapeutic applications of radiation. Medical imaging.

PHYS248.title: Computer Assisted Physics
PHYS248.subject: PHYS
PHYS248.description: Use of a high-level computing language for physics simulations, physics calculations and modelling of physical systems. Use of both packaged routines and purpose-written short programs for numerical and symbolic computation, visualization, and data management. Taught in a computing language with strong support for physics calculations. Emphasis on hands-on coding in a variety of physical applications.
PHYS248.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 248, MATH 248.

PHYS280.title: Special Topics in Physics
PHYS280.subject: PHYS
PHYS280.description: Occasional offerings dealing with a specific topic in Physics.

PHYS301.title: Introductory Mathematical Physics
PHYS301.subject: PHYS
PHYS301.description: An introduction to mathematical and computational techniques applied to solving physical problems. Vectors and tensors. Integration techniques. Solutions of differential equations. Integral transforms. Numerical analysis, simulation, and data visualization. Applications to Classical Mechanics, Electromagnetism, Quantum Mechanics, Thermal and Statistical physics.
PHYS301.notes: • Not open for credit to students registered in or with credit in PHYS 410.

PHYS303.title: Origin of Space, Time and Matter in the Universe
PHYS303.subject: PHYS
PHYS303.description: For non-science students interested in expanding their understanding of the physical world. The aim is to combine topics in earth physics, particle physics, astronomy, and cosmology to study the nature and origin of space-time and matter, and the chemical composition of the earth, planets and stars. Highlights of larger issues, such as the nature of scientific knowledge, and the validity of science and the scientific method. A non-mathematical approach.
PHYS303.notes:
• Credit will only be granted for one of PHYS 303, RCS 303.
  • Credit for this course will not be counted toward any Physics or Astronomy program requirement except as an elective.

crossListed.title: Origin of Space, Time and Matter in the Universe

PHYS313.title: Atomic and Molecular Physics
PHYS313.subject: PHYS
PHYS313.description: Applications of quantum physics to atoms and molecules. Electron spin, Zeeman effect. Atomic and molecular spectroscopy.
PHYS313.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 313, PHYS 413A, PHYS 413B.
  • Normally offered in alternate years.
  • Students are advised to consult the department to determine when the course is offered.

PHYS314.title: Nuclear Physics and Radioactivity
PHYS314.subject: PHYS
PHYS314.description: Applications of quantum physics to atomic nuclei; nuclear properties, structure, models and modes of decay. Radioactivity and applications in industry, medicine, archaeology and cosmology. Fission and fusion.
PHYS314.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 314, PHYS 413B.
  • Normally offered in alternate years.
  • Students are advised to consult the department to determine when the course is offered.

PHYS317.title: Thermodynamics
PHYS317.subject: PHYS
PHYS317.description: Ideal gas laws. Laws of Thermodynamics. Temperature and entropy. Thermodynamic potentials. Heat engines. Introductory statistical physics.
PHYS317.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 317, PHYS 217.

PHYS321A.title: Classical Mechanics I
PHYS321A.subject: PHYS
PHYS321A.description: Oscillatory motion, motion under a central force, dynamics of a system of particles, gravitational potential theory.

PHYS321B.title: Classical Mechanics II
PHYS321B.subject: PHYS
PHYS321B.description: Rigid body dynamics, an introduction to analytical mechanics including Lagrange's and Hamilton's equations, theory of small oscillations.

PHYS323.title: Quantum Mechanics I
PHYS323.subject: PHYS
PHYS323.description: Introduction to quantum mechanics, historical review, postulates, development of the theory and applications.
PHYS323.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 323, PHYS 413A.

PHYS325.title: Optics
PHYS325.subject: PHYS
PHYS325.description: Reflection and refraction at plane and spherical surfaces, thin lenses, lens aberrations, optical instruments, interference, diffraction, polarization.

PHYS326.title: Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS326.subject: PHYS
PHYS326.description: Properties of electromagnetic fields using vector calculus, displacement current, Maxwell's equations, plane electromagnetic waves with applications, transmission lines, and transients in LRC circuits.

PHYS328.title: Solid State Physics I
PHYS328.subject: PHYS
PHYS328.description: Physics of solids including crystal structure and symmetry; thermal, electrical, elastic, and optical properties of solids.
PHYS328.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 328, PHYS 428.

PHYS329.title: Intermediate Physics Laboratory
PHYS329.subject: PHYS
PHYS329.description: Principals and techniques of experiment design and measurement, systematic and statistical uncertainties, data acquisition and analysis. Modelling, parameter estimation and hypothesis testing. Troubleshooting, repair, calibration and maintenance of apparatus. Experiments illustrate important techniques across the discipline.

PHYS340.title: Atmospheric Physics
PHYS340.subject: PHYS
PHYS340.description: An introduction to the study of the atmosphere as a physical system. Equations of motion; force balances; thermodynamics; phase changes of water; radiative transfer; waves and instabilities; predictability.
PHYS340.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 340, EOS 340.

PHYS342.title: Computational Modeling and Analysis
PHYS342.subject: PHYS
PHYS342.description: A combined lecture and laboratory course designed to introduce numerical methods and data analysis techniques of use in the physical sciences. These include basic statistical methods, methods for solving differential equations, Monte Carlo simulation, error analysis, parameter estimation, hypothesis testing and data visualization.
PHYS342.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 342, PHYS 242, CSC 242.

PHYS410.title: Topics in Mathematical Physics I
PHYS410.subject: PHYS
PHYS410.description: Mathematical methods applied to solving physical problems. Topics include: Finite dimensional and complex linear spaces; dimensional analysis; theory of distributions and applications to Fourier transforms and Green's functions; variation and perturbation methods; nonlinear differential equations.

PHYS411.title: Time Series Analysis
PHYS411.subject: PHYS
PHYS411.description: Continuous and discrete Fourier transforms, convolution and correlation, autocorrelation, spectral density estimation, deconvolution, linear filtering, frequency domain and two-dimensional filtering. Digital data processing and computer analysis are stressed.

PHYS415.title: General Relativity and Cosmology
PHYS415.subject: PHYS
PHYS415.description: Introduction to Einstein's theory of gravitation and its experimental verification. Applications within the realms of astrophysics and cosmology.

PHYS423.title: Quantum Mechanics II
PHYS423.subject: PHYS
PHYS423.description: Further development of the theory and applications, angular momentum, linear vector spaces, perturbation theory, scattering.

PHYS424.title: Particle Physics
PHYS424.subject: PHYS
PHYS424.notes:
• Normally open to Honours students only, others by permission of the department.
  • Normally offered in alternate years.
  • Students are advised to consult the department to determine when the course is offered.

PHYS426.title: Fluid Mechanics
PHYS426.subject: PHYS
PHYS426.description: Flow kinematics, vorticity, the Navier-Stokes equations, Bernoulli's theorem, irrotational flow, viscous flow, dynamic similarity. Application to aerodynamics, water waves, low Reynolds number (very viscous) flow and other selected topics.

PHYS427.title: Geophysics
PHYS427.subject: PHYS
PHYS427.description: Principles of seismology, gravity, geomagnetism, heat flow, and how they contribute to our understanding of whole Earth structure and plate tectonics.
PHYS427.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 427, EOS 427.
  • Normally offered in alternate years.
  • Students are advised to consult with the department to determine when the course is offered.

PHYS429A.title: Honours Laboratory
PHYS429A.subject: PHYS
PHYS429A.description: Introduction to research, with several research-oriented experiments and with instruction on experimental techniques and theory of measurement.
PHYS429A.notes: • Normally open only to fourth-year Honours students, others by permission of the department.

PHYS432.title: Medical Physics
PHYS432.subject: PHYS
PHYS432.description: Introduction to medical physics. Production and measurement of x-rays and charged particles for nuclear medicine, interaction of radiation with biological materials, radiation dosimetry, radiation safety, physics of medical imaging, magnetic resonance imaging.

PHYS435.title: Introduction to Accelerator Physics
PHYS435.subject: PHYS
PHYS435.description: An introduction to particle accelerators. Survey of accelerator technology with particular emphasis on Beam optics and RF systems. Synchrotron radiation, damping, luminosity, and diagnostics.

PHYS438.title: Solid State Physics II
PHYS438.subject: PHYS
PHYS438.description: Nanoscale physics, including semiconductor nanostructures and devices, nanomagnetism and spintronics, nanophotonics, molecular electronics, and superconductivity.

PHYS441.title: Physical Oceanography
PHYS441.subject: PHYS
PHYS441.description: Observations and theories explaining the wind- and buoyancy-driven circulations of the ocean. Topics include wind-forced currents; ocean-scale gyres; coastal circulation; conservation of dynamical tracers; mixing, potential energy and the resulting basin-scale overturning circulations; waves.
PHYS441.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 441, EOS 431.

PHYS480.title: Advanced Special Topics in Physics
PHYS480.subject: PHYS
PHYS480.description: Occasional offerings dealing with a specific topic in Physics.

PHYS499.title: Honours Thesis
PHYS499.subject: PHYS
PHYS499.description: A research project conducted under the direction of faculty.
PHYS499.notes:
• Not open for credit to students with credit in PHYS 429B or ASTR 429.
  • Normally only open to students declared in an Honours program offered by the department.

POLI101.title: Canadian Politics
POLI101.subject: POLI
POLI101.description: An introduction to the social bases of Canadian politics focusing on the distribution and exercise of political power. Topics include: regionalism, Québec nationalism, and economic inequality; political parties, voting, interest groups and the mass media; the policy process.
POLI101.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 101, POLI 100, POLI 470.

POLI103.title: The Worlds of Politics
POLI103.subject: POLI
POLI103.description: Introduces students to the study of politics in three fields (comparative politics, international politics and political theory). Each term focuses on a particular theme of broad interest to the three fields such as democracy, power and violence.

POLI201.title: Canadian Institutions of Government
POLI201.subject: POLI
POLI201.description: Introduction to the Canadian system of government; the constitutional framework; parliamentary and federal political structures; institutional change and major constitutional developments and debates.
POLI201.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 201, POLI 100, POLI 102, POLI 470.

POLI202.title: An Introduction to Political Theory
POLI202.subject: POLI
POLI202.description: Focuses on one or more topics in contemporary political theory such as the nature of democracy, the role of ideology, or the functions of the state. Different analyses are compared and students are introduced to various models and techniques of theoretical inquiry.

POLI210.title: Comparative Politics
POLI210.subject: POLI
POLI210.description: An introduction to the comparative study of politics and the basic structures and processes of modern political systems, with illustrations from around the world.

POLI211.title: European Integration and the European Union
POLI211.subject: POLI
POLI211.description: An introduction to the study of the European integration process and the basic structures and processes of the European Union, including an examination of selected policies.

POLI217.title: Global Development
POLI217.subject: POLI
POLI217.description: An introduction to global development and contemporary issues facing the Global South (Africa, Latin America and Asia). Focuses on theoretical, historical and policy debates shaping global development. Topics may include: colonization and decolonization; post-colonial nation-state building; democratization; global poverty and inequality; food security; culture and development; international development assistance and the role of international organisations, NGOs and social movements in shaping development.
POLI217.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 217, GDS 201.

POLI240.title: International Politics
POLI240.subject: POLI
POLI240.description: An introduction to the study and practice of international politics. Topics covered include the historical evolution of the international system, the major theoretical approaches to the study of international politics, state and non-state actors, and key contemporary issues in the areas of security and political economy.

POLI263.title: The Politics of Indigenous Peoples
POLI263.subject: POLI
POLI263.description: An introduction to the politics of Indigenous Peoples in Canada, with an emphasis on Indigenous understandings and practices, as well as contemporary responses to the challenges of colonialism and imperialism.

POLI300A.title: Ancient and Medieval Political Thought
POLI300A.subject: POLI
POLI300A.description: A survey of the main themes and assumptions of political theory in ancient Greece and medieval Europe, including study of Plato's Republic and Aristotle's Politics.
POLI300A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 300A, POLI 301, POLI 300 (if taken prior to Sep 1982 - Apr 1983).

POLI300B.title: Early Modern Political Thought
POLI300B.subject: POLI
POLI300B.description: An examination of basic texts and persistent themes in Western political thought from the Renaissance to the Enlightenment, including study of texts by such key thinkers as Machiavelli, Hobbes, Locke, Hume and Kant.
POLI300B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 300B, POLI 300.

POLI300C.title: Post-Enlightenment Political Thought
POLI300C.subject: POLI
POLI300C.description: An examination of basic texts and persistent themes in Western political thought from the Enlightenment to the late 19th century, including study of texts by such key thinkers as Rousseau, Hegel, Marx and J.S. Mill.
POLI300C.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 300C, POLI 300.

POLI305.title: The Politics of Diversity
POLI305.subject: POLI
POLI305.description: Examines the political theories of diversity and pluralism from multiculturalism and minority rights to animal rights and eco-pluralism.

POLI306.title: Introduction to Marxism
POLI306.subject: POLI
POLI306.description: An overview of the thought of Karl Marx and Fredrick Engels, focusing on its philosophical origins, key concepts and ideas of their historical materialism, critique of political economy, political theory and philosophy. The development of Marxism after Marx and Engels, particularly in the tradition of Western Marxism, is traced in the case of each concept and idea.
POLI306.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 306, POLI 406.

POLI309.title: Democracy and Disobedience
POLI309.subject: POLI
POLI309.description: Political thought and case studies about organized disobedience to law and policy as a form of political protest; connection between disobedience and legal and social change in contemporary states.

POLI311.title: Governments and Politics in Europe
POLI311.subject: POLI
POLI311.description: Historical backgrounds to, institutional framework for, and players involved in, political conflict in European countries. Consideration is given to contemporary policy issues and the process of European integration.

POLI313A.title: U.S. Politics: Parties, Elections, and Social Movements
POLI313A.subject: POLI
POLI313A.description: An analysis of the political system of the United States, with an emphasis on elections, parties, political participation, and social movements.
POLI313A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 313A, POLI 313.

POLI313B.title: U.S. Politics: Public Policy, the Constitution, and Civil Liberties
POLI313B.subject: POLI
POLI313B.description: An analysis of constitutional politics and public policy in the United States, with a particular focus on issues related to civil rights and civil liberties.
POLI313B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 313B, POLI 313.

POLI319.title: Issues in Comparative Politics
POLI319.subject: POLI
POLI319.description: An analysis of contemporary issues in comparative politics.

POLI320.title: The Canadian Constitution
POLI320.subject: POLI
POLI320.description: An analysis of the Canadian Constitutional framework, including the Constitution acts of 1867 and 1982, the shaping of the federal system and the impact on Canadian society of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
POLI320.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 320, POLI 320A, POLI 320B.

POLI321.title: Introduction to Research Methods in Politics
POLI321.subject: POLI
POLI321.description: Advanced introduction to the key empirical research methods used in the study of politics, including interpretive, historical, participatory, quantitative, case study and comparative.
POLI321.notes: • Not open for credit to students with credit in POLI 339.

POLI322.title: Sweatshops and the Politics of the Clothing Industry
POLI322.subject: POLI
POLI322.description: Explores the politics of the contemporary clothing industry to investigate the complexities of one of the largest and most global industries. Analyses both historic and contemporary exploitation in the industry with an emphasis on sweatshops, fast fashion, and how garment work and consumption are gendered, racialized and class-based. Topics include workers’ rights and resistance, regulation of supply chains, trade agreements, migration, ethical labeling, economic benefits for global south countries and environmental impacts of garment production.
POLI322.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 322, POLI 323 (if taken in the same topic).

POLI323.title: Issues in Politics
POLI323.subject: POLI
POLI323.description:
A lecture class in selected contemporary political issues.


* Contact hours may vary depending on the topic.

POLI324.title: China and the World
POLI324.subject: POLI
POLI324.description: Examines the contemporary history of Chinese foreign policy, familiarizing the students with the development of the foreign policy of the People's Republic of China from a communist isolationist country to a rising power in world politics. Introduces the wide policy arena where China perceives, manages and develops its relations with various powers, groups of countries, geopolitical regions and international organizations.
POLI324.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 324, POLI 319 (if taken in the same topic), HSTR 365C, HIST434C, HIST438 (if taken in the same topic)

POLI326.title: Politics of the Global Arctic
POLI326.subject: POLI
POLI326.description: Examines historical and contemporary politics of the Arctic region. Topics include geopolitics, international law, political economy, climate change and Indigenous peoples. Discusses how the Arctic reflects global patterns and remains a unique region of the world. Considers the global and regional perspectives on the Arctic and issues in northern Canada.
POLI326.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 326, POLI 323 (if taken in the same topic).

POLI327.title: Political Economy in the Global South
POLI327.subject: POLI
POLI327.description: Major themes and issues in political economy in the Global South (Africa, Latin America and Asia). Issues explored may include: globalization and work, debt and development, aid and trade, south-south migration, China's role in Africa, the growing political and economic influence of the emerging economies (India, China, Brazil and South Africa), and the impact of international actors such as the World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF). Country-specific case studies are used for illustration.
POLI327.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 327, POLI 317 (if taken in Sep 2013 - Apr 2014).

POLI328.title: Gender and International Relations
POLI328.subject: POLI
POLI328.description: Examines gender inequalities from the standpoint of feminist international relations theories and through the study of key international relations concepts such as violence, globalization, democratization, transnational politics and ethnic nationalism.
POLI328.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of POLI 328, POLI 349 (if taken in the same topic).

POLI329.title: The Political Foundations of International Law
POLI329.subject: POLI
POLI329.description: An advanced introduction to the political nature of international law. Reviews the conceptual and analytical foundations of the field, as well as conventional and critical theoretical approaches to the study of international law. Also examines the main substantive areas of international law and practice.

POLI335.title: Gender and Politics
POLI335.subject: POLI
POLI335.description: An introduction to key debates about the relation between gender and politics in the Western political tradition. Explores how gender has shaped and been shaped by key political ideas (including the public-private distinction, the idea of contract, political representation, rights, justice, identity and equality), as well as connections between conceptual debates and practical policy-oriented problems in law and politics.

POLI338.title: Approaches to Political Analysis (Seminar Course)
POLI338.subject: POLI
POLI338.description: An examination of the ways in which political analysts generalize about politics. Addresses types of theory in the discipline (normative, empirical, public choice, critical discourse) and the assumptions that underpin them.
POLI338.notes: • Required for Honours students in their third year.

POLI340.title: International Studies
POLI340.subject: POLI
POLI340.description: The historical development of the modern states system with reference to its changing social, economic, and political environments and to related theoretical developments.

POLI341.title: The United Nations and Global Issues
POLI341.subject: POLI
POLI341.description: Examines the structure and functioning of the United Nations and its agencies as they address key contemporary global issues. Attention is paid to the practice of diplomacy in the UN, the secretariat and the roles of states and non-state actors. Issues may include human rights and humanitarian intervention, economic globalization and human development, climate change and other environmental problems, disarmament and health.

POLI343.title: International Organization
POLI343.subject: POLI
POLI343.description: The nature and function of international and regional governmental and non-governmental organizations.

POLI344.title: International Political Economy
POLI344.subject: POLI
POLI344.description: The politics of international economic relations in trade, investment, finance and macroeconomic policies from a variety of theoretical perspectives.

POLI345.title: Ethics in International Relations
POLI345.subject: POLI
POLI345.description: An exploration of the application of moral judgment to international politics. Introduces different moral theories and applies them to topical issues to help make reasoned judgments about important international issues.
