SPAN305B.description: Themes and cultural trends in Latin America or Spain.
SPAN305B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 305B, SPAN 305 (if taken in the same topic).

SPAN306.title: Spanish Culture (in English)
SPAN306.subject: SPAN
SPAN306.description: An overview of the culture of Spain. Consideration of the artistic, literary, intellectual, social and political trends in Spain from pre-Roman times to the present.
SPAN306.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 208A, SPAN 306.

SPAN307.title: Latin American Culture Through Music (in English)
SPAN307.subject: SPAN
SPAN307.description: Overview of the cultures of the Spanish-speaking countries of Latin America through the analysis of song lyrics, audio recordings, music videos and feature films. Exploration of some key figures, such as Salvador Allende, Simón Bolívar, Fidel Castro, Pope Francis I, Ernesto "Che" Guevara, Miguel Hidalgo, Frida Kahlo, La Malinche, José Martí, Rigoberta Menchú, Mothers of Plaza de Mayo, Pablo Neruda, Violeta Parra, Evita Perón, Diego Rivera, Mercedes Sosa, Chavela Vargas, Pancho Villa and Emiliano Zapata.
SPAN307.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 307, SPAN 208B, LAS 307.

crossListed.title: Latin American Culture Through Music (in English)

SPAN349.title: Intensive Upper Intermediate Spanish
SPAN349.subject: SPAN
SPAN349.description: Acquisition of upper-intermediate language and intercultural competencies equivalent to the B1 level of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages. Equivalent of SPAN 350A and SPAN 350B. Taught in Spanish.
SPAN349.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 349, 350, SPAN 350A, SPAN 350B.
  • Not open to native or near-native speakers of Spanish.

SPAN350A.title: Upper Intermediate Spanish I
SPAN350A.subject: SPAN
SPAN350A.description: Acquisition of upper-intermediate language and intercultural competencies equivalent to the B1.1 level of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages. Taught in Spanish.
SPAN350A.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 350A, SPAN 350.
  • Not open to native or near-native speakers of Spanish.

SPAN350B.title: Upper Intermediate Spanish II
SPAN350B.subject: SPAN
SPAN350B.description: Acquisition of upper-intermediate language and intercultural competencies equivalent to the B1.2 level of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages. Taught in Spanish.
SPAN350B.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 350B, SPAN 350.
  • Not open to native or near-native speakers of Spanish.

SPAN355.title: Communicating in Spanish
SPAN355.subject: SPAN
SPAN355.description: This optional companion course to 350B focuses on developing reading, listening, and speaking skills in Spanish at an upper-intermediate level, using a variety of literary texts and films.
SPAN355.notes: • Not open to native and near-native speakers of Spanish.

SPAN390.title: Hispanic Literature I
SPAN390.subject: SPAN
SPAN390.description: Introduces students to the literature of Latin America from 1492 to the present. Surveys the most representative male and female writers, works and movements in relation to their cultural, political and historical contexts.
SPAN390.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 390, LAS 390, SPAN 380, SPAN 385.
  • May be offered in alternate years

  • Students are advised to consult the department to determine when the course is offered.

SPAN391.title: Hispanic Literature II
SPAN391.subject: SPAN
SPAN391.description: Introduces students to the literature of Spain from Medieval times to the present. Surveys the most representative male and female writers, works and movements in relation to their cultural, political and historical contexts.
SPAN391.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 391, SPAN 370, SPAN 375.
  • May be offered in alternate years.

  • Students are advised to consult the department to determine when the course is offered.

SPAN408A.title: Advanced Topics in Spanish Culture
SPAN408A.subject: SPAN
SPAN408A.description: Explores the artistic, literary, intellectual, social and political trends in Spain from the Middle Ages to the present.

SPAN408B.title: Advanced Topics in Latin American Culture
SPAN408B.subject: SPAN
SPAN408B.description: Explores the artistic, literary, intellectual, social and political trends in Latin America.
SPAN408B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 408B, LAS 408B (if taken in the same topic)

crossListed.title: Advanced Topics in Latin American Culture

SPAN417.title: Global Perspectives in the Spanish-speaking World
SPAN417.subject: SPAN
SPAN417.description: Exploration of global dynamics in the Spanish Speaking world aiming to improve students' critical skills as well as reading, writing and speaking skills. An analysis of contemporary issues, such as globalization, internationalization with particular focus on migration, environment, gender, media and society.

SPAN449.title: Intensive Advanced Spanish
SPAN449.subject: SPAN
SPAN449.description: Acquisition of advanced language and intercultural competencies equivalent to the B2 level of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages. Equivalent of SPAN 450A and SPAN 450B. Taught in Spanish.
SPAN449.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 449, 450, SPAN 450A, SPAN 450B.
  • Not open to native or near-native speakers of Spanish.

SPAN450A.title: Advanced Spanish I
SPAN450A.subject: SPAN
SPAN450A.description: Acquisition of advanced language and intercultural competencies equivalent to the B2.1 level of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages. Taught in Spanish.
SPAN450A.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 450A, SPAN 450.
  • Not open to native or near-native speakers of Spanish.

SPAN450B.title: Advanced Spanish II
SPAN450B.subject: SPAN
SPAN450B.description: Acquisition of advanced language and intercultural competencies equivalent to the B2.2 level of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages. Taught in Spanish.
SPAN450B.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 450B, SPAN 450.
  • Not open to native or near-native speakers of Spanish.

SPAN469.title: Advanced Topics in Hispanic Literatures
SPAN469.subject: SPAN
SPAN469.description: Variable content course focusing attention on themes, literary and cultural trends, countries or authors.

SPAN470.title: Medieval Literature
SPAN470.subject: SPAN
SPAN470.description: Studies the literature of medieval Spain and its interaction with culture and society.
SPAN470.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 470, SPAN 470A, SPAN 470B.

SPAN472.title: Cervantes' Don Quixote
SPAN472.subject: SPAN
SPAN472.description: A study of Don Quixote in the context of Cervantes' life and times. May be taught in Spanish or English.

SPAN473.title: Spanish Golden Age Literature
SPAN473.subject: SPAN
SPAN473.description: Studies the literature of the Spanish Renaissance and Baroque from the 16th and 17th centuries and its interaction with culture and society.
SPAN473.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 473, SPAN 474A, SPAN 474B
  • Open to students with credit in SPAN 473A, SPAN 473C (if taken in different topics).

SPAN478.title: 20th and 21st Century Spanish Literature
SPAN478.subject: SPAN
SPAN478.description: Studies the literature of Spain from the 20th and 21st centuries and its interaction with culture and society.
SPAN478.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 478, SPAN 476C, SPAN 478A, SPAN 478B.
  • Open to students with credit in SPAN 478C (if taken in different topics).

SPAN483B.title: Latin American Fiction from the "Boom" to the Present
SPAN483B.subject: SPAN
SPAN483B.description: Introduces students to recent developments in Latin American literature since the late 1950s to the present. Covers post-boom writers, testimonial literature, the rise of literature by women in the 1980s, movements such as McOndo, Crack and narcoliterature. Works are discussed in the context of the changing cultural and socioeconomic landscape of Latin America in the last decades.
SPAN483B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 483B, LAS 483B, SPAN 480D.

crossListed.title: Latin American Fiction from the "Boom" to the Present

SPAN483C.title: Modern Latin American Literature and the Arts
SPAN483C.subject: SPAN
SPAN483C.description: Addresses modern Latin American literature and its relation with the arts. Reflects on the way writers have linked their literary works with arts and aesthetics and their impact on society and politics. Covers visual arts, film, music and architecture, as well as alternative means of expressions such as graffiti, performance and digital art.
SPAN483C.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 483C, LAS 483C.

crossListed.title: Modern Latin American Literature and the Arts

SPAN484A.title: Latin American Women's Writing
SPAN484A.subject: SPAN
SPAN484A.description: Studies women's writing in Latin America from the 19th century to the present. Discusses the relevance of each writer within her national and/or regional literature.

SPAN484C.title: Conquest and Rebellion in Latin America, 1492 to 1783
SPAN484C.subject: SPAN
SPAN484C.description: Topics include the fall of the Aztec and Inka empires, the contribution of Indigenous, European and African cultures to the evolution of Latin American identities, the Brazilian "plantation complex" and the "Great Rebellions" of the 18th-century Andes.
SPAN484C.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 484C, HIST 470, HSTR 376A, LAS 376A.
  • Given in English.

crossListed.title: Conquest and Rebellion in Latin America, 1492 - 1783
Conquest and Rebellion in Latin America, 1492 - 1783

SPAN484D.title: The Struggle for Independence in Latin America, 1767-1867
SPAN484D.subject: SPAN
SPAN484D.description: Topics include creole patriotism, the Enlightenment and Latin America, the growth of antislavery sentiment and the emergence of Dessalines, Bolívar, Hidalgo, and Morelos as leaders of independence movements. Explores the destabilizing battles between conservatives and liberals in the newly created nations focussing on Argentina, Colombia, México and Perú.
SPAN484D.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 484D, HIST 471, HSTR 376B, LAS376B.
  • Given in English.

crossListed.title: The Struggle for Independence in Latin America, 1767-1867
The Struggle for Independence in Latin America, 1767-1867

SPAN484E.title: Revolutions and Dictators in 20th Century Latin America
SPAN484E.subject: SPAN
SPAN484E.description: The Mexican, Nicaraguan and Cuban revolutions, music and nationalism, the populism of Getúlio Vargas and Eva Perón, changing attitudes towards Indigenous culture and the struggle against racism in Brazil. Marxism from Mariÿtegui to "Che" Guevara, a half-century of the Castro brothers and the long history of guerrilla warfare in Colombia. How a region that produced Frida Kahlo and Tarsila do Amaral was slow to accept an enhanced role for women in the public sphere.
SPAN484E.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 484E, HIST 468 (if taken in the same topic), HSTR 376C, LAS 376C.
  • Given in English.

crossListed.title: Revolutions and Dictators in 20th-century Latin America
Revolutions and Dictators in 20th-century Latin America

SPAN485A.title: Spanish Film
SPAN485A.subject: SPAN
SPAN485A.description: A selection of major accomplishments in Spanish-language film, from the experimental cinema of Buñuel to post-Franco director Almodóvar. May be taught in Spanish or English.
SPAN485A.notes: • If taken in Spanish, open to native and near-native speakers.

SPAN485B.title: Latin American Film (in English)
SPAN485B.subject: SPAN
SPAN485B.description: Presents a selection of major accomplishments in Spanish-language film in Latin America, focusing on historical, cultural and aesthetic perspectives. Course content varies to include the most important films, directors and actors, and recent trends in Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Cuba, Mexico and other countries.
SPAN485B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 485B, LAS 485B (if taken in the same topic).

SPAN487.title: Spain in the Pacific Northwest (in English)
SPAN487.subject: SPAN
SPAN487.description: Study of the Spanish exploration and depiction of the Pacific Northwest, including the coastline of British Columbia, during the 18th century, as presented in the diaries of explorers such as Francisco de la Bodega y Quadra, Pere d'Alberni and Gonzalo Lopez de Haro and in letters between them and authorities in Spain and New Spain (modern-day Mexico).

SPAN490B.title: English-Spanish Translation
SPAN490B.subject: SPAN
SPAN490B.description: Training and practice in textual and audiovisual translation from English into Spanish. Training in the use of subtitling software. In-class use of computers is compulsory.
SPAN490B.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 490B, SPAN 426.
  • Not open to native and near-native speakers of Spanish.

SPAN495.title: Advanced Directed Reading
SPAN495.subject: SPAN
SPAN495.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN 495, SPAN 430.

SPAN499.title: Honours Graduating Essay
SPAN499.subject: SPAN
SPAN499.description: Honours students write a graduating essay of 7,500 - 10,000 words, in Spanish and on an approved topic, under the direction of a member of the department. The essay must conform to acceptable standards of style and format, and be submitted before the end of Second Term classes.

STAT123.title: Data Science
STAT123.subject: STAT
STAT123.description: A marriage of computational and inferential thinking that enables analysts to use data to make good decisions. Introduces and develops the foundational skills required to tackle complex data science projects. Topics covered include: R programming, data visualization in R, data wrangling, statistical foundations and introductory regression modelling.
STAT123.notes:
• Not open for credit to students with credit in 300- or 400- level STAT course.
  • Cannot be counted towards the 3-unit credit limit for lower-level statistics courses.

STAT252.title: Statistics for Business
STAT252.subject: STAT
STAT252.description: Descriptive statistics, probability distributions, random sampling and sampling distributions, point and interval estimation, hypothesis testing, statistical inference for comparing samples from two populations, analysis of variance, correlation analysis, simple and multiple linear regression, chi-square test, goodness of fit test, contingency table test, time series analysis. Examples are taken from business applications. Students are expected to analyze data using computer software.
STAT252.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 252, STAT 255.
  • Not open to students registered in or with credit in one of STAT 254, STAT 250, STAT 260.
  • See "Credit Limit - Beginning Level Statistics Courses".
  • Intended primarily for Business students.

STAT254.title: Probability and Statistics for Engineers
STAT254.subject: STAT
STAT254.description: Probability axioms, properties of probability, counting techniques, conditional probability, independence, random variables, discrete and continuous probability distributions, expectation, variance; binomial, hypergeometric, negative binomial, Poisson, uniform, normal, gamma and exponential distributions; discrete and continuous joint distributions, independent random variables, expectation of functions of random vectors, covariance, random samples and sampling distributions, central limit theorem; point and interval estimation; hypothesis testing; linear regression and correlation.
STAT254.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 254, STAT 250, STAT 260.
  • See "Credit Limit - Beginning Level Statistics Courses".

STAT255.title: Statistics for Life Sciences I
STAT255.subject: STAT
STAT255.description: Descriptive statistics; probability; random variables and probability distributions; expectation; binomial, Poisson, and normal distributions; random sampling and sampling distributions; point and interval estimation; classical hypothesis testing and significance testing. Statistical examples and applications from life sciences are emphasized.
STAT255.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 255, STAT 252.
  • Not open to students registered in or with credit in one of STAT 254, STAT 250, STAT 260.
  • See "Credit Limit - Beginning Level Statistics Courses".
  • Intended primarily for students in Biochemistry, Microbiology, Biology, Environmental Studies combined with a Science discipline, Kinesiology, and Combined Computer Science and Health Information Science.

STAT256.title: Statistics for Life Sciences II
STAT256.subject: STAT
STAT256.description: Estimation and hypothesis testing; analysis of variance and the design of experiments; regression and correlation; analysis of categorical data; distribution-free procedures. Statistical examples and applications from life sciences are emphasized.
STAT256.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 256, STAT 251, STAT 261.
  • Intended primarily for students in Biochemistry, Microbiology, Biology, and Environmental Studies.

STAT260.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics I
STAT260.subject: STAT
STAT260.description: Descriptive statistics; elementary probability theory; random variables, discrete and continuous probability distributions, expectation, joint, marginal and conditional distributions; linear functions of random variables; random sampling and sampling distributions; point and interval estimation; classical hypothesis testing and significance testing. The mathematical foundations of statistical inference are introduced and illustrated with examples from a variety of disciplines.
STAT260.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 260, STAT 250, STAT 254.
  • See "Credit Limit - Beginning Level Statistics Courses".

STAT261.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics II
STAT261.subject: STAT
STAT261.description: Estimation and hypothesis testing; normal sampling distribution theory; analysis of variance and the design of experiments; regression and correlation; analysis of categorical data; distribution-free procedures. The mathematical foundations of statistical inference are introduced and illustrated with examples from a variety of disciplines.
STAT261.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 261, STAT 251, STAT 256.

STAT321.title: Data Management and Presentation
STAT321.subject: STAT
STAT321.description: Data acquisition by scraping and other means. Data storage, cleaning and wrangling. Database administration, design and queries. Presentation of data in tabular, graphical summary, and interactive formats, including special methods for spatial and multivariate data. Statistical analysis, programming, and simulation.

STAT350.title: Mathematical Statistics I
STAT350.subject: STAT
STAT350.description: Discrete and continuous probability models, random variables and their distributions, mathematical expectation, moment generating functions, sums of random variables, limit theory, and sampling distributions. Emphasis on the probability theory needed for 450.
STAT350.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 350, MATH 352.

STAT353.title: Applied Regression Analysis
STAT353.subject: STAT
STAT353.description: An outline of linear regression theory with applications; multiple linear regression, polynomial regression, model adequacy checking, variable transformation, variable selection, indicator variable, diagnostics for leverage and influential observations, multicollinearity problem, model selection, stepwise regression, prediction and inference

STAT354.title: Sampling Techniques
STAT354.subject: STAT
STAT354.description: Principal steps in planning and conducting a sample survey. Sampling techniques including stratification, systematic sampling and multistage sampling. Practical survey designs with illustrations. Nonsampling errors.

STAT355.title: Statistical Methods in Health Sciences
STAT355.subject: STAT
STAT355.description: Rates and comparison of rates: case-control studies; odds ratios; regression models; Poisson and logistic regression; dose-response models; Cox's regression analysis.

STAT359.title: Data Analysis
STAT359.subject: STAT
STAT359.description: An introductory data analysis course for students who have had an introduction to descriptive statistics, probability distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing and confidence intervals. Emphasis is placed on proper use of computer software, interpretation of output and assumptions required for use of each statistical method. Topics may include: linear and nonlinear regression, time series analysis, analysis of variance, design of experiments, generalized linear models, repeated measures analysis, survival analysis, methods for multivariate data, and nonparametric methods.

STAT450.title: Mathematical Statistics II
STAT450.subject: STAT
STAT450.description: Brief introduction to decision theory, point and interval estimation, hypothesis testing; regression and correlation, analysis of variance. Emphasis on the mathematics of statistics.
STAT450.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 450, STAT 351.

STAT453.title: The Design and Analysis of Experiments
STAT453.subject: STAT
STAT453.description: An introduction to the principles of experimental design and the techniques of analysis of variance. A discussion of experimental error, randomization, replication, and local control. Analysis of variance is developed for single factor and multifactor experiments. The use of concomitant observations. Multiple comparisons and orthogonal contrasts.

STAT454.title: Topics in Applied Statistics
STAT454.subject: STAT
STAT454.description: Possible topics include: Bayesian statistics, bioinformatics, biostatistics, clustering methods, longitudinal data analysis, mixture models, robust statistics, spatial statistics, sampling theory and methods, statistics for imaging, and statistical computing. Information on the topics available in any given year may be obtained from the department.

STAT455.title: Distribution-Free Statistics
STAT455.subject: STAT
STAT455.description: Tests based on the binomial distribution; contingency tables; methods based on ranks; statistics of the Kolmogorov-Smirnov type; resampling methods; empirical likelihood methods.
STAT455.notes: • Students with credit for STAT 454 require permission of the department.

STAT456.title: Multivariate Analysis
STAT456.subject: STAT
STAT456.description: Multivariate normal distribution; multivariate analysis of variance; regression; discriminant analysis; classification analysis; principal component analysis; cluster analysis; and factor analysis.
STAT456.notes: • Students with credit for STAT 454 require permission of the department.

STAT457.title: Time Series Analysis
STAT457.subject: STAT
STAT457.description: Stationary time series; Box-Jenkins methodology; autoregressive, moving-average and ARIMA models; smoothing; time series regression; spectral analysis and linear filters.
STAT457.notes: • Students with credit for STAT 454 require permission of the department.

STAT458.title: Generalized Linear Models
STAT458.subject: STAT
STAT458.description: Nonlinear regression models; logit and probit models for binomial responses; log-linear models for counts; quasi-likelihoods and generalized estimating equations for non-normal data.
STAT458.notes: • Students with credit for STAT 454 require permission of the department.

STAT459.title: Survival Analysis
STAT459.subject: STAT
STAT459.description: Analysis of time-to-failure data; censoring; survival, hazard rate and mean residual life functions; nonparametric estimation and comparisons of survival functions; covariates; parametric models; semi-parametric (Cox) regression model; time-dependent covariates.
STAT459.notes: • Students with credit for STAT 454 require permission of the department.

STAT460.title: Bayesian Statistics
STAT460.subject: STAT
STAT460.description: Bayesian modelling, prior distributions; Jeffreys prior, posterior distributions, single and multi-parameter models; Bayesian point and interval estimation; Bayes factors and point null hypothesis testing; Bayesian computation; decision theory. Other topics may include: hierarchical modeling, Bayesian model selection.
STAT460.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 460, STAT 454 (if taken in the same topic).
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

STAT464.title: Statistical Computing
STAT464.subject: STAT
STAT464.description: Computer representation of numbers, univariate optimization, multivariate optimization, combinatorial optimization, genetic algorithms, EM algorithm, random number generation, numerical integration, simulation and Monte Carlo integration, Gibbs sampling, Metropolis-Hastings algorithm; bootstrapping. Other topics may include: permutation tests,smoothing, reversible jump MCMC, importance sampling, hybrid Gibbs sampling.
STAT464.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 464, STAT 454 (if taken in the same topic).
  • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

STAT465.title: Statistical Methods for Genomic Data
STAT465.subject: STAT
STAT465.description: Introduction to genomic data and statistical methodology for its analysis; examples of data may include single-nucleotide polymorphisms or gene expression levels, generated from microarrays or next-generation sequencing. Statistical techniques may include data preprocessing, filtering, normalization, exploratory methods, visualization, dimension reduction, differential expression, generalized linear models, corrections for multiple comparisons, clustering, gene ontology analyses, genome-wide association studies.
STAT465.notes: • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

STAT466.title: Robust Statistics
STAT466.subject: STAT
STAT466.description: Influence function and breakdown point; efficiency and robustness; robust location and scale estimation; robust regression; robust covariance matrix estimation; robust k-means clustering; robust principal component analysis; outlier detection.
STAT466.notes: • May be offered as a joint undergraduate and graduate class.

STAT469.title: Machine Learning
STAT469.subject: STAT
STAT469.description: An introduction to machine learning methods including: Supervised learning methods (linear regression models, elastic net, LDA, QDA, KNN, decision tree, random forest, splines, GAM, and multi-task predictions); Unsupervised learning methods in dimension reduction (PCA, t-SNE, UMAP) and in clustering (K-means, clustering, mixture models); and Ensemble learning methods (bagging, boosting, stacking).
STAT469.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of STAT 469, STAT 454 (if taken in the same topic).

STAT498.title: Seminar and Independent Project
STAT498.subject: STAT
STAT498.description: Seminar and research project in statistics under the direction of a faculty member. The student is required to pursue an independent project, to prepare a written report, and to give a talk in the statistics seminar describing the work. Only available in areas of faculty interest.

TCA210.title: Introduction to the Human Dimensions of Climate Change
TCA210.subject: TCA
TCA210.description: Examines a range of understandings of and approaches to addressing climate change, exploring: the kind of problem(s) it poses; the toolkits we need to develop to engage it effectively; how to collaborate across diverse understandings of and priorities in relation to it, and the scales and kinds of actions that should be prioritized.
TCA210.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of TCA 210, HDCC 200 (if taken prior to 2023)

TCA310.title: Transformation in Complex Systems
TCA310.subject: TCA
TCA310.description: Introduces skills needed to support planning and decision-making about climate action under conditions of uncertainty, with particular attention to assessing sites for and implications of specific interventions. Emphasis placed on skills of risk analysis and anticipatory management, collaborative planning for diverse goals, and decision-making with sometimes contradictory and diverse forms of knowledge.

TCA320.title: Politics, Policies and Planning for Climate Action
TCA320.subject: TCA
TCA320.description: British Columbia is used as a case study to introduce the policy and political contexts that shape climate action across scales from local to global, including relevant institutional and governance innovations. Emphasis placed on skills and strategies for engaging and overcoming stagnation and polarization; developing strategies that are responsive to climate science as well as social and ecological impacts and effective communication.

TCA410.title: Indigenous-Led Climate Action
TCA410.subject: TCA
TCA410.description: Explores Indigenous understandings of and responses to climate change, with a particular emphasis on developing skills for respectful and effective collaboration in support of Indigenous priorities.

TCA415.title: Adaptation Planning and the Built Environment
TCA415.subject: TCA
TCA415.description: Focuses on skills and strategies for urban and regional planning in the context of a rapidly-changing climate, including appropriate use of downscaled climate models to guide adaptation planning.

TCA420.title: Water Futures: Drought, Fire, Floods, Collaborative Governance
TCA420.subject: TCA
TCA420.description: Explores the evolution of governance to address the impacts of climate change on freshwater regimes, including cycles of drought, fire and floods with a particular emphasis on collaborative governance.

TCA425.title: Organizing for Transformative Change
TCA425.subject: TCA
TCA425.description: Focuses on concepts, skills and practices for organizing transformational change, including strategic landscape analysis, effective communications and alliance-building strategies, and navigating cultural and institutional impediments to change.

TCA430.title: Future Ecosystems and Communities
TCA430.subject: TCA
TCA430.description: British Columbia is used as a case study to introduce the policy and political contexts that shape climate action across scales from local to global, including relevant institutional and governance innovations. Emphasis placed on skills and strategies for engaging and overcoming stagnation and polarization; developing strategies that are responsive to climate science as well as social and ecological impacts and effective communication.

TCA480.title: Special Topics in Transformative Climate Action
TCA480.subject: TCA
TCA480.description: Presents selected topics in an emerging field related to transformative climate action or one not covered in regular offerings.

TCA490.title: Practicum in Transformative Climate Action
TCA490.subject: TCA
TCA490.description: An opportunity to apply evolving of transformative climate action skills to field-based practice through placement with an organization, community group, or service. Involves a minimum of 100 hours of professional practice activity.

THEA101A.title: Introduction to Western Theatre I
THEA101A.subject: THEA
THEA101A.description: A practical and theoretical introduction to play analysis, dramatic criticism, theatrical form and the principles of stage production from Ancient Greece to the Neoclassical Era.
THEA101A.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 101A, THEA 101.
  • Not open to Theatre Majors.

THEA101B.title: Introduction to Western Theatre II
THEA101B.subject: THEA
THEA101B.description: A practical and theoretical introduction to play analysis, dramatic criticism, theatrical form and the principles of stage production from the Restoration Era to the modern day.
THEA101B.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 101B, THEA 101.
  • Not open to Theatre Majors.

THEA102.title: Theatre Appreciation from Page to Stage
THEA102.subject: THEA
THEA102.description: Enhances understanding and appreciation of today's theatre.
THEA102.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 102, THEA 100.
  • Not open to Theatre Majors.

THEA105.title: Introduction to Stagecraft and Technical Practice
THEA105.subject: THEA
THEA105.description: The intensive study and application of the principles of scenery and costume construction, stage lighting and theatre organization and practice. Practical assignments include the preparation and crewing of department productions, which may occur outside of regularly scheduled hours.

THEA111.title: Theatre History I
THEA111.subject: THEA
THEA111.description: A survey of the history of western theatre from its beginnings to the Middle Ages. Early forms, conventions and styles are compared with those of the contemporary theatre.
THEA111.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 111, THEA 100, THEA 110.

THEA120A.title: Introduction to the Art of Acting I
THEA120A.subject: THEA
THEA120A.description: An orientation to the art of acting and an introduction to the actor's creative process.
THEA120A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 120A, THEA 120.

THEA120B.title: Introduction to the Art of Acting II
THEA120B.subject: THEA
THEA120B.description: A continuation of the Art of Acting I.
THEA120B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 120B, THEA 120.

THEA122.title: The Acting Experience
THEA122.subject: THEA
THEA122.description: An examination of the fundamentals of the art of acting through self-exploration, improvisation, character and scene study.
THEA122.notes: • Not open to students registered in or with credit in any of THEA 120, THEA 120A, THEA 120B, THEA 121.

THEA132A.title: Introduction to Applied Theatre I
THEA132A.subject: THEA
THEA132A.description: Explores how to use theatre for community building, social justice, and educational purposes through creative exercise.
THEA132A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 132A, THEA 132, THEA 181.

THEA132B.title: Introduction to Applied Theatre II
THEA132B.subject: THEA
THEA132B.description: Continues to explore how to use theatre for community building, social justice, and educational purposes through creative exercises.
THEA132B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 132B, THEA 132, THEA 181.

THEA144.title: Special Topics in Theatre and Performance Studies
THEA144.subject: THEA
THEA144.description: Discussion and analysis of divergent topics relevant to contemporary performance culture.
THEA144.notes: • Topics information will be provided by the departmental office.

THEA150.title: Public Speaking
THEA150.subject: THEA
THEA150.description: An overview of the theoretical bases of speech communication and the development of the vocal, verbal and non-verbal skills of organization and presentation essential to effective communication.
THEA150.notes:
• Not open to registration by declared Theatre Majors with a Performance focus.
  • Credit will not be counted towards a Theatre Major with Performance focus except as an elective in the degree.

THEA205.title: Introduction to Production and Management Areas of the Theatre
THEA205.subject: THEA
THEA205.description: The basic principles and procedures of the major production and management areas of the theatre. Includes a practical assignment in a department or other designated production(s).
THEA205.notes: • Students enrolled in this course must consult the instructor before making evening or lunchtime engagements which might interfere with the schedule of practical assignments that may occur outside of regularly scheduled hours.

THEA206.title: Fundamentals of Play Analysis
THEA206.subject: THEA
THEA206.description: A beginner's guide to script analysis that focuses on how to read and analyze a play text.

THEA218.title: Acting I (non-Performance Focus)
THEA218.subject: THEA
THEA218.description: Work in characterization and scene study designed for Theatre students who are pursuing programs other than the Performance Focus.
THEA218.notes: • Not open to students with credit in THEA 221 or THEA 222.

THEA219.title: Acting II (non-Performance Focus)
THEA219.subject: THEA
THEA219.description: Work in characterization and scene study designed for theatre students who are pursuing programs other than the Performance Focus.
THEA219.notes: • Not open to students with credit in THEA 221 or THEA 222.

THEA221.title: Acting I (Performance Focus)
THEA221.subject: THEA
THEA221.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 221, THEA 220.

THEA222.title: Acting II (Performance Focus)
THEA222.subject: THEA
THEA222.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 222, THEA 220.

THEA225.title: Introduction to Stage Movement
THEA225.subject: THEA
THEA225.description: Development of a basic movement vocabulary for the stage.
THEA225.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 225, THEA 260.
  • Enrolment limited.

THEA234.title: The Director and Designer Relationship
THEA234.subject: THEA
THEA234.description: Focuses on the fundamentals of developing shared vocabularies and processes necessary in the director and designer relationship.

THEA235A.title: Theatre for Community Building
THEA235A.subject: THEA
THEA235A.description: A broad interpretive examination of the uses of theatre in a variety of educational and non-traditional settings.
THEA235A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 235A, THEA 235.

THEA235B.title: Drama in Education
THEA235B.subject: THEA
THEA235B.description: Explores a variety of drama-based activities, and ways of developing drama-based workshops and lessons for classroom learning.
THEA235B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 235B, THEA 235.

THEA236.title: Theatre History II
THEA236.subject: THEA
THEA236.description: A survey of the history of Western theatre from the Middle Ages through the Early Modern period.
THEA236.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 236, THEA 100, THEA 110, THEA 112.

THEA246.title: Theatre History III
THEA246.subject: THEA
THEA246.description: A survey of Western theatre history from the Early Modern period through the 19th century. Introduces library research methods in theatre history.
THEA246.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 246, THEA 200, THEA 210.

THEA251.title: Introduction to Design I
THEA251.subject: THEA
THEA251.description: Exploring the elements and principals of design in two and three dimensions.
THEA251.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 251, THEA 240.

THEA252.title: Introduction to Design II
THEA252.subject: THEA
THEA252.description: Development of studio techniques in drafting and physical scale model building. Computer aided drafting is explored.
THEA252.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 252, THEA 240.

THEA261.title: Costume Design I
THEA261.subject: THEA
THEA261.description: An introduction to the design principles, drawing techniques, and materials of costume design for the stage and other media.

THEA299.title: Theatre Laboratory
THEA299.subject: THEA
THEA299.description: Under the supervision of faculty, students participate in projects that include both their particular areas of interest and other aspects of the theatre.

THEA304.title: Acting for the Camera
THEA304.subject: THEA
THEA304.description: Familiarizes students with the techniques necessary to deliver a truthful performance for the camera. The course also addresses set etiquette, finding an agent, cold reading, how to do a live audition and how to prepare a taped audition.

THEA305.title: Advanced Production and Management
THEA305.subject: THEA
THEA305.description: Students are instructed and given practical experience in one or more of the major production and management areas of the theatre.

THEA310.title: Seminar in Theatre History I
THEA310.subject: THEA
THEA310.description: Intensive study of a specific period or genre. The topics for consideration change each year.

THEA311.title: Seminar in Theatre History II
THEA311.subject: THEA
THEA311.description: Intensive study of a specific period or genre. The topics for consideration change each year.

THEA314.title: Studies in Theatre of the Ancient World
THEA314.subject: THEA
THEA314.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 314, THEA 306.
  • Students should consult the department for the topic to be considered.

THEA317.title: Studies in 19th-Century Theatre
THEA317.subject: THEA
THEA317.notes: • Students should consult the department for the topic to be considered.

THEA318.title: Studies in Contemporary Theatre
THEA318.subject: THEA
THEA318.notes: • Students should consult the department for the topic to be considered.

THEA321.title: Acting III
THEA321.subject: THEA
THEA321.description: The study of acting as related to specific theatrical genres, styles or periods.
THEA321.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 321, THEA 320.

THEA322.title: Acting IV
THEA322.subject: THEA
THEA322.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 322, THEA 320.

THEA323.title: Voice and Speech in the Theatre I
THEA323.subject: THEA
THEA323.description: Work in voice and speech as related to specific theatrical genres, styles or periods.
THEA323.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 323, THEA 350.

THEA324.title: Voice and Speech in the Theatre II
THEA324.subject: THEA
THEA324.description: A continuation of 323. Work in voice and speech as related to specific theatrical genres, styles or periods.
THEA324.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 324, THEA 350.

THEA325.title: Stage Movement I
THEA325.subject: THEA
THEA325.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 325, THEA 360.

THEA326.title: Stage Movement II
THEA326.subject: THEA
THEA326.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 326, THEA 360.

THEA327.title: Introduction to Physical Theatre Creation
THEA327.subject: THEA
THEA327.description: Collaborative methods of theatre-making and performance through practice.

THEA331.title: Directing I
THEA331.subject: THEA
THEA331.description: Fundamental textual analysis, stage composition, movement and rhythm, methods of rehearsal procedure and basic techniques of working with the actor.
THEA331.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 331, THEA 330.

THEA332.title: Directing II
THEA332.subject: THEA
THEA332.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 332, THEA 330.

THEA333.title: History of Dance in Canada
THEA333.subject: THEA
THEA333.description: An examination of the history of dance in Canada. Potential topics include artistic innovations, dance as a form of social activism and the politics of the performer's body.
THEA333.notes: • No prior knowledge of dance is required.

THEA334.title: Director and Designer Relationship II
THEA334.subject: THEA
THEA334.description: By focusing on a classic, contemporary play text or devised theatre production, directors and designers are offered the opportunity to put the concepts outlined in THEA 234 into action.

THEA335A.title: Theatre in Education
THEA335A.subject: THEA
THEA335A.description: Creates workshops and/or short performances to use in educational settings.Explores facilitation styles and devising techniques to engage communities and learners in topics pertinent to them.
THEA335A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 335A, THEA 335.

THEA335B.title: Socially Engaged Theatre
THEA335B.subject: THEA
THEA335B.description: Devising and facilitation of theatre that focuses on outreach and social justice initiatives.
THEA335B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 335B, THEA 335.

THEA337.title: History of the Broadway Musical
THEA337.subject: THEA
THEA337.description: An examination of the Broadway Musical from its genesis in the mid-nineteenth century to the present day.

THEA338.title: The Broadway Producer
THEA338.subject: THEA
THEA338.description: An examination of the role of for-profit producers in the creation of shows on Broadway in New York City.
THEA338.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 338, THEA 410 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA339.title: Performances in Popular Culture
THEA339.subject: THEA
THEA339.description: Examines performances in such popular culture phenomena as role-playing games, fantasy/anime conventions, cosplay and board games. Draws on theories from the field of Performance Studies to examine how we perform while playing.
THEA339.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 339, THEA 310 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA344.title: Selected Topics
THEA344.subject: THEA
THEA344.description: An investigation of a special aspect or area of Theatre.
THEA344.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of THEA 344, THEA 390 (if taken in the same topic), THEA 391 (if taken in the same topic), THEA 392 (if taken in the same topic), THEA 393 (if taken in the same topic), THEA 394 (if taken in the same topic), THEA 395 (if taken in the same topic),THEA 396 (if taken in the same topic), THEA 397 (if taken in the same topic), THEA 398 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA344A.title: Special Topics in Applied Theatre
THEA344A.subject: THEA
THEA344A.description: An investigation of a special aspect or area in Applied Theatre.

THEA347.title: Theatre History IV
THEA347.subject: THEA
THEA347.description: A survey of western theatre history from the 19th century to the present day. Includes research with primary source.
THEA347.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 347, THEA 200, THEA 211.

THEA348.title: Lighting for the Theatre I
THEA348.subject: THEA
THEA348.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 348, THEA 342.

THEA349.title: Lighting for the Theatre II
THEA349.subject: THEA
THEA349.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 349, THEA 342.

THEA351.title: Introduction to Scenic Design
THEA351.subject: THEA
THEA351.description: A project-based course. Continues to develop two and three-dimensional design communication skills explored through the study of 20th and 21st century scenographic styles.
THEA351.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 351, THEA 340.

THEA352.title: Scenic Design
THEA352.subject: THEA
THEA352.description: Paper projects in the design of stage settings.
THEA352.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 352, THEA 340.

THEA353.title: Assisting the Scenic Designer
THEA353.subject: THEA
THEA353.description: Assisting the scenic designer of a mainstage production.

THEA354.title: Assisting the Lighting Designer
THEA354.subject: THEA
THEA354.description: Assisting the lighting designer of a mainstage production.

THEA357.title: Ways of Seeing
THEA357.subject: THEA
THEA357.description: An introduction to the language of creativity and visual expression. A study of elements of design and their application in the theatre. Consists of theoretical discussion, historical analysis and practical design assignments.
THEA357.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of THEA 357, THEA 355, THEA 356.

THEA361.title: Costume Design II
THEA361.subject: THEA
THEA361.description: The further study and development of the art, craft and practice needed in the design of costumes.

THEA365.title: Assisting the Costume Designer
THEA365.subject: THEA
THEA365.description: Working alongside the costume designer of a mainstage production.

THEA367.title: Producing Non-Profit Professional Theatre in Canada
THEA367.subject: THEA
THEA367.description: The basic issues facing producers of non-profit professional theatre in Canada. Models studied range from the large (regional or festival theatres) to the small (fringe shows). Topics include mandates and artistic vision; incorporation and governance of non-profit societies; creation of artistic vision; fundamentals of budgeting marketing, development and production management strategies.
THEA367.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 367, THEA 399 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA368.title: History of Fashion and Body Modification
THEA368.subject: THEA
THEA368.description: A survey of costume and fashion from the middle ages to present day. Historical analysis and a detailed study of how clothing and costume signals and defines culture.
THEA368.notes:
• Credit will only be granted for one of THEA 368, THEA 362, THEA 363.
  • THEA 368 may be credited as a theatre history or design requirement, but not both.

THEA390.title: Directed Studies in Theatre History
THEA390.subject: THEA
THEA390.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of THEA 390, THEA 344 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA391.title: Directed Studies in the History of Drama
THEA391.subject: THEA
THEA391.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of THEA 391, THEA 344 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA392.title: Directed Studies in Theories of Acting
THEA392.subject: THEA
THEA392.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of THEA 392, THEA 344 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA393.title: Directed Studies in Theories of Directing
THEA393.subject: THEA
THEA393.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of THEA 393, THEA 344 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA394.title: Directed Studies in Applied Theatre
THEA394.subject: THEA
THEA394.description: Supervised research in Applied Theatre culminating in the production of a specific project either written or practical.
THEA394.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of THEA 394, THEA 344 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA395.title: Directed Studies in Production and/or Management
THEA395.subject: THEA
THEA395.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of THEA 395, THEA 344 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA396.title: Directed Studies in Scene Design
THEA396.subject: THEA
THEA396.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of THEA 396, THEA 344 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA397.title: Directed Studies in Costume Design
THEA397.subject: THEA
THEA397.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of THEA 397, THEA 344 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA398.title: Directed Studies in Lighting Design
THEA398.subject: THEA
THEA398.notes: • Credit will only be granted for one of THEA 398, THEA 344 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA399.title: Theatre Laboratory
THEA399.subject: THEA
THEA399.description: Under the supervision of faculty, students participate in projects that include both their particular areas of interest and other aspects of the theatre.
THEA399.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 399 (if taken in the same topic), THEA 367.

THEA405.title: Specialized Studies in Production and Management
THEA405.subject: THEA
THEA405.description: Supervised practical experience in one or two specialized areas of production and management in the theatre.

THEA409.title: Theories of Acting From Antiquity to Today
THEA409.subject: THEA
THEA409.description: A historical survey of acting theory from past to the present. Traces and evaluates the conceptualization and expression of acting methods across historical periods and theatrical cultures.
THEA409.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 409, THEA 310 (if taken in the same topic), THEA 311 (if taken in the same topic).

THEA410.title: Seminar in Theatre History III
THEA410.subject: THEA
THEA410.description: Intensive study of a specific period or genre. The topics for consideration change each year.

THEA411.title: Seminar in Theatre History IV
THEA411.subject: THEA
THEA411.description: Intensive study of a specific period or genre. The topics for consideration change each year.

THEA414.title: Studies in Canadian Theatre
THEA414.subject: THEA
THEA414.description: Explores the dramatic texts and theatrical styles of the Canadian theatre.

THEA415.title: Methods and Materials of Theatre Research
THEA415.subject: THEA
THEA415.description: Introduces students to the skills required to do original scholarly research in Theatre.
THEA415.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 415, THEA 490 (if taken in the same topic).
  • A combined undergraduate and graduate course.

THEA416.title: Theories of Meaning
THEA416.subject: THEA
THEA416.description: A survey of the chief schools of reading and interpretation from biographical criticism to post-humanism.
THEA416.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 416, THEA 490 (if taken in the same topic).
  • A combined undergraduate and graduate course.

THEA421.title: Acting V
THEA421.subject: THEA
THEA421.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 421, THEA 420.

THEA422.title: Acting VI
THEA422.subject: THEA
THEA422.description: A continuation of 421. Advanced work in special challenges in acting.
THEA422.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 422, THEA 420.

THEA423.title: Voice and Speech in the Theatre III
THEA423.subject: THEA
THEA423.description: Advanced work in voice production and speech for the stage.
THEA423.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 423, THEA 450.

THEA424.title: Voice and Speech in the Theatre IV
THEA424.subject: THEA
THEA424.description: A continuation of THEA 423. Advanced work in voice production and speech for the stage.
THEA424.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 424, THEA 450.

THEA425.title: Stage Movement III
THEA425.subject: THEA
THEA425.description: Advanced techniques and improvisation in stage movement.
THEA425.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 425, THEA 460.

THEA426.title: Stage Movement IV
THEA426.subject: THEA
THEA426.description: A continuation of 425. Advanced technique and improvisation in stage movement.
THEA426.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 426, THEA 460.

THEA431.title: Directing III
THEA431.subject: THEA
THEA431.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 431, THEA 430.

THEA432.title: Directing IV
THEA432.subject: THEA
THEA432.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of THEA 432, THEA 430.

THEA435.title: Advanced Practices in Applied Theatre
THEA435.subject: THEA
THEA435.description: Advanced theoretical and practical engagement with applied theatre practices, including outreach initiatives in community centers or classroom environments.

THEA465.title: Costume Design for Production
THEA465.subject: THEA
THEA465.description: Supervised design and production in the execution of costumes for theatre production.

THEA490.title: Graduating Project
THEA490.subject: THEA
THEA490.description: Students undertake a special project according to their areas of interest.

THEA499.title: Theatre Laboratory
THEA499.subject: THEA
THEA499.description: Under the supervision of faculty, students participate in projects that include both their particular areas of interest and other aspects of the theatre.

TS200.title: Introduction to the Human Uses of Technology
TS200.subject: TS
TS200.description: Explores approaches to understanding media, communication, and technology with an emphasis on the critical appreciation of social, cultural, and political impacts of technology on contemporary society. Focuses on what current events teach us about the human uses of technology, and the influence of technology on humans.

TS300.title: Networking, New Media and Social Practices
TS300.subject: TS
TS300.description: Explores the hands-on application of social networking and personal technological devices, and their consequences for society. Engages virtual and mobile technologies for their contributions to personal, social, and cultural understanding. Requires written and practical engagement with social networking and communications technologies.

TS310.title: Critical Skills for Online Identity Management
TS310.subject: TS
TS310.description: Explores established and emerging technologies, security and privacy issues, communication strategies and critical practices required to establish and maintain a professional online presence.
TS310.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of TS 310, TS 320 (if taken in the same topic).

TS320.title: Special Topics in Technology and Society
TS320.subject: TS
TS320.description: Explores contemporary issues related to technology and society from an interdisciplinary perspective.

TS390.title: Directed Studies in Technology and Society
TS390.subject: TS
TS390.description: An investigation or research project on a specific theme or topic in the field of Technology and Society.

TS400.title: Technologies of the Future
TS400.subject: TS
TS400.description: Seminar on cutting-edge research in technology and society. Explores current thoughts on technological change, visualization trends, and political and social uses of technology.

VIRS301.title: Visiting International Research Studies: Education
VIRS301.subject: VIRS
VIRS301.description: Visiting international students participate in undergraduate research in Canada under the supervision of UVic instructors.

VIRS309.title: Visiting International Research Studies: Peter B. Gustavson School of Business
VIRS309.subject: VIRS
VIRS309.description: Visiting international students participate in undergraduate research in Canada under the supervision of UVic instructors.

VKUR201.title: VKURA Research Internship
VKUR201.subject: VKUR
VKUR201.description: As recipients of the Valerie Kuehne Undergraduate Research Award, first year students gain research-enriched applied learning experience working directly with a faculty supervisor.

WRIT100.title: Introduction to Writing
WRIT100.subject: WRIT
WRIT100.description: A non-historical survey of the basic structures in poetry, playwriting, screenwriting, creative nonfiction and fiction that involves the students in the writing and criticism of compositions in all five genres.
WRIT100.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 100, CW 100.

WRIT102.title: Introduction to Professional Nonfiction
WRIT102.subject: WRIT
WRIT102.description: Introduces students to the theory and practice of journalism, as well as media history and analysis.
WRIT102.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 102, WRIT 101, WRIT 103, WRIT 104.

WRIT109.title: The Writer's World in Books and Film
WRIT109.subject: WRIT
WRIT109.description: This lecture course, which is open to students in all faculties, explores a selection of authors and filmmakers through an analysis of their writing in various genres and a study of films that show us their working methods.
WRIT109.notes: • Open to students with credit in WRIT 109 if taken prior to May 2019.

WRIT120.title: Writing for the Arts
WRIT120.subject: WRIT
WRIT120.description: An introduction to the forms and techniques of non-academic composition and writing for a general audience about music, theatre, visual arts, literature, film and other cultural media.

WRIT201A.title: Introduction to Poetry Workshop
WRIT201A.subject: WRIT
WRIT201A.description: A lecture and seminar in the writing and workshopping of poetry.
WRIT201A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 201A, WRIT 201, CW 201.

WRIT201B.title: Poetry Workshop
WRIT201B.subject: WRIT
WRIT201B.description: A workshop in the writing of poetry.
WRIT201B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 201B, WRIT 201, CW 201.

WRIT202A.title: Introduction to Fiction Workshop
WRIT202A.subject: WRIT
WRIT202A.description: A lecture and seminar in the writing and workshopping of fiction.
WRIT202A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 202A, WRIT 202, CW 202.

WRIT202B.title: Fiction Workshop
WRIT202B.subject: WRIT
WRIT202B.description: A workshop in the writing of fiction.
WRIT202B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 202B, WRIT 202, CW 202.

WRIT203A.title: Introduction to Playwriting Workshop
WRIT203A.subject: WRIT
WRIT203A.description: A lecture and seminar in the writing and workshopping of scripts for the stage.
WRIT203A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 203A, WRIT 203, CW 203.

WRIT203B.title: Playwriting Workshop
WRIT203B.subject: WRIT
WRIT203B.description: A workshop in writing for the stage.
WRIT203B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 203B, WRIT 203, CW 203.

WRIT204A.title: Introduction to Creative Nonfiction Workshop
WRIT204A.subject: WRIT
WRIT204A.description: A lecture and seminar in the writing and workshopping of creative nonfiction.
WRIT204A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 204A, WRIT 204, CW 204.

WRIT204B.title: Creative Nonfiction Workshop
WRIT204B.subject: WRIT
WRIT204B.description: A workshop in the writing of creative nonfiction.
WRIT204B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 204B, WRIT 204.

WRIT215.title: Journalism and Professional Writing
WRIT215.subject: WRIT
WRIT215.description: The theory and practice of journalism, publishing, and media studies.
WRIT215.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 215, WRIT 205.

WRIT218A.title: Introduction to Screenwriting Workshop
WRIT218A.subject: WRIT
WRIT218A.description: A lecture and seminar in the writing and workshopping of screenwriting.
WRIT218A.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 218A, WRIT 218.

WRIT218B.title: Screenwriting Workshop
WRIT218B.subject: WRIT
WRIT218B.description: A workshop in writing for the screen.
WRIT218B.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 218B, WRIT 218.

WRIT300.title: Narrative and Mythic Structure in Film Writing
WRIT300.subject: WRIT
WRIT300.description: A survey course of global cinema examining archetypal and mythic structure in classical narrative film writing.

WRIT302.title: Special Study in Craft
WRIT302.subject: WRIT
WRIT302.description: A workshop/seminar in which students focus on particular elements of writing applicable to more than one genre.

WRIT303.title: Poetry Workshop
WRIT303.subject: WRIT
WRIT303.description: A workshop in the writing of poetry.

WRIT304.title: Fiction Workshop
WRIT304.subject: WRIT
WRIT304.description: A workshop in the writing of fiction.

WRIT305.title: Playwriting Workshop
WRIT305.subject: WRIT
WRIT305.description: A workshop in the writing of drama for the stage.

WRIT306.title: Digital Publishing
WRIT306.subject: WRIT
WRIT306.description: The theory and application of digital publishing in a practice-based format.
WRIT306.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 306, WRIT 306B, CW 306B.

WRIT307.title: Basic Forms and Techniques in Poetry
WRIT307.subject: WRIT
WRIT307.description: A lecture course surveying the functions of specific poetic techniques in a representative group of poems. Aspects of poetics discussed include prosody, sound patterns, diction and figurative language.
WRIT307.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 307, CW 307.

WRIT308.title: Non-Traditional and Experimental Forms and Techniques in Poetry
WRIT308.subject: WRIT
WRIT308.description: A lecture and discussion course surveying forms and techniques in non-traditional and experimental structures in poetry. Topics include world poetry and various historical and emerging avant gardes.
WRIT308.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 308, CW 308.

WRIT309.title: Basic Forms and Techniques in Short Fiction
WRIT309.subject: WRIT
WRIT309.description: A lecture course surveying the structural composition and the function of technique in a representative group of narrative prose works. Aspects of narrative discussed include: theme, point of view, scenic structure, role of narrator, metaphor, diction, plot and dialogue.
WRIT309.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 309, CW 309.

WRIT310.title: Basic Forms and Techniques in the Novel
WRIT310.subject: WRIT
WRIT310.description: A lecture course surveying the structural composition and the function of techniques in a representative group of novels and novellas. Emphasis is placed upon form and voice, as well as upon their relationship with such other elements of narrative as plot, character development, scene development and theme.
WRIT310.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 310, CW 310.

WRIT311.title: Structure in Stage Drama
WRIT311.subject: WRIT
WRIT311.description: A lecture course surveying the structural characteristics of stage drama.
WRIT311.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 311, CW 311.

WRIT312.title: Structure in Cinema and Television Drama
WRIT312.subject: WRIT
WRIT312.description: A lecture course surveying the structural characteristics of screen drama, making use of published film and television scripts, and of actual films.
WRIT312.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 312, CW 312.

WRIT313.title: Recurrent Themes
WRIT313.subject: WRIT
WRIT313.description: A lecture course surveying recurrent themes in film and/or English literature and in other literatures in translation.
WRIT313.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 313, CW 313.

WRIT314.title: Changing Perspectives
WRIT314.subject: WRIT
WRIT314.description: A lecture course surveying the different ways in which writers have tackled similar subject matter, taking its material from film scripts and/or English literature and other literature in translation.
WRIT314.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 314, CW 314.

WRIT315.title: Advanced Journalism and Professional Writing
WRIT315.subject: WRIT
WRIT315.description: A lecture/seminar course in the techniques of investigative research and feature writing.
WRIT315.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 315, CW 315A, CW 315B.

WRIT316.title: Creative Nonfiction Workshop
WRIT316.subject: WRIT
WRIT316.description: A workshop in the writing of creative nonfiction.
WRIT316.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 316, CW 316A, CW 316B.
  • Credit may count either toward a Major in Writing or toward a Minor in Professional Writing in Journalism and Publishing, not both.

WRIT318.title: Screenwriting Workshop
WRIT318.subject: WRIT
WRIT318.description: A workshop in writing for the screen.

WRIT319.title: Studies in the Graphic Novel
WRIT319.subject: WRIT
WRIT319.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 319 or WRIT 410 if taken in the same topic.

WRIT320.title: Writing and Film Production Workshop
WRIT320.subject: WRIT
WRIT320.description: A seminar, focusing on teamwork in the development of screenplays into short motion pictures.

WRIT321.title: Issues in Journalism
WRIT321.subject: WRIT
WRIT321.description: An exploration of contemporary topics and techniques in journalism and the media.
WRIT321.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 321, WRIT 317 (if taken in Sep 1998 - Dec 1999).

WRIT322.title: Magazine Publishing
WRIT322.subject: WRIT
WRIT322.description: An introduction to the theory, craft and business of writing, editing and designing magazine stories for print and electronic publication.
WRIT322.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 322, WRIT 216.

WRIT323.title: Writing for TV
WRIT323.subject: WRIT
WRIT323.description: Writing TV pilots and serialized dramas for broadcast, streaming and the web.
WRIT323.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 323, WRIT 300 (if taken in Jan-Apr 2019)

WRIT324.title: Writing Interactive Narrative
WRIT324.subject: WRIT
WRIT324.description: A workshop/seminar in writing for digital media, hyper-literature, video games, interactive installations and experiences.

WRIT325.title: Writing for Theatrical Production Workshop
WRIT325.subject: WRIT
WRIT325.description: A workshop and seminar, focusing on bringing a script from the page to the stage and including a staged reading by students.

WRIT326.title: Media Production for Writers
WRIT326.subject: WRIT
WRIT326.description: Explores digital audio, photography and video production for writers and artists in a practice-based format.

WRIT328.title: Humour Writing
WRIT328.subject: WRIT
WRIT328.description: Theories and practice of humour writing in a variety of genres and media.
WRIT328.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 328, WRIT 314 (if taken Jan-Apr 2019).

WRIT330.title: Media and Culture
WRIT330.subject: WRIT
WRIT330.description: A lecture course surveying theories and controversies in mass media and popular culture from a writer's perspective.

WRIT331.title: A Study of Narrative
WRIT331.subject: WRIT
WRIT331.description: A lecture course that studies the elements of narrative in fiction, drama, screenwriting, poetry and creative nonfiction.
WRIT331.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 331, WRIT 231.

WRIT335.title: Forms and Techniques in Short Creative Nonfiction
WRIT335.subject: WRIT
WRIT335.description: A lecture course surveying short forms of creative nonfiction.

WRIT336.title: Forms and Techniques in Long Creative Nonfiction
WRIT336.subject: WRIT
WRIT336.description: A lecture course surveying long forms of creative nonfiction.

WRIT340.title: Revision and Editing
WRIT340.subject: WRIT
WRIT340.description: A lecture course exploring methods of revision to help students become their own best editors.
WRIT340.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 340, WRIT 240.

WRIT345.title: Advanced Environmental Journalism
WRIT345.subject: WRIT
WRIT345.description: A lecture/seminar course in investigative techniques for environmental journalism.
WRIT345.notes: • Students who took WRIT 345 in January to April 2022 may repeat the course with permission of instructor.

WRIT350.title: The Theory and Practice of Literary Creation
WRIT350.subject: WRIT
WRIT350.description: A lecture course surveying the nature of the creative process.
WRIT350.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 350, WRIT 200.

WRIT353.title: Writing a Sense of Place
WRIT353.subject: WRIT
WRIT353.description: A lecture course surveying writers who have made the natural world and a sense of place strong elements in one or more works.
WRIT353.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 353, WRIT 230.

WRIT390.title: Directed Studies in Writing
WRIT390.subject: WRIT
WRIT390.description: Granted under special circumstances only.Under the supervision of a full-time faculty member and with the approval of the Chair of the department for work which can not be completed as part of a regular course.
WRIT390.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 390, CW 390.
  • Students who have completed 4.5 units of workshop credit, third- or fourth-year standing, an A average in the area of specialization may request permission to register in the course.

WRIT391.title: Directed Studies in Writing
WRIT391.subject: WRIT
WRIT391.description: Granted under special circumstances only.Under the supervision of a full-time faculty member and with the approval of the Chair of the department for work which can not be completed as part of a regular course.
WRIT391.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 391, CW 391.
  • Students who have completed 4.5 units of workshop credit, third- or fourth-year standing, an A average in the area of specialization may request permission to register in the course.

WRIT400.title: Special Genres Workshop
WRIT400.subject: WRIT
WRIT400.description: A workshop that focuses exclusively on a particular sub-genre, such as the prose poem, docudrama, dystopian fiction, lyric novel, or radio play.

WRIT401.title: Advanced Poetry Workshop
WRIT401.subject: WRIT
WRIT401.description: A workshop in which the students are instructed in the writing of poetry.
WRIT401.notes:
• Normally class size is limited.
  • A combined undergraduate and graduate course.

WRIT402.title: Advanced Fiction Workshop
WRIT402.subject: WRIT
WRIT402.description: A workshop in which the students are instructed in the writing of fiction.

WRIT403.title: Advanced Playwriting Workshop
WRIT403.subject: WRIT
WRIT403.description: A workshop in writing for the stage.
WRIT403.notes:
• Normally class size is limited.
  • A combined undergraduate and graduate course.

WRIT405.title: Multi-Genre Workshop
WRIT405.subject: WRIT
WRIT405.description: A seminar across multiple and blended genres.
WRIT405.notes:
• A combined undergraduate and graduate course.
  • Normally offered in fall term. Intended for Writing Majors who will complete degree requirements by December. With permission of department may be used in lieu of WRIT401, WRIT402, WRIT403, WRIT416, or WRIT 418.

WRIT406.title: Writing for Children and Young Adults
WRIT406.subject: WRIT
WRIT406.description: This lecture course familiarizes students with writing for children and young adults.

WRIT410.title: Special Genres Lecture
WRIT410.subject: WRIT
WRIT410.description: An examination of craft in a particular genre, such as nature writing, travel narrative, the prose poem or children's literature.

WRIT412.title: Recurrent Themes in Film
WRIT412.subject: WRIT
WRIT412.description: A lecture and seminar teaching the craft of writing about film through study of selected directors, film trends and national cinemas.

WRIT415.title: Literary Adaptation
WRIT415.subject: WRIT
WRIT415.description: A lecture course in the theory and craft of adapting prose narratives for the screen or stage.
WRIT415.notes: • Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 415, WRIT 412 (if taken in Sep-Dec 2015).

WRIT416.title: Advanced Creative Nonfiction Workshop
WRIT416.subject: WRIT
WRIT416.description: A workshop in which the students are instructed in the writing of creative nonfiction.
WRIT416.notes:
• Normally class size is limited.
  • A combined undergraduate and graduate course.

WRIT417.title: Publishing Principles
WRIT417.subject: WRIT
WRIT417.description: A production course in the fundamentals of editing and selection of manuscript materials, and the principles and practice of design and production for print and digital publication.

WRIT418.title: Advanced Screenwriting Workshop
WRIT418.subject: WRIT
WRIT418.description: A workshop in writing for the screen.
WRIT418.notes:
• Normally class size is limited.
  • A combined undergraduate and graduate course.

WRIT420.title: Film Writing and Production
WRIT420.subject: WRIT
WRIT420.description: Advanced narrative film writing and the techniques of film production. Focuses on script analysis, screen-directing technique and film production.

WRIT440.title: The Writing Business
WRIT440.subject: WRIT
WRIT440.description: A lecture course that prepares students for careers as writers.

WRIT490.title: Directed Studies in Writing
WRIT490.subject: WRIT
WRIT490.description: Granted under special circumstances only.Under the supervision of a full-time faculty member and with the approval of the Chair of the department for work which can not be completed as part of a regular course.
WRIT490.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 490, CW 490.
  • Students who have completed 7.5 units of workshop credit, third- or fourth-year standing, an A average in the area of specialization may request permission to register in the course.

WRIT491.title: Directed Studies in Writing
WRIT491.subject: WRIT
WRIT491.description: Granted under special circumstances only.Under the supervision of a full-time faculty member and with the approval of the Chair of the department for work which can not be completed as part of a regular course.
WRIT491.notes:
• Credit will be granted for only one of WRIT 491, CW 491.
  • Students who have completed 7.5 units of workshop credit, third- or fourth-year standing, an A average in the area of specialization may request permission to register in the course.
